headline: Guess Who's Coming to Davos
abstract: Every year, Klaus Schwab throws the ultimate A-list party - gathering executives, politicians and even rock stars for the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Is Your House Overvalued?
abstract: Four days after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, pronounced the nation's housing market frothy, a new report on home prices this week suggested that he might have been understating the situation. Even after one of the steepest run-ups on record, home prices have jumped another 15 percent over the last year.

headline: Intel Is Target of Antitrust Suit by Rival Chip Maker
abstract: The chip maker accused Intel of antitrust violations, including strong-arm tactics intended to keep business away from A.M.D.

headline: Microsoft to Pay I.B.M. $775 Million to Settle Antitrust Claims
abstract: The settlement stems from the Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft in the mid-1990's.

headline: DreamWorks Forecasts Loss and Its Stock Plunges
abstract: Shares of DreamWorks Animation fell 13.2 percent today after the company forecast a second-quarter loss.

headline: DreamWorks Forecasts Loss and Its Stock Plunges
abstract: Shares of DreamWorks Animation fell 13.2 percent today after the company forecast a second-quarter loss.

headline: Time Warner to Pay $2.4 Billion for AOL Suit
abstract: The settlement eclipsed Time Warner's revenues for the second quarter, and it posted a loss of $1.2 billion.

headline: New Sun Software to Work With Microsoft
abstract: Sun Microsystems is hoping to steal market share from Microsoft with the release of a new version of its business software, StarOffice.

headline: At Last, M.I.T. Fields A Strong Sports Team
abstract: The new world of sports management met the hallowed halls of academia last week, when the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management introduced its first course on the subject, taught by a protÃ©gÃ© of Bill James, the baseball statistician hero of

headline: Oracle to Acquire Siebel Systems for $5.85 Billion
abstract: Oracle said the deal would make it the world's No. 1 producer of software for managing sales contacts.

headline: Suddenly, an Affinity for Teenagers
abstract: News Corporation has paid $580 million for the acquisition of MySpace.com, a social network used by 33 million young people.

headline: Crowds Usher in Holiday Shopping Season
abstract: Millions of Americans mobbed discount stores, raced into suburban malls and swarmed downtown shopping districts in a retail ritual whose outlandishness  seems to grow with every season.

headline: Ronald Burkle, the Complete Interview
abstract: As more consumers make their way to the ÂnaturalÂ and ÂorganicÂ aisles of their local food stores, the supermarket business has found itself in a bit of a fixpickle.

headline: For Some, Just Reading a Column Isn't Enough
abstract: FOR my last column of the year, I'm letting a few readers have their say. Every column has elicited reaction; however the ones I assume are going to generate the biggest fuss aren't always the ones that do. Somewhat to my surprise, the strongest responses have been to my columns on computers (we can thank the Mac users for that), on hiring private nurses and on the Do Not Call registry (mainly those begging for information on a similar Do Not Fax registry.).

headline:
Hot Technology for Chilly 
Streets in Estonia
abstract: Skype has become a hot calling card for Estonia, which has turned itself into a sort of Silicon Valley on the Baltic Sea.

headline: Any Science at Davos Is Anything but Dismal
abstract: Davos, a high-altitude schmooze-fest of rare quality, is a decent barometer of economic and political stability in the world.

headline: Microsoft Vows to Fight South Korean Antitrust Decision
abstract: Microsoft Corp. vowed Friday to appeal a decision by South Korea’s antitrust regulators concluding the U.S. company had abused its market dominance and ordering it to offer alternative versions of Windows. The commission had ruled that Microsoft’s practice of tying certain software to its flagship Windows operating systems was an abuse of its dominant position in the market.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Jim Anstey, vice president and brand action director at Lime Public Relations and Promotion, New York, was promoted to partner. Lime is part of the Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners unit of MDC Partners.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Microsoft? Not VC’s
abstract: Microsoft used to cast such a pall over startups that venture capitalists would ask them the “M question” — how does the company plan to coexist with Microsoft? And if the answer was that the startup planned to compete with the software giant, then venture capitalists wouldn’t invest.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Maker of Remote Sensors
abstract: Microsoft has confirmed that it plans to buy Vexcel, a maker of remote sensors, to help expand Microsoft’s digital mapping efforts. In a statement on Monday, Microsoft said the pending deal would help it with its efforts “to deliver a dynamic immersive digital representation of the real world that provides the best local search and mapping experience.”

headline: Microsoft Accuses Europe of Colluding With Rivals
abstract: Microsoft‘s battle with the European Commission escalated Thursday, as the company accused the commission of colluding with its competitors in the software market and of again withholding documents it says are crucial to its defense in an antitrust case.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Internet Software Firms
abstract: Onfolio Inc., a privately held Cambridge company that makes software enabling Web surfers to store pages, pictures, and other Internet content and retrieve it later, has been acquired by Microsoft Corp. for an undisclosed sum, the companies are expected to disclose this morning.

headline: Judge Blocks Microsoft Request for Rivals’ Documents
abstract: District Court in California on Wednesday quashed an attempt by Microsoft to force Sun Microsystems and Oracle to provide documents in its battle with the European Commission.

headline: Europeans Again Accuse Microsoft of Flouting Antitrust Ruling
abstract: An independent monitor called the software company's responses "incomplete, inaccurate and unusable."

headline: Seeking to Mollify Europe, Microsoft Offers to Assist Rivals
abstract: Microsoft offered on Wednesday to give rival software companies unlimited technical support to help them develop programs that work smoothly with the Windows operating system, the company’s latest effort to comply with a European Commission order and avoid daily fines of up to 2 million euros ($2.4 million).

headline: U.S. Asks European Union to Be Fair in Microsoft Case
abstract: The United States government has intervened in Microsoft’s antitrust dispute with the European Commission, urging it and the 25 national governments in the European Union to be fair to the company, American diplomats and European officials said on Thursday.

headline: Microsoft Steps up EU Battle by Publishing Dispute File
abstract: Microsoft last night stepped up its antitrust battle with the European Commission by publishing letters between Steve Ballmer, its chief executive, and Neelie Kroes, the EU Competition Commissioner, to show that it had complied with a Brussels mandate to allow competitors access to its technology.

headline: Centeris Raises Series B Round
abstract: Centeris, a software maker that integrates Linux servers in a Microsoft Windows network, said it’s raised $11.5 million in Series B financing. Participating venture capital companies included Trinity Ventures of Menlo Park, Calif., Intel Capital of Santa Clara, Calif., and Ignition Partners of Bellevue, Wash.

headline: On the Ethanol Bandwagon, Big Names and Big Risks
abstract: Big name investors, like  Vinod Khosla, founder of Sun Microsystems and former partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, Sir Richard Branson, chairman of the Virgin Group, and Bill Gates of Microsoft, are embracing ethanol the plant-derived fuel that some say could rapidly displace gasoline.

headline: Why Hank Paulson Isn’t Getting Back to You
abstract: If you are trying to reach the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, don’t fire up your Microsoft Outlook.

headline: Google’s Writerly Deal: A Symptom of Start-Up Fever?
abstract: Two major questions emerge from Google‘s recently announced acquisition of Web-based word-processing start-up Writely. The obvious one — how does it fit Google’s business strategy? — is generating a lot of discussion, as one would expect. But the secondary question — why are tiny Internet companies with no business model being bought so quickly? — is getting louder as well.

headline: Skype Backers Get Behind AllPeers
abstract: The venture capitalists behind Skype are placing a new bet on AllPeers, a start-up based in Oxford, England.

headline: Armed With BlackBerry Bounty, Will NTP Sue Again?
abstract: With $612.5 million coming in from the maker of the BlackBerry messaging device, patent holding company NTP has plenty of ammunition for its next move — whatever that may be.

headline: More Software Deals Ahead?
abstract: The recent uptick in software-industry mergers and acquisitions is expected to continue into 2006, according to a UBS Securities research report highlighted in Barron’s.

headline: Challenge to iPod Restrictions Advances in French Legislature
abstract: French lawmakers approved copyright legislation on Tuesday with a novel approach to the idea of digital freedom of choice: requiring online music vendors to make songs available for use on any digital player.

headline: AT&T Shares Slip as Investors Weigh $67 Billion BellSouth Deal
Ethanol Makers File For I.P.O.’s as Sector Gets Hot
abstract: Just how hot is ethanol? Consider that two producers of the alternative fuel filed for initial public offerings on the same day Thursday. While the proposed I.P.O.’s are small — they hope to raise a maximum of $200 million between them — they reflect the mounting buzz surrounding this plant-derived fuel.

headline: Gladwell vs. Gladwell
abstract: Malcolm Gladwell, a writer for The New Yorker, has reversed the opposition on Canada's single-payer health care system that he voiced six years ago.

headline: Sony Delays Launch of PlayStation3
abstract: The company portrayed the move as a marketing decision but analysts said it may reflect difficulty in containing high component prices.

headline: Microsoft Fights Europe's Antitrust Ruling on Windows
abstract: Microsoft began its weeklong appeal of the European Union's decision to require the company to provide Windows software without a built-in video and music player.

headline: Microsoft Buys ProClarity
abstract: Microsoft announced Monday that it plans to acquire business analytics software developer ProClarity to increase its presence in the business intelligence market.

headline: Microsoft a Loser in Patent Suit
abstract: A federal jury in East Texas decided on Wednesday that Microsoft and Autodesk should pay a Michigan technology company $133 million for infringing on two software patents. The lawsuit, filed in 2004 by z4 Technologies of Commerce Township, Mich., claimed that Microsoft and Autodesk used two z4 patents in Office and AutoCad software programs without paying royalty fees.

headline: Is Microsoft Preparing A Big Attack?
abstract: Microsoft reported strong third-quarter revenue growth on Thursday, but analysts said the company also telegraphed a significant increase in spending, an indication that it was preparing to take on its big online rivals, Google and Yahoo.

headline: Should Microsoft Just Buy Apple?
abstract: Imagine if Coca-Cola agreed to stock Pepsi in its vending machines.

headline: Microsoft’s European Antitrust Battle Gets Messy
abstract: Microsoft‘s antitrust battle in Europe threatens to snarl the release of the next version of Windows and has turned into a big distraction for executives that could spur more lawsuits, analysts and investors say.

headline: Microsoft Said to Plan Bid for Videogame Advertiser
abstract: Microsoft plans to pay $200 million to $400 million for Massive, a privately held company that places ads in videogames, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: All Eyes on Microsoft’s European Legal Adventure
abstract: Tech executives from around the globe will be focused on a Luxembourg courtroom over the next week, as one of the world’s most closely watched legal battles reaches its next step. Starting Monday, Microsoft will square off against the European Commission in an appeal of the commission’s tough 2004 antitrust ruling against the software giant, which included a record $612 million fine.

headline: Microsoft Says Its Rivals Get a ‘Free Ride’
abstract: Microsoft said on Wednesday that the European Commission had forced it to hand over trade secrets to rivals, effectively giving them a “free ride” on the work the software maker did to acquire new customers and develop new technologies

headline: Microsoft Gets ‘God Games’ Guru With Lionhead Deal
abstract: To read the BBC News Web site’s article on Microsoft‘s purchase of British videogame maker Lionhead Studios, the story is not one company buying another — it is the acquisition of one person.

headline: 2 Sides Differ Over Results of Hearing on Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft left a two-day antitrust hearing in Brussels on Friday claiming it had reached a breakthrough with European regulators, but regulators and rivals dismissed the claim as an exaggeration. Microsoft was making a last-ditch attempt to avoid daily fines of up to two million euros ($2.4 million) for failing to honor an antitrust ruling handed down by the European Commission in March 2004.

headline: Microsoft in European Court Says 2004 Ruling Is a Failure
abstract: While Microsoft and the European Commission took turns denouncing each other’s interpretation of events that resulted in the 2004 antitrust ruling against the company, they did agree on one thing on Tuesday: The commission’s remedy for restoring competition in the market for software that plays music and videos has failed.

headline: Lucent Takes Microsoft to Court Over Xbox Technology
abstract: Lucent Technologies has filed a patent infringement suit against Microsoft over the same MPEG-2 decoding technology at the center of a 2003 legal dispute.

headline: Discord at European Court Handling Microsoft’s Antitrust Case
abstract: Forbidden from publishing dissenting opinions and guarded in their relations with the media, the judges who sit on the European Union’s second-highest tribunal were once a picture of unanimity when they pronounced on merger reviews, trademark law and trade disputes.

headline: U.S. Justices May Review Patent Case
abstract: The Supreme Court asked the Bush administration yesterday for help in deciding whether to review a patent dispute between Microsoft and AT&T over technology used to improve Internet voice transmissions.

headline: Bill Gates Venture Firm Goes Green
abstract: Cascade Investment, a venture and investment firm funded by Microsoft chairman Bill Gates, has finalized an $84 million investment in Pacific Ethanol, as the momentum for clean technology grows. Fresno, Calif.-based Pacific manufactures a corn-derived ethanol that can be mixed with gas to power cars or, potentially, in hydrogen fuel cells.

headline: Google Pockets $2 Billion in Stock Sale
abstract: Google  raised $2.07 billion in a stock sale that will bolster cash reserves to fight Yahoo and Microsoft. The 5.3 million shares were priced at $389.75 each, Mountain View, California-based Google said Friday in a statement. Its second stock sale in seven months raised more than Google’s $1.67 billion initial public offering in August 2004.

headline: Oracle’s Ellison Considers Linux Moves
abstract: Larry Ellison has never shied away from a fight. Now he’s apparently looking at taking on Microsoft in the operating system arena, by going the Linux route. Ellison told the Financial Times that he was considering launching a version of the Linux operating system, and has looked into buying either Red Hat or Novell, the two companies which dominate the Linux market.

headline: “De-equitization” and its Discontents
abstract: There is a term for all those things that companies do to mop up their publicly held stock: de-equitization.

headline: Maker of WordPerfect Tries Its Hand at IPO
abstract: Corel, once one of Canada’s biggest software companies, is set to go public again this week, but the company’s flagship product may be a relic of the computer age. Corel, a provider of word processing and digital imaging software, plans to sell 8 million shares Tuesday at an estimated price of $18 to $20 a share.

headline: $10 Billion Burning a Hole in Google’s Pocket
abstract: Google‘s growing cash hoard (analysts predict that Google could have more than $12 billion by year’s end) has Wall Street speculating about what the company might be planning to do next. While the company is mum on its plans for the money, analysts expect the search engine to continue its strategy of acquiring smaller firms.

headline: TheStreet.com’s ‘Dumbest Things': Eyecare, Skilling, More
abstract: In the latest edition of “The Five Dumbest Things on Wall Street This Week,” TheStreet.com takes aim at Bausch & Lomb‘s eye-watering troubles, Jeffrey Skilling’s need to hire Emily Post and Bill Gates’ non-analog world.

headline: U.S. Economic Growth Rises Sharply
abstract: The economy grew at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the first quarter, its fastest pace in more than two years.

headline: Rising Yuan Pushes China Upmarket
abstract: If the United States persuades China to push up the value of its currency, there could be some unintended consequences.

headline: Microsoft Says New Windows Is on Schedule
abstract: Bill Gates announced the release of the final test version of the program, along with test versions of its Office business software suite and Longhorn server software on Tuesday.

headline: Judge Extends Oversight of Microsoft
abstract: A federal judge approved a two-year extension of court supervision, in an effort to ensure that Microsoft meets the terms of its antitrust settlement.

headline: Flaw in Microsoft Word Used in Computer Attack
abstract: Symantec said would-be intruders had already tried to compromise PC's at a Japanese government agency by exploiting the flaw.

headline: U.S. Says Microsoft Browser Is No Threat to Competition
abstract: The Justice Department found that the design of Microsoft's new Web browser did not pose a threat to competition in the lucrative new market for Internet search.

headline: Microsoft and Google Grapple for Supremacy
abstract: The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.

headline: Microsoft to Put More Money Into MSN
abstract: Microsoft will increase investments in its online businesses as it escalates a battle with Google.

headline: Microsoft and Google Set to Wage Arms Race
abstract: The rivalry between the companies is growing more combative as the outcome is likely to shape the future of competition in computing and the way people use information technology.

headline: China Begins Effort to Curb Piracy of Computer Software
abstract: With piracy rampant in China, Microsoft and other software companies are seeking the good will of the country's top leaders.

headline: Timing the Electronics Market for the Best Deal on a New PC
abstract: Sometimes the slow but relentless drop in electronics price turns into a torrent. That's happening now in personal computers.

headline: New Microsoft Browser Raises Google's Hackles
abstract: Google says Microsoft is unfairly grabbing Web traffic by making its MSN search engine the default in its browser.

headline: Cadillac Models to Join the Action in Xbox 360 Game
abstract: Cadillac is one of the first companies to advertise on Xbox Live. Microsoft said it expects between 10 and 20 such deals over the next year.

headline: May's Treo Leapfrogs Past January's
abstract: Good things come to those who wait. The Treo 700P smartphone is the Windows Treo without the Windows, and it's almost everything you'd wish it to be.

headline: MTV Will Test Its Own Entry in Online Music
abstract: A test version of MTV's Urge, a long-delayed online music service co-developed with Microsoft, will be introduced Monday.

headline: At an Industry Media Lab, Close Views of Multitasking
abstract: In a sleek Los Angeles lab, advertisers and media companies are researching Americans' propensity for "concurrent media usage."

headline: At a Gamers' Show, Gates Makes His Pitch as a Player
abstract: Bill Gates described a future in which gamers using the Xbox 360 console can connect to others on a PC or a cellphone.

headline: At E3 Video Game Convention, New Generation Bows
abstract: At this year's E3 convention, game makers hope to show that they have realistic plans to capitalize on next-generation consoles.

headline: Yahoo Is Unleashing a New Way to Turn Ad Clicks Into Ka-Ching
abstract: In hopes of catching up to Google's ad revenue, Yahoo will soon release a simpler, more stable and more nuanced search-advertising system.

headline: Video Games Struggle to Find the Next Level
abstract: At a time when sales of games tied to movies have slowed, publishers are trying to develop more game concepts from scratch.

headline: A Big Question Unanswered by a Tiny PC
abstract: The Ultra Mobile PC aims to bridge the size gulf between a palmtop and a laptop, but winds up inheriting the worst aspects of each.

headline: Yahoo Stake for Microsoft?
abstract: There was a range of reactions to Wednesday’s report in The Wall Street Journal that Microsoft has held discussions to buy a stake in Internet media company Yahoo to compete against Google.

headline: Microsoft Rebuffed by Korean Regulator
abstract: South Korea’s antitrust watchdog has rejected an objection lodged by Microsoft over a ruling that the company should unbundle its media player and messaging service from Windows software.

headline: Judge Extends Oversight of Microsoft
abstract: A federal judge approved a two-year extension of court supervision for Microsoft yesterday, in an effort to ensure that the company meets the terms of its antitrust settlement.

headline: Yahoo Chief: No Sale to Microsoft
abstract: Terry Semel, the chief executive of Web powerhouse Yahoo, on Thursday gave his side of the story following a report earlier this month that Microsoft has considered taking a stake in his company.

headline: Microsoft’s Sinking UMPC Ship
abstract: If so many people at Microsoft saw the UMPC disaster coming, how does something so misguided like the UMPC get past the drawing board?

headline: Microsoft Settles California Antitrust Suit
abstract: Microsoft will pay $70 million to thousands of California government agencies in the latest legal settlement spurred by price-gouging allegations against the world’s largest computer software maker.

headline: Can Microsoft Fight Threats With Deals?
abstract: Microsoft is the world’s dominant force in computing, but the software giant is also facing some significant threats to its reign. One of those is the Internet. The New York Times writes on Wednesday that Microsoft and Google, the powerhouse of Internet search tools, appear to be “on a collision course, as the realms of desktop computing and Internet services and software overlap more and more.”

headline: Justice Department Extends Microsoft’s Antitrust Oversight
abstract: Citing Microsoft‘s lapses under part of a landmark antitrust settlement, the Justice Department and the software giant agreed to extend by two years the agency’s oversight of some of the company’s business practices.

headline: Microsoft Pressed to Make Mammoth Buyback
abstract: Microsoft is getting all kinds of advice these days on what it should do with its giant piles of cash. Bloomberg News reports that many investors think the company should use all or part of its $34.8 billion to buy back some of its own shares. Some argue that the world’s largest software maker should go even further and leverage a buyback to the tune of $60 billion. (That is roughly one-quarter of its market capitalization.)

headline: Microsoft Likes Its Acquisitions Fresh
abstract: Microsoft seems to be stepping up its acquisition activity, though its succession of bite-size deals has been easy to overlook. Blogger Paul Kedrosky lists 22 recent purchases, mostly of small companies. He points to an entry in a blog by Don Dodge, a Microsoft employee, who notes that a third of Microsoft’s latest acquisitions were early-stage companies that never even took venture capital financing.

headline: Microsoft Spinoff Bags $10 Million
abstract: Inrix, the first of what is expected to be a reliable flow of technology spinoffs from Microsoft, raised $10 million in a second round of venture capital led by Boston’s Bain Capital Ventures.

headline: Sizing Up Paper in Microsoft Word
abstract: I changed my printer's settings in Windows to print on a paper of a certain size, but Microsoft Word refuses to acknowledge the change when I print.

headline: Microsoft and Google Set to Wage Arms Race
abstract: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, described Google in an interview late last year as a worthy adversary, a company to test Microsoft’s mettle. “This is hypercompetition, make no mistake,” Mr. Gates observed.

headline: Microsoft Makes Massive Run at Ad Market
abstract: Microsoft agreed to buy Massive, a closely held seller of video-game advertisements, to gain early entry into a new ad market. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Symantec Takes Microsoft to Court Over Trade Secrets
abstract: Symantec sued a software rival, Microsoft, on Thursday, accusing it of misappropriating trade secrets to develop its own competing features and products, including the next version of Windows.

headline: Yahoo and eBay Form Advertising Alliance
abstract: Yahoo and the Web auctioneer eBay announced a partnership designed to improve their position against Microsoft and the Web search leader Google, underscoring recent speculation the two companies could eventually merge.

headline: Mr. Ballmer Goes to Manhattan
abstract: Schmoozing Wall Street is part of the job for most titans of industry. Not Steve Ballmer. The Microsoft chief executive prefers to let investors come to him — just once a year, at an event the company hosts at its Redmond, Wash., headquarters.

headline: Spotlight on Small Firms as High-Tech Industry Matures
abstract: Let Wall Street fret about the $2 billion Microsoft is investing in Web services over the next year. Right now the action is closer to the floor of the Silicon Forest, in the shadow of the big evergreens.

headline: Sony to Sell PlayStation 3 for $499
abstract: The price may be too high to compete with Xbox 360.

headline: Google Reaches Agreement to Have Its Software Installed on New Dell Computers
abstract: The arrangement means that Google's search toolbar will appear on the screens of new Dell systems, and that Dell users will be directed to a Web page branded by the two companies.

headline: Televisa to Enter Bidding for the Spanish-Language Broadcaster Univision
abstract: After a whirl of press reports teaming Grupo Televisa up with several private equity firms for a Univision bid, the Mexican media company confirmed on Friday that it planned to bid for the Spanish-language broadcaster along with five private investment firms, including one owned by the chairman of Microsoft, Bill Gates.

headline: SAP Co-Founder Makes Takeover Shortlist
abstract: He is not saying that SAP is in talks to be acquired — in fact, he took pains to say it was not — but it it were, SAP co-founder Hasso Plattner sees only three logical acquirers for the German business-software giant. The three possibilities are IBM, Microsoft and Google, Mr. Plattner said in an interview with German newspaper Financial Times Deutschland, which was published Thursday afternoon on the newspaper’s Web site.

headline: Intel to Offer Its Own Plan for Global Internet Access
abstract: The company plans to announce a design for a sub-$400 educational laptop and a program to train teachers and to extend wireless digital Internet access worldwide.

headline: Verizon Takes Stake in Online Gamer
abstract: First the phone company went after TV, and now it’s after online games. Verizon Communications is investing in new applications that will help its customers fill their broadband pipes.

headline: Shares Rise for First Time This Week as Oil Price Falls
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Back Up Your Phone, Not Just Your Computer
abstract: A new service from Sprint copies a cellphone's contact list to a server to save irritation for both absent-minded phone owners and their friends.

headline: I.B.M. Seeks to Make the Mainframe Modern Technology
abstract: I.B.M. is introducing new software tools, academic programs and developer support to spur demand for its mainframe computers.

headline: More Open Source Deals To Come
abstract: The business models associating with open source software – code that is open to developers and freely distributed – are rapidly evolving, but still nascent. Recent events show one thing clearly: there is money to be made in open source. Not content to rest on their laurels while smaller open source players garner market share and revenue, both Oracle and Red Hat recently struck deals that have thus far proven to be wise.

headline: Buyers Don't Let High Prices Get in the Way
abstract: KEEP spending. That message came through in several ways this week, in decisions by corporate boards to pursue mergers despite high valuations, in the determination of drivers to burn more gasoline regardless of near record prices, and in the assumption that consumers will gladly pay twice as much for the latest electronic playthings.

headline: Should Yahoo and eBay Merge?
abstract: J.P. Morgan‘s team of Internet analysts has issued a report speculating on a number of potential mergers or partnerships among the largest Web companies — it’s an interesting read brought to our attention by PaidContent.org. Of all the possible pairings, the combination that the report deems “most strategically feasible” is a union between Yahoo and eBay.

headline: How to Surf Safely at Cybercafes: Use Their Computer, but Bring Your Own Desktop From Home
abstract: New flash drives from Lexar will come with software that lets you carry a virtual copy of your home computer in your pocket.

headline: Microsoft Plans to Blend Phones With Computers
abstract: Microsoft needs to convince corporations to buy its software at a time when Web services are becoming increasingly popular.

headline: A Microsoft Safety Package. Grit Your Teeth.
abstract: You might be surprised to find out who just entered the antivirus and anti-spyware market: Microsoft.

headline: Europe Said to Plan to Fine Microsoft $2.5 Million a Day
abstract: Under the plan Microsoft would have to pay up to two million euros for every day it has failed to disclose information about its operating system to competitors.

headline: Windows Live Executive Leaves Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft said Tuesday that Martin Taylor, vice president in charge of marketing Windows Live services, had left the company.

headline: Microsoft Lieutenants Look Ahead, Hoping to Avoid Other Companies' Mistakes
abstract: Finding the company's way in the new era will largely fall to the successors to Bill Gates, who will leave his day-to-day role in two years.

headline: Microsoft to Use Cash for Development, Not Share Buybacks
abstract: Microsoft's chief executive has defended his decision to increase spending next year and has signaled he is unlikely to increase the company's share buyback plan.

headline: Microsoft Sets Sail Against Pirates
abstract: Q. Every time I start up my computer I get a message saying, "This copy of Windows is not genuine." What can I do?

headline: Would You Say That to Somebody's Face? You Can, With Voice and Video Messaging
abstract: The Microsoft LifeCams is one of the first Webcams that bear Microsoft's name.

headline: Changing the Way a File Opens
abstract: Every time I double-click on a picture file, it opens on the Microsoft viewer program. Can I change this behavior?

headline: Video Game Makers Are Battling Sinking Stock Prices
abstract: While air has seeped steadily from the stock market, it has poured from the four major publicly traded game publishers.

headline: Now, Free Ways to Do Desktop Work on the Web
abstract: Programmers have developed word processing, spreadsheet, calendar and other software that you operate in a Web browser.

headline: Hiding in Plain Sight, Google Seeks More Power
abstract: A sprawling new data center in Oregon shows the extraordinary drive to beat Microsoft and Yahoo.

headline: Real-Life Wrist Communicator Also Tells the Time, if You Care
abstract: The Microsoft Abacus Smart Watch gets news, weather, traffic information, stock quotes and more.

headline: Google Takes Aim at Excel
abstract: Google's Web-based spreadsheet program will make it easy to edit and share lists and data online.

headline: Microsoft Blogger Leaves for Start-Up
abstract: Renowned corporate blogger Robert Scoble, credited with helping to break down a siege mentality at his employer, Microsoft, confirmed Sunday that he is leaving to join a Silicon Valley video blogging start-up.

headline: Adobe on the Fence About Microsoft Suit
abstract: Adobe Systems “has made no determination” to take legal action against Microsoft, after Microsoft said it would offer a free download to let users create PDF files in the next version of Office.

headline: Windows Live Executive Leaves Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft said Martin Taylor, a vice president appointed in March to revamp marketing for the MSN Web sites and Windows Live services, has left the company.

headline: More Chatter About Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
abstract: The mere suggestion of a union between Microsoft and Yahoo — a potential combination that has been reported upon, praised, derided, refuted and generally tossed around for months — was enough to lift Yahoo’s shares as much as 3 percent on Friday. The speculation resurfaced because of a research note from a Merrill Lynch analyst that said a “possible acquisition of Yahoo! would be a strategic positive” for Microsoft. Specifically, such a deal would help advance Microsoft’s strategy on the Web, an area in which the software behemoth is something of an underdog.

headline: Microsoft to Use Cash for Development, Not Share Buybacks
abstract: Microsoft‘s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, has defended his decision to increase spending next year and has signaled he is unlikely to increase the company’s share buyback plan.

headline: Europe Said to Plan to Fine Microsoft $2.5 Million a Day
abstract: European Commission authorities plan to recommend that Microsoft pay up to two million euros ($2.5 million) for every day it has failed to disclose information about its operating system to competitors, The International Herald Tribune reported.

headline: Gates to Cede Software Reins
abstract: The move, analysts said, points to the changes sweeping the software industry.

headline: Gates to Cede Software Reins in Era Change
abstract: Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates said Thursday that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years.

headline: Inquiry Into Stock Option Pricing Casts a Wide Net
abstract: With the revelation Friday that Microsoft routinely priced workers’ stock options at the low for the month through much of the 1990’s, investors now have a new worry: If one of the nation’s biggest companies helped employees get a head start on profits, did other large firms follow suit?

headline: News Corp. May Auction MySpace Search Business
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation could auction off the MySpace search business to one of the larger search providers like Google, Yahoo or Microsoft‘s MSN, a senior News Corp. executive said Tuesday.

headline: Ignition Adds $80 Million to Third Fund
abstract: Ignition Partners, the Seattle-area venture capital firm run by wireless industry notables and Microsoft alumni, has expanded its $300 million third fund with an additional $80 million earmarked for helping its start-ups grow up fast through acquisitions.

headline: For New Windows, New Requirements
abstract: It might be a good idea to keep Windows Vista, the upcoming new version of Windows, in mind when buying a new computer.

headline: As Tech Giants Hunt for Startups, Oracle Pounces
abstract: Oracle announced yet another acquisition on Thursday. This time the target is Demantra, an Israeli startup that makes product-management software. Financial terms were not disclosed, but an Israel-based newsletter, Globes, put the price at $41 million in cash. Oracle has recently agreed to buy SleepyCat, Net4Call and Portal Software, among other companies.

headline: Entrepreneurs Looking to Flip May Flop Instead
abstract: Forget built to last. These days Internet entrepreneurs build companies to sell.

headline: Buffett Will Not Leave Berkshire
abstract: Warren Buffett, the world’s second-richest person, has no interest in stepping down as chairman and chief executive of the insurance and investment company Berkshire Hathaway, Reuters reported.

headline: A $31 Billion Gift Between Friends
abstract: Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates agree that the capitalist system is not capable alone of addressing the root causes of poverty.

headline: European Commission Drastically Raises Fines
abstract: Companies found guilty of anti-competitive practices will face multi-billion euro fines or more than 10 times the current tariffs for abusing their monopoly and taking part in cartels, under new guidelines adopted by the European commission yesterday.

headline: For JibJab Guys, This Round Is Their Round
abstract: JibJab Media, known for the jerky, animated political satires that probably landed in your e-mail inbox a few years back, has secured its first round of venture financing from Polaris Venture Partners, PaidContent.org reported Friday.

headline: Apple Tells of Problems on Options
abstract: Apple Computer and its chief executive are likely to come under heavy scrutiny following the company’s announcement yesterday that it had uncovered irregularities related to stock options awarded between 1997 and 2001. The move raises questions about whether a grant made to chief executive Steven P. Jobs, one of the largest ever, was properly disclosed.

headline: IDG Beats Retreat from European Venture Investing
abstract: IDG Ventures Europe has broken off from its former parent company and renamed itself Acacia Capital Partners, PE Week Wire reported on Monday. The move represents a retreat from the Continent for International Data Group, the Massachusetts-based publisher of technology magazines that started the venture-capital outfit in 2000 and committed $100 million to it.

headline: Motorola's Q: Lovely Phone; Ugly Software
abstract: The Q is an eye-catching, extremely thin slab but getting anything done on it requires more steps than the Empire State Building.

headline: Google Is Testing Ads for Video Service
abstract: Google said Thursday that it had started testing advertisements on its video site, matching a capability long offered by other major Internet sites.

headline: Internet Companies Divided on Plan to Fight Pornography
abstract: Some companies presented a less than united front addressing proposals on the issue being drafted in Congress.

headline: Not Exactly Breaking Even in a Format War
abstract: Toshiba loses money on every high-def DVD player that it sells. What gives?

headline: Apple Tells of Problems on Options
abstract: Apple Computer said Thursday that it had uncovered irregularities related to stock options awarded between 1997 and 2001.

headline: Days Later, Televisa Bid Turns Up
abstract: Shares of Univision crept higher on Friday after Grupo Televisa and its fellow bidders — or what remains of them — submitted an offer for the Spanish-language broadcasting company. The takeover bid may have been tardy, missing Univision’s supposedly final deadline of Tuesday by a long shot, but it was reportedly greater than the one previously lodged (pre-deadline) by a rival consortium including media entrepreneur Haim Saban. That earlier bid was said to value Univision at $11 billion.

headline: A Handy Tip From a Reader on Flash Drives
abstract: It's mind-blowing: you can run an entire operating system off of your flash drive.

headline: Can Murdoch Find Money in MySpace?
abstract: It may be a huge hit with the youngsters, but social-networking phenomenon MySpace “is so irrelevant to the financial performance” of owner News Corporation that “it doesn’t even merit describing,” Henry Blodget wrote Thursday in his Internet Outsider blog. MySpace’s financial insignificance leaves Mr. Blodget wondering why the media giant spent $580 million to acquire MySpace’s parent, Intermix Media, six months ago.

headline: Did Overstock Write a Script for Hedge-Fund Testifier?
abstract: Wednesday’s testimony by Demetrios Anifantis, one of the speakers at the Senate Judiciary Committee’s controversial hearings on hedge funds, is creating some controversy of its own.

headline: A Flash Drive That Holds Your Computer
abstract: Lexar PowerToGo software is designed to turn a flash drive into a portable Windows XP ecosystem.

headline: Inquiry Into Stock Option Pricing Casts a Wide Net
abstract: In the latest scandal, companies handed out options in a way that undermined the idea of options as a pay-for-performance tool.

headline: Polarized Responses to Bill Gates
abstract: Readers' reactions to Bill Gates were so polarized that I found it hard to believe we live in the same society, let alone the same planet.

headline: Buffett Gift Brings New Challenges for Gates Foundation
abstract: Warren Buffett’s commitment to give the bulk of his $44 billion fortune to Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and four other philanthropies is “the largest in philanthropic history, a record previously held by Bill and Melinda Gates, who have given away more than $29 billion,” according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy.

headline: PC's That Are a Lot Smaller Than a Breadbox
abstract: These PC's are measured in ounces, not pounds, and considerable thumb power may be required.

abstract: The $6 billion investment underlies the country's growing importance as a market for technology products and a source of high-technology workers.

abstract: The move shifts away from the company’s usual strategy of encouraging others to create industry-specific products using its operating system.

headline: Microsoft Confirms That It Is Developing a Competitor to the iPod
abstract: Part of the project, code-named Zune and set to go on sale this year, is a service that will compete with Apple’s iTunes.

headline: In Microsoft Plan for Future, All Roads Lead to Internet
abstract: The company detailed how it was spending heavily on building Internet services into its products, but that any payoff from the effort would not come for a few years.

abstract: The company is in the midst of product transition as sales of Xbox video game consoles are increasing rapidly, while new versions of Windows and Office are still a year off.

abstract: The European Commission fined Microsoft $357 million for failing to comply with a 2004 antitrust order.

headline: Microsoft Is Graying but Still Spry
abstract: Microsoft is looking distinctly middle aged these days — wealthier than it used to be, but slower, too.

abstract: The European Commission is expected to fine Microsoft hundreds of millions of euros for failing to provide information to its competitors.

abstract: Microsoft's interest in making its own hand-held music and video player indicates that its old way of doing things is not working in its battle against Apple Computer's iPod.

headline: Microsoft Is Looking for More Elbow Room
abstract: A crowded campus and competition have forced the world's largest software company to spend $1 billion over the next three years to expand.

abstract: Antitrust regulators in the E.U. gave unanimous support to a plan to again fine Microsoft for failing to comply with a 2004 ruling against it.

abstract: By Bloomberg News.

abstract: Microsoft says 300 engineers have been working to come up with the documentation for its server software that the European Commission has sought.

abstract: In the research field known as artificial intelligence, reality is finally catching up to the science-fiction hype.

headline: Surge in Violence Abroad Overwhelms Markets
abstract: Terrorism in India and escalating violence in the Middle East were collectively too much for stock investors as the Dow Jones plunged and energy prices soared.

abstract: <em style=

headline: At AOL, a Plan for a Clean Break
abstract: AOL's chief executive plans to turn away from Internet access and focus AOL on building its free Web-based services.

abstract: Q. Does the TiVo recorder work with high-definition television?

headline: A Search Engine That's Becoming an Inventor
abstract: Google is a solid member of the Fortune 500 with $9 billion in cash, but it is stubbornly sticking to its do-it-yourself approach to technology.

abstract: AT&T's new television service, U-verse, crams video, data and, soon, phone calls down one high-speed broadband line.

abstract: Europe’s antitrust regulators voted unanimously Monday to support fining Microsoft, the world’s largest software company, for flouting a 2004 ruling.

abstract: Software giant Microsoft was instructed to hand over information to rivals when the European Commission said it was abusing its dominant position in March 2004.

abstract: Microsoft announced a $40 billion share buyback program and as the company’s quarterly profit fell by 24 percent on higher costs and legal expenses.

headline: Nortel and Microsoft Form Telecom Alliance
abstract: After the Ericsson–Marconi  and Alcatel–Lucent mergers and the Nokia–Siemens tie-up, it seemed as if poor Nortel Networks would end up partnerless as rivals telecommunications equipment makers bulked up. But on Tuesday, Nortel revealed that it has found a powerful partner indeed, announcing that it agreed to a four-year partnership with Microsoft to develop sotware for Internet calling, instant messaging and voice and video conferencing.

abstract: Microsoft on Wednesday said it would purchase health-care software technology called Azyxxi, which was developed by a group of three physicians to gather patient information from numerous sources and make it instantly available to caregivers.

abstract: Microsoft‘s recently announced alliance with Nortel is aimed at joining its software with Nortel’s phone technology to create new kinds of telecommunications systems for businesses, linking computers and telephones to integrate voice, instant messaging, email and videoconferencing.

abstract: Neelie Kroes, competition commissioner for the European Union, apparently earned her nickname because she’s tough in the same vein as the “Iron Lady” of Britain, Margaret Thatcher.

abstract: Voyager Capital‘s Tony Audino has resigned from the Seattle venture capital firm that he co-founded in 1997 to devote more time to a new Internet company called OneDegree, a successor to the non-profit Microsoft Alumni Network.

abstract: I found these notes from a panel that featured ex-Apple and ex-Microsoft software designers, discussing how Mac OS X and Vista came into existence.

abstract: A wiki software start-up is releasing two products into open source to help get more developers familiar with its commercial products.

abstract: What do the elite few who are invited to attend Allen & Company‘s Sun Valley conference discuss over their morning coffee? The people who are not there, of course.

abstract: Oil prices dropped, Coca-Cola’s profit surpassed estimates and United Technologies raised its full-year earnings forecast.

headline: Judge Looks Into Modifying Terms of 2 Phone Mergers
abstract: A federal district judge in Washington is considering the imposition of major modifications to the two largest telephone mergers in history.

headline: Interactive Netscape Site Gets Some Sour Responses
abstract: When AOL tried to update Netscape.com last month, it received some surprisingly angry feedback.

headline: Limelight Gets $130 Million, Mostly From Goldman

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY Fed watchers will be out in force when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, delivers his semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy and the state of the economy. In the first day of what is known as the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Mr. Bernanke will address the Senate Banking Committee; the next day he will testify to the House Financial Services Committee. With Mr. Bernanke still in his rookie year, many on Wall Street can be expected to be parsing his speech for signs of what kind of player he might turn out to be. (Wednesday and Thursday.).

headline: NBC Considers Its Next Web Deal
abstract: There may be another development in Big Media’s continuing quest to get in on the social-networking craze. Paid Content on Friday became the latest to report that NBC Universal has all but sealed a deal to buy social-networking Web site Tribe.net. It speculated that the sale price would be “probably less than $50 million.”

headline: Taking the Taxi to Higher Heights
abstract: For years, questions about the size of an air taxi market have been largely theoretical. But that will change this year.

headline: Intel Presents New Line of Processors
abstract: The Intel Corporation hopes to reclaim market share that it has lost over the last three years to a smaller rival, Advanced Micro Devices.

headline: Like Having a Secretary in Your PC
abstract: If you’re among the thousands who have abandoned dictation software in the past, it’s now ready for prime time.

headline: Home, Sweet (Second) Home
abstract: ALONG with the pictures and souvenirs, many vacationers return home with a lingering thought: Wouldn’t it be great to own a place there?.

headline: I.B.M. Reports Strong Profit, but Services Unit Struggles
abstract: In after-hours trading, I.B.M.’s stock rose $1.06 a share, after closing the regular session at $75.26 a share, up 56 cents.

headline: News Online Seems to Have Long Shelf Life
abstract: A new research paper seeks to answer a riddle for publishers, editors and even readers: When does new news become old news?

headline: Cameras and TV’s Lead Sales Gains at Sony
abstract: Analysts called the return to profit an early sign of success for Sir Howard Stringer, who took Sony’s helm a year ago.

headline: Quick Approval of Phone Deals Uncertain
abstract: A federal district judge is reviewing the antitrust settlements that permitted the two largest telephone acquisitions in American history.

headline: Microsoft Increases Buyback of Shares
abstract: Microsoft nearly doubled its stock buyback to $36 billion after an initial invitation to sell failed to generate enough interest.

headline: Microsoft to Provide and Sell Ads on Facebook, the Web Site
abstract: Microsoft will be the exclusive seller and provider of banner advertising for Facebook, a Web site aimed at college students.

headline: An Apple-Google Friendship, and a Common Enemy
abstract: The alliance between Google and Apple may make the prospect of outdueling Microsoft’s empire better than ever.

headline: Microsoft Has a Starter Kit for Aspiring Game Designers
abstract: Microsoft is expected to announce the fall release of tools that will let aspiring game designers write games on a PC, test them on an Xbox 360, then sell or share them on Xbox Live.

headline: Google to Offer Services for Businesses
abstract: Taking aim at Microsoft, Google plans to offer a package of software for business users.

headline: This Is Only a Drill: In California, Testing Technology in a Disaster Response
abstract: In San Diego, technology companies, nongovernmental agencies and the Pentagon held a five-day test of a new set of digital tools for responding to disaster.

headline: Universal Music Group and an Online Site Plan a Joint Venture to Challenge iTunes
abstract: A new service, supported by advertisements, will let consumers download a huge catalog of songs from the world’s largest record company for free.

headline: Windows Editions in South Korea
abstract: Microsoft said it would release two new versions of Windows XP Home Edition and Windows XP Professional Edition in South Korea today to comply with a South Korean antitrust ruling. One version of Windows in Korea will exclude Microsoft Media Player and Windows Messenger, and the other one will carry links to Web pages that will allow consumers to download competing versions of the operating system. In a final ruling in February, the South Korean Fair Trade Commission fined Microsoft 32.5 billion won ($34 million) while ruling that the company breached antitrust laws by bundling its media player and instant messaging services in its operating system. A Seoul court rejected Microsoft’s request to suspend the ruling last month.

headline: U.S. Warns PC Users of Flaw in Windows
abstract: The flaw would make it possible to install malicious programs or to change or delete data.

headline: Weighing a Switch to a Mac
abstract: Retail stores, iPods and new Intel chips are increasing the appeal of making the jump from a PC to a Mac.

headline: Adobe Reaches Far and Wide
abstract: The company’s chief executive spoke about how far-reaching Adobe has become in Americans’ daily lives.

headline: Of Private Equity, Microsoft and Flying Pigs
abstract: Could Microsoft be bought out? A report in The Financial Times recently posited that a deal for the software giant was possibility. A consortium of private equity firms, the paper wrote, could cobble together the $288 billion needed — nearly nine times more than the largest deal ever made.

headline: Microsoft to Provide and Sell Ads on Facebook
abstract: Microsoft failed to sign MySpace to an advertising deal, so the software giant went out and landed Facebook, the second-largest social networking site.

headline: E.U. Examines New Microsoft Documents
abstract: Microsoft has given the European Union more documents in response to a 2004 antitrust order, but regulators said they do not know yet whether the company will avoid additional fines.

headline: Microsoft Plans Rapid-Fire Security Buys
abstract: Microsoft plans to focus on rapid acquisitions to quickly build its security capabilities, the company said this week.

headline: Getting Hung Up on the Apple-Microsoft War
abstract: Two new operating systems from Apple and Windows are inspiring fierce arguments about which is better. But as far as I can tell, there is no real war.

headline: Microsoft Raises Share Buyback Plan to $36.2 Billion
abstract: Microsoft said Friday it had increased its share buyback plan by about $16.2 billion, increasing its total repurchase authorization to $36.2 billion through June 30, 2011.

headline: Software Glitch May Have Wiped Out Enron E-mails
abstract: Some of the emails produced for use in civil lawsuits in the Enron case may have been erased due to a bug in the Microsoft software used by the company handling discovery documents.

headline: Weekend Reading: Anti-Google Bloc As 19th Century Europe
abstract: Google, according to The Economist, is much like Napoleonic France. Google’s rivals – Yahoo, eBay, and Microsoft – are much like France’s enemies, Russia, Prussia and Austria. They should ally against their enemy to create a “balance of power.”

headline: Bill Gates Moves into Newspapers — Sort of
abstract: When MediaNews sought to buy four newspapers from McClatchy, it found help from an unlikely source: Microsoft‘s Bill Gates.

headline: I.B.M. to Buy Content Software Maker for $1.6 Billion
abstract: The acquisition of FileNet is a move by I.B.M. to strengthen its position in the market for content management software.

abstract: Apple Computer said yesterday that the chief executive of Google, Eric Schmidt, was joining its board, linking two of Silicon Valley’s most iconic – and maverick – companies.

Loudeye, based in Seattle, runs music services for more than 60 partners, ranging from the Microsoft MSN Web portal to Oxfam, the aid organization. “Being able to combine Loudeye services with Nokia terminals provides a good base for innovative and useful consumer services,’’ said Ilkka Raiskinen, senior vice president for multimedia experiences at Nokia, based in Espoo, Finland.

headline: Buyout Firms Should Think Small, Merrill Analysts Say
abstract: With many people wondering which giant companies will be the next targets of private equity takeovers — the notion of a hypothetical Microsoft buyout has prompted much debate — analysts at Merrill Lynch are saying that small-cap companies are looking more attractive on that front.

headline: Apple Changes Its Tunes on Viruses
abstract: For years, Apple avoided advertising the fact that Mac OS X hasn't come under a single virus attack "in the wild." But now Apple has changed its tune.

headline: Apple Settles Patent Dispute With a Rival
abstract: Apple Computer settled a legal dispute with Creative Technology over its patented music player, agreeing to pay a one-time $100 million licensing fee to use the technology.

headline: European Panel Investigates DVD-Standards Rivalry
abstract: European investigators want to know if Hollywood studios have been pressured by manufacturers of next-generation DVD’s to favor one standard over another.

headline: Mid-Life Crisis: As Yahoo and eBay Mature, Employees Go for Start-Ups
abstract: While once workers left other companies to join Yahoo and eBay, many employees are now leaving those firms to work at the newest wave of Web start-ups.

abstract: I used to believe that I.T. people didn't like Macs because they are less trouble-prone and would make their jobs obsolete. Today, however, I'm convinced that it's a myth.

headline: Stealth Tech Start-Up Gets First Taste of Funding
abstract: Coming out of stealth mode, tech start-up iTaggit raised $1.04 million from some big-name backers in its Series A offering.

abstract: Sandisk’s new Sansa e200 MP3 players do more than play music. They can capture it.

abstract: Shares in FileNet were down slightly on Friday morning, but still trading above the $35 that IBM offered for the company on Thursday, leading to continued speculation that a bidding war might ensue.

headline: Google Deal Will Give News Corp. Huge Payoff
abstract: It appears that News Corporation‘s bet on MySpace is paying off — and Google will be footing the bill.

abstract: Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com and other News Corporation sites.

abstract: AOL removed a list of the Web search inquiries of 658,000 unnamed users from a public Web site, after bloggers complained that the information compromised the users’ privacy.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Technology Editor Kevin McKenna
abstract: Kevin McKenna, technology editor at The Times, answered reader questions about the newspaper's coverage of computers and technology.

headline: Apple Completes Transition to Intel Chips
abstract: Analysts agreed that Apple’s shift to Intel, in a quest to improve upon the performance of the Power PC chips developed by I.B.M. and Motorola, had been a success.

headline: Sybase Outgrows the Valley
abstract: John Chen, the chief executive of Sybase, has managed to stay under the radar and keep his company profitable.

headline: Alcatel May Buy Nortel Unit, Reports Say
abstract: Citing a telecom newsletter and a Paris-based analyst, Reuters reported Tuesday that Alcatel is in talks with Nortel Networks, its Canadian rival, to acquire its high-speed mobile arm. Such a deal would be worth 1.51 billion euro ($1.91 billion), Reuters said.

headline: The Exuberant Corporate Yachtsmen
abstract: It must be August. A brief mention of the giant yacht belonging to Legg Mason fund manager Bill Miller in Saturday’s issue of Barron’s has launched a flotilla of discussions about certain moguls’ and money managers’ love affairs with enormous sea-faring status symbols.

headline: Despite Loss, Electronic Arts Predicts Upturn
abstract: Electronic Arts  suggested that the industry’s cyclical downturn was showing signs of turning around.

headline: Blogger Lists Possible YouTube Buyers; Other Blogger Makes Fun
abstract: YouTube is worth an estimated $1 billion, and everybody’s wondering what’s next for the online-video juggernaut. One option, made more appealing by the anemic market for technology IPOs, is to seek an acquirer. ZDNet blogger Russell Shaw on Monday chose what he said are the most likely buyers.

headline: Brand-Name Stock Picks

headline: Talk Turns to Chances of Recession

abstract: Q. Is there a way to find out where e-mail messages actually came from?

abstract: Microsoft increased its dividend by 11 percent as the company seeks to distribute more of the $34 billion that it has on hand.

abstract: Microsoft said its Zune music player will include wireless technology that will allow owners to share songs and playlists easily.

abstract: Microsoft rushed what may be the final test version of its Windows Vista operating system to more than a million testers, trying to meet deadlines for its long-delayed release.

headline: Deal to Put Live Concerts on Internet Is Dissolved
abstract: AOL and a group of entertainment entrepreneurs have dissolved their venture to produce and distribute live concerts on the Internet and elsewhere.

abstract: A device due out next year will wirelessly stream video and music from a Macintosh computer to a television.

abstract: Apple’s chief executive touched off speculation last week about how far Apple will go as it takes its next big step into digital video.

abstract: Some people like to spend their time speculating about the courtship habits of Hollywood stars like Jennifer Aniston and Vince Vaughn.

abstract: The competition regulator for the European Union clashed with Microsoft again on Tuesday, this time over security upgrades in the company’s new Windows Vista operating system.

abstract: Preston Gates & Ellis, the Seattle-based law firm that counts Microsoft and T-Mobile as its anchor clients, is in talks with Kirkpatrick & Lockhart Nicholson Graham of Pittsburgh about a possible merger.

abstract: The social-networking site Facebook is in serious talks to sell itself to Yahoo for an amount that could approach $1 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported.

abstract: Is it true that hard drives can get tired or aged?

headline: Only Billionaires Welcome on Forbes’s ‘Richest’ List

abstract: AT&T said Tuesday it has agreed to acquire USinternetworking, a privately held provider of specialized software for business customers, for about $300 million in cash and assumed debt.

headline: Software Start-Up SoonR Gets $6 Million
abstract: Bucking conventional wisdom that more computing applications will migrate from personal computers to cell phones, a mobile startup, SoonR raised $6 million from Clearstone Venture Partners and Intel Capital in a bid to maintain the relevancy of PCs.

headline: Of Sporting News, Yoga and Magazine Karma
abstract: Two separate magazine deals announced Tuesday have something in common. Or, rather, someone.

headline: Napster Ponders Sale or Alliance
abstract: Napster said that it had hired UBS Investment Bank to assist in the possible sale of the company.

headline: New Product by Nintendo for Holidays
abstract: Nintendo plans to release its new Wii video game console in the Americas in November.

headline: Venture Investing as a Strategy, Not to Make Money
abstract: Technology giants are increasingly deciding that venture investing is not for them and not just because of the financial risk involved.

headline: More Deal Speculation About Facebook, YouTube
abstract: After a few quiet weeks, speculation about the fate of two popular Web sites is getting louder. Thursday brought two separate reports on Facebook and YouTube, suggesting once again that these Internet businesses were considering a sale.

headline: Don’t Keep All Your Data in One Stash
abstract: What happens to those beloved family photos or your extensive music collection if something should happen to your PC and your backup? Seagate is trying to solve the off-premises backup problem.

headline: William B. Ziff Jr., 76, Builder of Magazine Empire, Dies
abstract: William B. Ziff Jr. made publications like Car and Driver and PC Magazine must reading among hobbyists and computer enthusiasts.

headline: When Apple Hit Bottom
abstract: As you probably know, Apple's been in the news quite a bit lately. (That's "lately," as in, "pretty much every other month for the last five years.")

headline: New Service From Amazon Offers Downloadable Films
abstract: The move is the first major effort by Amazon to sell downloadable entertainment to compete with an array of online video retailers.

headline: H.P. Spy Case Spotlights a Technology News Site
abstract: CNet’s News.com site often breaks major technology stories and has been described as the home page for Silicon Valley.

headline: New Name and Strategy for Chip Division at Philips
abstract: The semiconductor unit of Philips Electronics is adopting a new name, NXP, and a new strategy to supply chips to the advanced electronics products market.

headline: Many Theories on Income Inequality, but One Answer Lies in Just a Few Places
abstract: According to two researchers, the increase in income inequality  resulted from large income changes in areas heavily involved in the information technology boom.

headline: Safely Removing Reluctant Hardware
abstract: Why is it that my Windows computer sometimes will not let me unplug my U.S.B. flash drive?

headline: Choosing a Backup Buddy
abstract: Which is better for backing up the computer on the road — a flash-memory drive or a portable hard drive?

headline: Removing Antivirus Software
abstract: How do I fully remove an antivirus program from my computer?

headline: Tired of Trolls, a Feisty Chief Fights Back
abstract: Believing that patent trolls were hurting small businesses, one chief executive decided that enough was enough.

headline: Philanthropy Google’s Way: Not the Usual
abstract: Unlike most charities, Google’s new philanthropy will be for-profit, a move that could greatly increase its range and flexibility.

headline: Hoping to Be a Model, I.B.M. Will Put Its Patent Filings Online
abstract: I.B.M., the nation’s largest patent holder, will publish its patent filings on the Web for public review as part of a new policy.

headline: Intel to Cut Work Force by 10,500
abstract: The two-year effort will reduce its work force by 10 percent and cut $5 billion in costs. Analysts see the measures as essential to compete against Advanced Micro Devices.

headline: BlackBerry Adds Diversions, Counting on Sales
abstract: Phone carriers hope the new BlackBerry Pearl will finally persuade consumers to send data on their cellphones.

headline: Yahoo Woos a Social Networking Site
abstract: Yahoo has offered about $900 million to woo Mark Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of the popular social networking site Facebook.com.

headline: Online Game, Made in U.S., Seizes the Globe
abstract: World of Warcraft, with almost seven million paying subscribers, has become the first truly global video-game hit since Pac-Man in the early 80’s.

headline: Microsoft Looks Within to Design and Test Chips
abstract: Microsoft is exploring hardware design now in part because of a new set of tools that will make it possible to test ideas quickly.

headline: Microsoft Profit and Revenue Up 11% on Strength of Games and Servers
abstract: Earnings slightly surpassed expectations, as the company’s Xbox game business and database software continued to drive growth.

headline: Microsoft Makes Changes in Windows Vista to Suit Foreign Regulators
abstract: Microsoft said its Windows Vista operating system had been altered to satisfy regulatory concerns and would be introduced simultaneously worldwide.

headline: En Garde! Fight Foes Using a Controller Like a Sword
abstract: With its new Wii console, Nintendo is eschewing speed and graphics quality in favor of an inventive new controller that senses a user’s motions.

headline: Cultivating Server Farms
abstract: The good times are back for data center operators. Over the next 10 years, more than half expect to expand, according to a 2006 survey.

headline: Sony Readies Its PlayStation 3 for Battle
abstract: Sony said 21 games would be available for the PlayStation 3 console when it goes on sale next month.

headline: Battleground for Consoles Moves Online
abstract: With the arrival of its PlayStation 3 nearing, Sony is aiming at its rival's sweet spot: Internet-based gaming.

headline: Is Windows Near End of Its Run?
abstract: Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, answered questions about the new Windows Vista operating system, his job and the future of software.

headline: A Challenge for Exterminators
abstract: The five-year redesign of Microsoft Windows and Office has come down to a final scramble to get the programs to users by the end of the year.

headline: Their Crime: Playing iTunes on Devices Not Named iPod
abstract: A protest in Paris reflects a growing concern that laws intended to prevent digital piracy place unacceptable limits on the use of legally purchased songs and videos.

headline: Feeling Free to Take Shots at an Old Bully
abstract: Computer security firms are complaining that a feature in Microsoft’s new operating system would cripple their industry’s innovation.

headline: Security Software Makers Upset Over Windows Vista
abstract: The companies say the new version of Windows hinders them and steers users to Microsoft’s security offerings.

headline: Want to Help Treat AIDS in Africa? Buy a Cellphone
abstract: A new line of products from companies like Gap, Armani Exchange and Motorola aims to raise money to help fight AIDS in Africa. The campaign was created by the musician Bono and Bobby Shriver, a California politician.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Software Maker Colloquis
abstract: Microsoft is buying Colloquis, a maker of natural language-processing technology used to provide automated customer assistance. The software maker said it will use Colloquis’ technology to offer a managed service called Windows Live Service Agents.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Microsoft-AT&T Patent Suit
abstract: The Supreme Court said Friday it would intervene in a patent dispute between Microsoft and AT&T over Windows programs distributed overseas.

headline: Wooed by Yahoo, Facebook Made Vow to Microsoft
abstract: Amid bubbly speculation about who might buy Facebook and what the price would be, The New York Post reports that Facebook previously agreed to pay Microsoft a breakup fee in the event it is acquired by a Microsoft competitor.

headline: Microsoft Tries and Fails in Pitchfork Deal, Report Says
abstract: In a bid to out-cool Apple and its ubiquitous iPod, Microsoft approached the ultra-snarky Pitchfork blog about supplying content to its Zune digital music player – but was rebuffed by the music hipster haven, The New York Post reported.

headline: Merrill Calls Yahoo a Buy (in More Ways Than One)
abstract: A Merrill Lynch analyst on Monday raised his rating on Yahoo‘s stock to “buy” from “neutral” and suggested that popular Web portal could make an attractive acquisition target for Microsoft.

headline: Withering Monopolies
abstract: Remember the Wintel monopoly? It’s fading away.

headline: Gates and Ballmer Get Smaller Bonuses
abstract: Microsoft‘s chairman Bill Gates and its chief executive, Steve Ballmer, may be valued in the billions of dollars, but they did not quite crack the $1 million mark in annual salary and bonuses for the last fiscal year.

headline: Investor Pushes DreamWorks to Sell Shares in Offering
abstract: The investment firm owned by Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, said Wednesday that it had exercised an option to force DreamWorks Animation to sell shares in the company to the public in a secondary offering.

headline: Raymond Noorda, 82, Novell Founder, Dies
abstract: Raymond J. Noorda was a co-founder of Novell Inc., a software company that helped pioneer computer networking.

headline: Who (If Anyone) Should Buy Yahoo?
abstract: When high-profile deals go down — as when the Internet search giant Google announced its YouTube acquisition — everybody starts looking for the next one. So speculation over who might buy Yahoo, one of the best-known brands on the Web, is in heavy rotation in the news and, much moreso, in blogland.

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry on Hedge Fund Draws Scrutiny
abstract: Two Senate committees are investigating how diligently the S.E.C. pursued its inquiry of possible insider trading by Pequot Capital Management.

headline: Is This Bud for Lampert?
abstract: After the notion of a hypothetical Microsoft buyout by private equity firms has been floated, it would seem no target is too big for industry speculation. So a report Tuesday in The Times of London that hedge fund manager Edward Lampert is preparing a $44 billion bid for Anheuser-Busch, the world’s largest brewer, was taken with more than a grain of salt.

headline: Yahoo Feels Breath on Its Neck
abstract: As Google whips out its fat wallet to buy the video site YouTube, it is making Yahoo look even more out of step with the fast-changing Internet advertising market.

headline: I.B.M. Division Moves to China
abstract: I.B.M. has moved its global procurement headquarters to southern China to “capitalize on emerging market opportunities.”

headline: Energy Shake-Up Reaches Far, Even to Playboy Stock Pickers
abstract: The recent slide in ethanol-related stocks has stung many investors who placed big bets on alternative energy, including Microsoft‘s Bill Gates and the venture capitalist Thomas Perkins. It has also wreaked havoc with the imaginary portfolio of Amy Sue Cooper.

headline: Shares Surge Amid Hopes for Lower Rates
abstract: The S. & P. index set a five-year high and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed above 11,800 for the first time.

headline: Adding On to the House of Google
abstract: Having pieced together a rapidly multiplying set of products, Google’s leaders have a new concern. Call it Google sprawl.

headline: M.B.A.’s and the Vanishing Bonus
abstract: For some business school students, procrastination can be very expensive.

headline: When Outside the Loop, a Quicker Way to Get In
abstract: Hoovers.com, the business research site, will soon offer its users the ability to mine their contacts to find prospective clients or business partners.

headline: On the Horizon: A Vista Upgrade
abstract: How can I find out if my current computer hardware will be compatible with the upcoming Windows Vista system?

headline: An Old-Economy High
abstract: The Dow record is a victory for the old economy, but investors are cautious about new companies.

headline: Center of Outsourcing in India Won’t Be Answering the Phone
abstract: Bangalore, where dozens of multinational companies have operations, will completely shut down on Wednesday as part of a protest over a border issue.

headline: Apple Says Jobs Knew of Options
abstract: Apple said an internal review found that Steven P. Jobs knew the company was backdating stock options to inflate their value.

headline: Cramer to Make Wish List for Yahoo
abstract: Market pundit Jim Cramer weighed in on the what’s-the-matter-with-Yahoo debate yesterday saying that the company needed to get acquisitive if it wanted to compete with the likes of Google.

headline: Dot-Com Boom Echoed in Deal to Buy YouTube
abstract: A profitless Web site started by three 20-somethings after a late-night dinner party is sold for more than a billion dollars, instantly turning dozens of its employees into paper millionaires. It sounds like a tale from the late 1990’s dot-com bubble, but it happened Monday.

headline: Investor Pushes DreamWorks to Sell Shares in Offering
abstract: The offering is estimated at around $300 million, 40 percent less than the offering DreamWorks canceled last year after it missed its projections on DVD sales.

headline: The YouTube Paradox
abstract: YouTube and its founder Chad Hurley have media executives in a twist. The online video-sharing upstart, which shows more than 100 million video clips a day, has titans wondering: friend or foe?

headline: Tellme and Cingular Plan Broader Directory Service
abstract: The enhanced 411 service will use voice recognition technology to offer some Internet-style searches in addition to telephone directory information.

headline: Google Is Said to Set Sights on YouTube
abstract: Google is said to be in discussions to acquire the popular video-sharing Web site that has yet to turn a profit, for $1.6 billion.

headline: Tattoos to Massages: It’s All About Selling
abstract: A look back at the 96th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Profit Rises 53% at Infosys, a Top Indian Outsourcing Company
abstract: Profit at Infosys surpassed expectations and reflected a strong demand for technology and services from Western customers.

headline: Kidney Dialysis Center Deal With Amgen Blocks Roche
abstract: Amgen reached an agreement that will make it the sole supplier of an anemia drug to a main operator of kidney dialysis centers.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Association of National Advertisers, New York, elected new officers at its 96th annual conference. Stephen G. Sullivan, senior vice president for communications at the Liberty Mutual Group, was elected the chairman for 2006-8. He succeeds James R. Stengel, global marketing officer at the Procter & Gamble Company, who was the 2004-6 chairman. Mr. Sullivan had been the vice chairman of the association for 2004-6. Rebecca Saeger, chief marketing officer at the Charles Schwab Corporation, was elected the vice chairwoman for 2006-8, placing her in line to be chairwoman in 2008-10.

headline: Joining the Party, Eager to Make Friends
abstract: Advertisers hope to use social networking sites to get the attention of tens of millions of young people who increasingly avoid television commercials.

headline: 55 Million Blogs, and Now a Service to Track Them
abstract: The Edelman public relations firm is sponsoring development of Technorati sites to monitor blogs written in French, German, Italian, Korean and Chinese.

headline: New York Bets on High-Tech to Aid Upstate
abstract: A chip factory is part of an ambitious effort to create a thriving high-technology hub in upstate New York.

headline: Clock Ticks, Bonus Ebbs for Recruits
abstract: More companies hoping to attract M.B.A. students are offering bonuses that decline or disappear unless the student accepts the job early.

headline: Microsoft Gives Europe Antitrust Documents
abstract: On Thursday, Microsoft met the latest deadline to provide information on whether it is complying with a 2004 antitrust ruling.

headline: Microsoft-Novell Pact Is Already in Dispute
