abstract: The agreement was seen as an affirmation of the importance of Microsoft's competitor, Linux, and of the need to satisfy corporate customers who want to run both operating systems.

headline: Europe Warns Microsoft Over Compliance
abstract: The European Commission threatened Microsoft with daily fines if it does not allow rivals to make their programs work with Windows.

headline: Microsoft Strikes Deal for Music
abstract: In a rare move, Microsoft agreed to pay a percentage of the sales of its new portable media player to the Universal Music Group.

headline: Microsoft Aims to Improve Its ‘Works Well With Others’ Score
abstract: Microsoft plans to unveil a technology industry alliance to make software from competing companies and partners work better together.

headline: Microsoft Counting on a Twist to Make Zune Shine in Shadow of iPod
abstract: The Zune, released on Monday, is a digital music and video player that can wirelessly exchange content.

headline: Microsoft Xbox to Join the Battle for Video Downloading
abstract: Microsoft said it would offer movies and television shows for download through its Xbox Live online service.

headline: Microsoft Vista Event
abstract: Microsoft plans to observe the release of Windows Vista and Office 2007 to corporate customers on Nov. 30 with an event in New York.

headline: For $150, Third-World Laptop Stirs Big Debate
abstract: The debate is centered on whether cheap laptops are the best way to improve education in the developing world.

headline: A College Education Without Job Prospects
abstract: Most of the 11 million students in India’s 18,000 colleges and universities receive starkly inferior training, heavy on obedience and light on useful job skills.

headline: Google Mapping an Offline Course
abstract: Major Internet sites are showing a growing interest in the advertising business, and traditional ad firms are starting to worry.

headline: Trying Out the Zune: IPod It’s Not
abstract: It can’t touch the iPod’s looks or coolness, but the new Microsoft Zune is certainly more practical.

headline: After 5 Years, Latest Version of Windows Is Set to Ship
abstract: Microsoft announced that it had finished the new version of its Windows operating system, Windows Vista.

headline: 2 Giants in a Deal Over Linux
abstract: Microsoft struck a deal with Novell to ensure that its version of Linux could operate with Windows in corporate data centers.

headline: A Web Site to Call Your Own
abstract: Microsoft Office Live is a suite of services, mostly free, to help the little guy get into the game of online sales and marketing.

headline: Trump’s ‘Fired’ is Microsoft’s ‘Hired’
abstract: Carolyn Kepcher, who helped Donald Trump fire corporate wannabes on “The Apprentice” television show, took a new role on Tuesday – helping Microsoft find the best small-business idea in America. Ms. Kepcher is one of the judges of Microsoft’s “Ultimate Challenge” contest, the winner of which will get $100,000 in seed money, a storefront or other space in Manhattan for a year rent-free, and software to help get their business started.

headline: Alcatel Takes Microsoft to Court
abstract: Alcatel, the world’s largest supplier of broadband Internet equipment, sued Microsoft, accusing it of infringing patents for digital video and communication networks. While details of the alleged infringement were not disclosed, the company said that it sought to preserve Alcatel’s rights to fair compensation for its intellectual property rights used by Microsoft.

headline: Microsoft Strikes Deal for Music
abstract: In a rare move, Microsoft said Wednesday that it had agreed to pay a percentage of the sales of its new portable media player, the Zune, to the Universal Music Group.

headline: Microsoft-Novell Pact Is Already in Dispute
abstract: Less than three weeks after they reached an accord hailed as proof that rival software companies could work together, the chief executives of Novell and Microsoft are engaged in an unusual public dispute. Explaining the agreement at a software developers’ conference in Seattle last week, Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, said it “appropriately compensated Microsoft” because Linux, an open-source competitor to Microsoft’s Windows operating system, “uses our patented intellectual property.” But Novell’s chief executive disagrees.

headline: Microsoft Gives Europe Antitrust Documents
abstract: Microsoft submitted a new batch of technical information about its Windows operating system to the European Commission on Thursday, meeting the latest deadline to provide information on whether it is complying with a 2004 antitrust ruling. “This is an important milestone,” Microsoft said in a statement. Final edits and technical review of the information already submitted in July have now been completed, it added, insisting that it had not broken the summer deadline.

headline: Europe Warns Microsoft Over Compliance
abstract: The European Commission has threatened Microsoft with daily fines of 3 million euros ($5.7 million) if it does not provide certain information that would allow rival software developers to make their programs work smoothly with Windows.

headline: Red Hat Says No Thanks to Microsoft Offer
abstract: Microsoft, which has agreed with Novell to make the Linux and Windows operating systems compatible, opened the door Thursday to a similar alliance with Red Hat. “We are willing to do the same deal with Red Hat Linux and other Linux distributors,” Microsoft Chief Executive Steve Ballmer said at an SQL database software conference in Seattle.

headline: 2 Giants in a Deal Over Linux
abstract: Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system on Thursday by striking a deal with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell’s version of Linux could operate together with Windows in corporate data centers.

headline: A Windows-Linux Pact for $348 Million
abstract: Microsoft will make two payments totaling $348 million to Novell under an agreement to allow Novell’s open-source Linux software to work with Windows.

headline: Influential Goldman Analyst to Jump Ship, Report Says
abstract: Rick Sherlund, a Goldman Sachs partner and veteran software analyst who has covered Microsoft since it went public, plans to leave the Wall Street firm to work in money management, possibly starting his own fund, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Gates’s Investment Firm in Energy Venture
abstract: Cascade Investment, the private investment vehicle for Microsoft founder Bill Gates, is forming a joint venture with utility operator PNM Resources to create an unregulated energy company. The 50-50-owned joint venture will serve markets in the Southwest, West and Texas, the companies said. Cascade is PNM’s second-largest shareholder.

headline: Amid Web 2.0 Buzz, 10 Reality Checks
abstract: What was the worst Internet acquisition ever? Many would nominate the expensive and ill-fated union of Time Warner and AOL. But that was only the second-worst Net deal, according to James Nicholson, an Internet entrepreneur and blogger whose own top 10 list of bad Web deals appears on the Seeking Alpha site. It is a thoroughly subjective and highly debatable ranking, but worth discussing in this time of renewed interest in online acquisitions. Mr. Nicholson’s criteria are simple: To rank among the worst, an Internet deal must have been expensive and contributed little or nothing to long-term growth. So much to choose from!

headline: So Much Music, So Few Choices
abstract: Restrictive hardware and convoluted rights management crimp consumer choices.

headline: Taj Hotels to Buy Boston Ritz
abstract: The Taj Hotels Resorts and Palaces, a 103-year-old luxury hotel firm based in Mumbai, agreed to purchase the Ritz-Carlton Boston for $170 million.

headline: Small Business Fighting Big Spam
abstract: Do you have any suggestions for individuals and small businesses to combat spam?

headline: Desktop Publishing on the Mac
abstract: I’m looking for a Mac program that is comparable to Microsoft Publisher. What are the choices?

headline: Some Advertisers Shun Air America, a Lonely Voice From Talk Radio’s Left
abstract: It seems that a lack of major advertising dollars was responsible for Air America filing for bankruptcy protection last month.

headline: Litigious Forgent Reaches Patent Settlement With Tech Firms
abstract: Forgent Networks, a company that generates most of its revenue from patent licensing and litigation, has reached an $8 million settlement with some of the technology industry’s biggest players over the use of a patent covering the ubiquitous JPEG digital image format.

headline: New Nvidia Chip Steps Closer to Supercomputing in the PC
abstract: Nvidia introduced its next-generation processor, capable of more than three trillion mathematical operations per second.

headline: A Smarter Computer to Pick Stocks
abstract: Traders’ quest for a competitive edge has led some of them to look at the outer frontier of trading: computer programs that use artificial intelligence.

headline: Takeover Bids Set Off the Biggest Rally in a Month
abstract: Monday’s frenzied round of takeover announcement spurred the biggest stock market rally in a month and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to its first gain in seven days.

headline: Release of PlayStation 3 Becomes a Waiting Game
abstract: Gamers were standing in line for days in cities across the country to be among the first owners of the Sony PlayStation 3.

headline: 176 Newspapers to Form a Partnership With Yahoo
abstract: The alliance is a sign that wary newspapers are increasingly willing to shake hands with the technology companies they once saw as a threat.

headline: A New Push to Raise Cap on H-1B Visa
abstract: A coalition of business and education groups is making a renewed push to persuade Congress to raise the number of skilled foreign workers allowed into the United States.

headline: Google Shortcuts for Quick Searches
abstract: Google can recognize certain types of numbers and codes typed into its search box and save you a step in your quest.

headline: Google Reaches Copyright Deal With Belgians
abstract: Google reached a settlement with Belgian photographers and journalists Friday in a copyright dispute over how Google News links to newspaper content.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MOSTLY GRAVY It is a holiday week, so there is fairly little on the schedule. Markets, of course, will be closed Thursday in observance of Thanksgiving. The bond market will close early on Wednesday. The only economic reports due out are the leading economic indicators for October, on Monday, and the University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment index, on Wednesday.

headline: Google Closes YouTube Deal, But Web 2.0 Debate Continues
abstract: While Google closed its $1.65 billion acquisition of the online video provider YouTube Tuesday, questions still remain for some industry watchers about the viability of so-called Web 2.0 companies like YouTube.

headline: Of Yahoo, Peanut Butter and Buyouts
abstract: Everyone seems to have a theory about why Yahoo! is struggling. Google, its rival and a darling of the investment world, is often cited as a major cause of the Web portal’s woes. Yahoo senior vice president Brad Garlinghouse recently compared his company’s predicament to a popular condiment in a four-page internal memo dubbed “The Peanut Butter Manifesto.” Whatever the cause, The New York Times wrote Monday that there is an emerging consensus about one thing: If Yahoo remains an underachiever, it could be a candidate for takeover.

headline: Rules for Small Businesses Will Recertify Their Sizes
abstract: The Small Business Administration announced new rules yesterday intended to help small businesses obtain more federal contracts and to assure that contracts set aside for small businesses are not going to larger companies.

headline: At $500, Is Google Midas or the Emperor With No Clothes?
abstract: As Google shares passed the $500 mark yesterday (shares closed at $509.65), the battle was on between the believers and the skeptics. The question: Is the stock overvalued, or does the potential growth of the Web giant support the high price?

headline: Takeover Bids Set Off the Biggest Rally in a Month
abstract: Takeovers spurred the biggest stock market rally in a month yesterday and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to its first gain in seven days.

headline: A $500 Milestone for Google Believers
abstract: Google’s shares gained $14.60, or 3 percent, to close at $509.65, passing the $500 mark for the first time.

headline: PlayStation 3 on Rescue Mission
abstract: Sony badly needs for PlayStation 3 to be a long-term hit to recover from its current decline and regain its title as global innovator.

headline: What’s Next, a MySpace Profile?
abstract: It’s a sign of how slow the government is with the Internet when the chairman of the S.E.C. posts to a blog, and it is seen as remarkable.

headline: Flaws Are Detected in Microsoft’s Vista
abstract: Researchers and hackers have found potentially serious flaws in Microsoft’s new Windows Vista operating system.

headline: The Lazy Top 10 Anything
abstract: As any media consumer knows, this is the season of the list. Late December is the point where editors tell their pundits to list the “Top Ten Moments in...”

headline: Microsoft Software Updates Go on Sale to Businesses
abstract: Microsoft made new versions of Windows and Office available to business customers on Thursday.

headline: Google Passes Yahoo in Tally of Visitors
abstract: Google displaced Yahoo as the world’s second-most-visited Web site in November and closed in on the leader, Microsoft.

headline: Stuffing the Electronic Ballot Box
abstract: When marketers and spammers try to manipulate the rankings at sites like Digg.com to promote a company, product or Web site, the system breaks down.

headline: Google Steps More Boldly Into PayPal’s Territory
abstract: Google’s aggressive promotion of its Checkout payment service has helped speed its adoption by online merchants.

headline: The Economist on ‘Fair Trade’
abstract: “Buy organic, destroy the rainforest,” The Economist said last week, eliciting howls of protest from food-activist bloggers.

headline: Vista Wins on Looks. As for Lacks ...
abstract: Microsoft’s new operating system, Vista, will soon be on sale to the public. But you may need a new computer to run it properly.

headline: Squeezing Money From the Music
abstract: Major labels have begun demanding a cut of concert earnings or T-shirt, ring tone and merchandise revenue from new artists seeking record contracts.

headline: Looking for a Gambit to Win at Google’s Game
abstract: Microsoft’s online chief wants to change the way his company runs its Internet business.  But he is finding that redirecting such a behemoth is slow going.

headline: Vista Is Ready. Are You?
abstract: Why it might be a better idea to wait until you need a new PC to get the latest version of Windows.

headline: Spam Doubles, Finding New Ways to Deliver Itself
abstract: The surge has left the antispam industry scrambling to develop new techniques to keep up.

headline: Sony Shifts Duties of the Leader of the PlayStation Unit
abstract: Ken Kutaragi, the father of the PlayStation game console, will no longer run the day-to-day affairs of Sony’s video game unit.

headline: Executives Sold Stock in Droves Last Month
abstract: Stock sales by America’s corporate chieftains exceeded purchases last month by the widest margin since 1987, a sign they don’t share the confidence of investors who sent the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index to a six-year high. Executives including Microsoft‘s Bill Gates, Google‘s Eric Schmidt and Kohl’s William Kellogg in aggregate sold $63.18 of shares for every $1 they bought in November, an analysis by Bloomberg of data from the Washington Service showed. Advances by Microsoft, Google and Kohl’s have helped push the S&P 500 up 13 percent this year.

headline: Double Fusion Links Up With Venture Investors
abstract: Double Fusion, the developer of one of the leading in-game advertising networks, has scored $26 million in new venture capital. The new round was led by Norwest Venture Partners and also included funding from Time Warner, Accel Partners, Jerusalem Venture Partners, Hearst Corporation, IDG Ventures Pacific and Sedona Capital. Double Fusion, and competitors like Microsoft-owned Massive, are in the business of linking advertisers with video games.

headline: Law Firms’ Merger Will Expand Reach
abstract: Kirkpatrick & Lockhart Nicholson Graham and Preston Gates & Ellis agreed to merge yesterday to form one of the nation’s largest law firms, with 1,400 lawyers and expected 2007 revenue of $750 million.

headline: Visto Scores $7.7 Million in Damages from Seven
abstract: Mobile e-mail provider Visto said Wednesday a federal judge has ordered rival Seven Networks to pay $7.7 million in damages for infringing on three patents, affirming a jury’s verdict reached eight months ago. Tuesday’s ruling by U.S. District Judge T. John Ward in Texas represents Visto’s biggest victory yet in its legal crusade to protect several patents on technology used by major wireless phone providers to deliver e-mail on their mobile networks. Seven, which, along with Visto and Good Technology, competes against the likes of Research in Motion and Microsoft, recently closed on a $42 million round of venture capital financing.

headline: Should Nasdaq’s Chief Be Smiling?
abstract: Robert Greifeld, Nasdaq‘s chief executive, was looking quite upbeat on Thursday as Microsoft chief Steven Ballmer stood next to him and rang the market’s opening bell. Prudential analyst Robert Rutschow was sounding downright gloomy, however. Mr. Rutschow on Thursday cut his rating on Nasdaq’s stock to “underweight” from “overweight” — skipping “neutral” altogether — citing concerns that Nasdaq is losing ground to electronic communication networks, or ECN’s, among other factors. The analyst also wrote that Nasdaq’s bid for the London Stock Exchange is not likely to succeed anytime soon.

headline: Helping a Balky Laptop
abstract: I get an occasional “insufficient system resources exist to complete the API” message when I try to put my laptop in hibernation. What can I do?

headline: Deal Chatter 2006: What Got You Talking
abstract: A would-be banker who does ballroom dancing. The life of a first-year lawyer. Steve Jobs.

headline: Google Wins Dismissal of Patent Lawsuit
abstract: Google won a dismissal of a lawsuit filed by a Wisconsin company over four patents covering database search technology.

headline: Strategic Corporate Altruism
abstract: Harvard Business Review argues that good corporate citizenship is “a source of opportunity, innovation and competitive advantage.”

headline: Nintendo to Offer Sturdier Straps for Wii
abstract: Nintendo said it was taking steps to keep energetic users of its Wii video game console from breaking their televisions and ceiling fans.

headline: To Get Viewers for Reruns, a ‘Sopranos’ Game
abstract: The online game A&E is using to promote reruns of “The Sopranos” is part of a trend toward marketing contests that require hunting around in the real world.

headline: Considering a Media Center PC
abstract: I see lots of machines with "Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005." What is the difference between this and good old XP?

headline: YouTube Rival Metacafe Said to Seek Buyer
abstract: TechCrunch, the blog that first broke the news that Google would acquire YouTube, is fueling speculation about the potential sale of another video-sharing site. The blog was following up on rumors that surfaced late last week, when Israeli news site Globes Online indicated that Metacafe, an Israel-based company with an office in Palo Alto, Calif., is “close to being acquired by a foreign company for as much as $300 million.” Asked about the report by Reuters, Metacafe declined to comment.

headline: Big Deals Ahead for Yahoo?
abstract: Shortly after Susan L. Decker was appointed chief financial officer of Yahoo in mid-2000, the bottom fell out of the Internet business. Throughout that challenging period, Ms. Decker played a leading role in helping reset expectations on Wall Street and inside the company.

headline: Yes, It’s a Spoof, but It’s Also Selling Something
abstract: Advertising agencies have turned to spoofing their own industry to attract viewers long enough to deliver a new message.

headline: Nasdaq Launches Hostile Bid for London Exchange
abstract: Nasdaq formally began its hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange on Tuesday, needing the support of just 21.3 percent of the target company’s shareholders. Nasdaq lowered the threshold for shareholder approval of its $5.3 billion offer to 50 percent. Because it already owns 28.75 percent of the exchange, an additional 21.3 percent was all it required to take control of the exchange, which has so far resisted Nasdaq’s approaches.

headline: Writer Wanted at Chapman Capital
abstract: Robert L. Chapman Jr., founder of activist hedge fund Chapman Capital and unofficial poet laureate of the 13D letter, is looking for a ghostwriter. Mr. Chapman’s public missives to corporations, in which he often demands that they change their ways or else, have become the stuff of legend for their multiloquence and for their opprobrious — often contumelious — tone. Now, according to a post over the weekend on Craigslist, Mr. Chapman is seeking an “Activist 13D Letter Writer/Editor” (and what kid didn’t dream of growing up to become that?)

headline: The Retooling of a Search Engine
abstract: Ask.com is introducing AskCity, a service that integrates maps with information about local businesses, restaurants, listings and reviews.

headline: Addressing a Shortage of Hotel Rooms, Not People
abstract: Demand for hotel rooms is soaring in India, pushing peak season rates for basic rooms into the stratosphere.

headline: 2 Hired to Overhaul Marketing Leave Their Posts at Wal-Mart
abstract: The departures coincide with slowing sales growth and several marketing stumbles at Wal-Mart, like designer-inspired fashions that have failed to sell.

headline: Brilliant Ideas That Found a Welcome
abstract: A top 10 list — not of the greatest tech products, but of the greatest individual features that surfaced in 2006.

headline: A Bubble Watcher Watches Google
abstract: Compared with the late-’90s technology boom, there are few initial public offerings, making it harder to determine when an Internet downturn has begun.

headline: The Gay-Friendly Places to Work
abstract: U.S. financial firms have become more gay-friendly than those in any other industry, according to a new report.

headline: Subscriptions for a Browser
abstract: How do I use R.S.S. feeds with Internet Explorer 7?

headline: Finally, a Way to Catch a Flight Without Shedding Your Shoes
abstract: The T.S.A. has approved a machine that scans air passengers’ shoes, while on their feet, for suspicious metal and signs of potentially explosive material.

headline: Whatever Happened to Online Etiquette?
abstract: The deeper we sail into the new online world of communications, the sadder I get about its future.

headline: Take the Hotel Room Home
abstract: Hotels have become miniature malls, putting a price tag on nearly whatever you see, hear, taste, touch and smell during your stay.

headline: Verizon to Allow Ads on Its Mobile Phones
abstract: The move is a symbolic advance toward the widespread appearance of marketing messages on the smallest of screens.

headline: Google to Offer Variation on Stock Options
abstract: Google said that it would grant employees transferable stock options that could be sold as well as exercised.

headline: A Researcher for Microsoft Is Reported Missing at Sea
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  The Coast Guard is searching for a computer scientist from Microsoft who left for a daylong sailing trip off the coast of San Francisco on Sunday and did not return.

headline: Delays Limit Robust Sales at Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft reported strong sales but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.

headline: First the Wait for Microsoft Vista; Now the Marketing Barrage
abstract: Skeptics were drowned out by the marketing campaign for Microsoft’s operating system on the eve of its arrival.

headline: Microsoft and Ford Combine Products
abstract: Bill Gates unveiled a partnership with the Ford Motor Company to build Microsoft technology into several Ford models.

headline: Costly Gift From Microsoft Is an Invitation to Blog
abstract: The gift of laptops loaded with Windows Vista is only the latest of Microsoft’s efforts to engage the technologically aware, and often anti-Microsoft, blogging community.

headline: Vista Arrives With Limited Fanfare
abstract: The quiet debut for Microsoft’s latest version of the Windows operating system reflects how the company’s influence has faded as the nature of computer software has changed.

headline: A Lively Market, Legal and Not, for Software Bugs
abstract: Software vulnerabilities are bought and sold online, both by legitimate security companies and by thieves.

headline: Group Formed to Support Linux as Rival to Windows
abstract: Major technology companies are consolidating their support into the Linux Foundation to help the operating system compete more effectively against Microsoft.

headline: Purging Bloat to Fashion Sleek Software
abstract: After a radical redesign, Microsoft's Word, Excel and PowerPoint applications are almost totally new programs.

headline: Netflix to Deliver Movies to the PC
abstract: Netflix is introducing a service to deliver movies and television shows directly to PCs, not as downloads but as streaming video.

headline: Getting Graphic With Vista
abstract: When shopping for a new computer, what kind of graphics card will be necessary to run Microsoft’s Windows Vista?

headline: Console Sales Beat Goals, Makers’ Early Reports Say
abstract: Video game makers are shipping more consoles than expected, setting the stage for what may be a multiyear battle among Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo.

headline: In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
abstract: Plenty of newcomers — with names like hakia and Snap — are trying to beat Google at its own game.

headline: Studios’ DVDs Face a Crack in Security
abstract: An anonymous computer programmer claims to have hacked the copy protection used in both the HD-DVD and Blu-ray high-definition DVD formats.

headline: Knock, Knock, Microsoft. It’s SanDisk
abstract: Microsoft has so far failed to fire the imagination of the buying public since the Zune digital music player’s release last fall.

headline: A Wake-Up Call to Microsoft's PR Team
abstract: Bribing bloggers, fabricating reviews and making up letters to the editor makes the company look worse, not better.

headline: E-Mail Start-Up Gets Cash to Take on Microsoft
abstract: Going head-to-head with Microsoft is a risky business strategy, but investors in a mail server technology developer, PostPath are confident enough to give the company an additional $15 million. The Series C financing for PostPath closed in late December and was led by a new investor, Jafco Ventures. Two previous investors Matrix Partners and Worldview Technology Partners also participated in the financing, which brings the company’s total funding to $30 million. PostPath has developed a Linux-based exchange server that integrates fully with Microsoft’s own Exchange server.

headline: Tips for Protecting the Home Computer
abstract: Botnet programs and other malicious software largely take aim at PCs running the Microsoft Windows operating system, because Windows’ ubiquity makes it fertile ground for network-based attacks.

headline: Non-Celebrities on the Web, Seeming to Make Non-Pitches
abstract: Marketers are turning to unusual personalities who offer the kind of novelty and freshness that young people might blog about, link to and comment on in chats.

headline: How E.T. Might Phone Home, if Home Had a G.S.M. Network
abstract: The Palm Treo 750 is a Windows Mobile smartphone with a full keyboard, bright color touch screen and 1.3-megapixel camera.

headline: More Deals Likely in Storage Sector, Report Says
abstract: Isilon‘s successful initial public offering could inspire other midrange data-storage companies to make a similar move, The 451 Group suggests in a report. The firm also predicts that other storage companies will get snapped up by acquirers such as Hewlett-Packard, Sun, or even longer shots such as Microsoft or fresh-out-of-bankruptcy SGI.

headline: In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
abstract: As Google continues to outmaneuver its main search rivals, Yahoo and Microsoft, plenty of newcomers – with names like Powerset, hakia, ChaCha and Snap – are trying to beat the company at its own game. And Wikia, a company started by a founder of Wikipedia, plans to develop a search engine that, like the popular Web-based encyclopedia, would be built by a community of programmers and users.

headline: A Seat for the Jet Cockpit in Your Game Room (No Need to Buckle Up)
abstract: Serious fans of flight-simulator programs can now grab their force-feedback joysticks and practically climb right into the cockpit.

headline: Big Labels Offer Free Music to College Students
abstract: Ruckus Network will offer free music downloads — with some substantial restrictions — to any college student.

headline: Apple Profit Rose 78% in Quarter
abstract: Apple delivered $1 billion in profit for its first quarter, based largely on the Christmas performance of its iPod music player business.

headline: Apple, Google and Napster Named in Patent Lawsuit
abstract: Intertainer, a video-on-demand company, last week filed a broad lawsuit asserting that Apple, Google and Napster are infringing on a 2005 patent that covers the commercial distribution of audio and video over the Internet.

headline: For the Well-Dressed iPod, a Leather Jacket in the Color of Your Choice
abstract: Rooting for Manchester United or the Giants to win? Get an iPod case in your team colors.

headline: Keeping Our Eyes on the Road
abstract: VoiceBox, a Seattle-based speech recognition company, is bringing voice commands to automobiles.

headline: AOL, Now Focused on Free, Sells Its Paid Music Service
abstract: After six years of trying to build an online music service, AOL agreed to sell its AOL Music Now to Napster for $15 million.

headline: I.B.M. to Introduce Workers’ Networking Software
abstract: I.B.M. plans to announce a set of social software tools typically associated with sites like MySpace and Facebook to the corporate world.

headline: Qualcomm Under Scrutiny by Korean Antitrust Agency
abstract: A task force will investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company, the latest in a string of legal battles.

headline: Demand Outpaced Supply for New Game Consoles
abstract: The Xbox 360 outsold the Wii, which outsold the PlayStation 3 during the crucial holiday season.

headline: The Computer With a TV, and a Family's Virtual Bulletin Board
abstract: The notion of a computer at the heart of every home gets a little bump with the multitasking Hewlett-Packard's $1,800 TouchSmart PC.

headline: At Davos, the Squabble Resumes on How to Wire the Third World
abstract: Passions still run high at the World Economic Forum over the best way to deploy computers in the developing world.

headline: Firms Fret as Office E-Mail Jumps Security Walls
abstract: More Internet-literate workers are forwarding their office e-mail to free Web-accessible personal accounts.

headline: Valleywag’s Denton Tells Doerr: Retire Now
abstract: L. John Doerr, one of the big names at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, is a legendary investor, according to Valleywag’s Nick Denton. So legendary that Mr. Denton uses the phrase twice within 15 words. But, the Gawker media emperor concludes in an editorial, now is the perfect time for the veteran venture capitalist to retire.

headline: Who Will Bring the Internet to Your TV?
abstract: The companies trying to bring the boundless realm of the Internet to the 83-year-old TV are taking one of three markedly different approaches.

headline: Moving It All to Vista
abstract: When the time comes, how can I move all of my bookmarks, music and other files from my old computer to a new Windows Vista PC?

headline: New Disc May Sway DVD Wars
abstract: Warner Brothers plans to announce a single videodisc that can play films and television programs in both Blu-ray and HD-DVD, the rival DVD technologies.

headline: Online Job Sites: Ripe for Consolidation?
abstract: The proliferation of niche help-wanted Web sites, as well as networking sites like Craigslist and LinkedIn, could lead to consolidation among more general jobs sites like Monster, HotJobs, and CareerBuilder. Niche sites made up 64 percent of the market in 2005, according to BusinessWeek, up from 39 percent in 2004. And visits to the “big three” jobs sites are falling fast, though sales are rising thanks to the strength of the job market.

headline: Patent Lawsuit Names Leading Technology Firms
abstract: The latest patent dispute pits Apple, Google and Napster against a company that closed five years ago.

headline: Macworld Rumors
abstract: The hottest rumors revolving around the upcoming Macworld convention are about the new products that could be introduced: an Apple cellphone/iPod, a touchscreen iPod and a Macintosh tablet.

headline: Best Buy and Circuit City Report Brisk Sales for December
abstract: Electronics sales were a bright spot for retailers facing slowing revenue this holiday season.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: ECONOMIC BAROMETERS Two critical economic events are scheduled to take place this week. First, on Wednesday, the Federal Open Market Committee is expected to meet and issue its decision on short-term interest rates; expectations are that the federal funds rate will remain at 5.25 percent. Investors have been hoping that rates would be lowered, but positive economic reports last week about new home sales and big factory orders have made that less likely. On Friday, the government is expected to report on unemployment for December, with forecasters predicting an increase of 140,000 jobs.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: DAVOS, ANYONE? The annual World Economic Forum will take place Wednesday through Sunday in Davos, Switzerland, drawing political and business leaders — plus a celebrity or two — to brainstorm solutions to world problems. Among the top issues on the agenda are climate change and the role of emerging markets. Klaus Schwab, right, the founder and executive chairman of the forum, said he hoped that this year’s conference would address a “schizophrenic world” in which there are both broad prosperity and tremendous risks from many directions.

headline: A Personal Computer to Carry in a Pocket
abstract: The newest cellphone screens are evolving to adopt more and more characteristics of a personal computer.

headline: SAP Plans New Venture for Serving Small Clients
abstract: The biggest maker of business management software said it would invest as much as $520 million on an organization aimed at smaller business clients.

headline: Nintendo’s Wii,  Radiating Fun, Is Eclipsing Sony Machine
abstract: There are growing signs that Nintendo’s Wii, which gets couch potatoes off the couch, has taken the lead over Sony’s PlayStation 3.

headline: Atop TV Sets, Basic Black Boxes Face Competition
abstract: As consumers stray, the traditional cable box is getting  a high-tech overhaul.

headline: Sun Microsystems Will Use Intel Chips
abstract: Sun Microsystems and Intel announced a deal for Sun to use Intel chips in some of its computer servers, a setback for the rival chip maker Advanced Micro Devices.

headline: A Google Package Challenges Microsoft
abstract: Google will unveil communications and productivity software aimed at businesses that will be accessible over the Internet.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine
abstract: Microsoft says its purchase of Medstory is part of an effort to build a suite of tools and services related to health care.

headline: A Software Maker Goes Up Against Microsoft
abstract: VMware is the early leader in a fast-growing market for virtual-machine software, putting it on a collision course with Microsoft.

headline: Microsoft Plays Down a Sales Lift From Vista
abstract: Wall Street analysts are being too optimistic about sales of Windows Vista, Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, said on Thursday.

headline: Microsoft Spurns Appeal to Intervene in Russian Piracy Case
abstract: Microsoft rebuffed a public appeal by Mikhail Gorbachev for its chairman, Bill Gates, to intervene on behalf of a Russian school principal charged with software piracy.

headline: Microsoft’s Vista Debut Wasn’t Nearly So ‘Wow’
abstract: The Vista release did not generate anything close to the excitement created 12 years ago when Windows 95 was introduced.

headline: MP3 Patents in Upheaval After Verdict
abstract: Microsoft was ordered by a federal jury to pay $1.52 billion in a patent dispute over the MP3 format.

headline: Deals in Radio and Food; Remorse From an Airline
abstract: Regulators will have more time on their hands as the Bush administration rejected more oversight of the rapidly growing hedge fund industry.

headline: How About a Mouse and Keyboard to Go With That Vista?
abstract: The Microsoft Wireless Entertainment Desktop 7000 combines a Bluetooth keyboard and a rechargeable mouse.

headline: Russian Judge Dismisses Any Penalty in Piracy Case
abstract: A provincial school headmaster was convicted of using pirated Microsoft software in school computers, but no penalty was imposed.

headline: Updating Windows Defender
abstract: When I turn on my computer I receive a message that includes “Windows Defender Application failed to initialize.” What can I do to fix this error?

headline: Silicon Valley’s High-Tech Hunt for Colleague
abstract: Silicon Valley’s best and brightest organized a concerted, high-tech effort to find a missing Microsoft researcher.

headline: YouTube Rival Catches Microsoft’s Eye
abstract: Sony bought video-sharing Web site Grouper in August. Google picked up YouTube, the king of video sites, in October. Now comes a report that Microsoft has taken a look at Revver, yet another venture-backed video-sharing startup. CNET News.com reports that executives from Microsoft toured Revver’s Los Angeles headquarters last month to determine whether that company’s service could enhance Soapbox, Microsoft’s own, newly launched service.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Health Information Search Engine
abstract: Microsoft‘s drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled Monday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers. Microsoft is buying Medstory, a small start-up in Foster City, Calif., for an undisclosed amount. Its search software applies artificial intelligence techniques to medical and health information in medical journals, government documents and on the Internet.

headline: Google’s Moves Rekindle Microsoft-Yahoo Speculation
abstract: Talk that Microsoft might (or at least, should) acquire Yahoo has been going on for months. On Monday, TheStreet.com’s Vishesh Kumar joined the chorus, writing that Google‘s continued encroachment on Microsoft’s territory might force the software giant’s hand. Last week, Google, already the leader of the online search business, introduced an upgraded version of its applications suite, which directly targets Microsoft’s venerable Office product.

headline: Paul Allen Takes Back Rose Garden
abstract: Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder and Seattle-area billionaire, has agreed to buy back the Rose Garden Arena in Portland that he previously owned. Mr. Allen is making the acquisition through his investment vehicle, Vulcan. As part of the agreement, a subsidiary of Vulcan plans to purchase Portland Arena Management, which has held the notes to the Rose Garden since Mr. Allen put the facility into bankruptcy about three years ago.

headline: Four Seasons Agrees to $3.8 Billion Buyout
abstract: Four Seasons Hotels, the luxury hotelier, said it agreed Monday to be acquired by a group including its chairman and controlling shareholder, Isadore Sharp; Prince Alwaleed bin Talal; and an investment firm owned by Microsoft‘s Bill Gates. The deal, first proposed in November, offers $82 in cash per share, valuing the company at $3.8 billion including debt.

headline: EMI May Sell Recordings Online With No Anti-Copying Software
abstract: EMI is said to have discussed proposals to sell unprotected files through an array of digital retailers, including Apple, Microsoft, Real Networks and Yahoo.

headline: EMC Plans Public Offering for 10% of Software Division
abstract: EMC said it planned to sell 10 percent of its fast-growing software subsidiary, VMware, in an initial public offering this summer.

headline: Too Big to Rise?
abstract: The five biggest stocks in America are lagging this year.

headline: Better Shoeboxes for Digital Photos
abstract: While digital photography has freed up closet space, sorting and retrieving pictures in the era of the 250-gigabyte hard drive has created a set of challenges of its own.

headline: A Notebook’s Two Hard Drives Work Separately or as a Team
abstract: The Toshiba Satellite A135-S4499 is one of the first entry-level notebooks with two hard drives for extra storage or automatic backup.

headline: Google Said to Buy Videogame Advertising Startup
abstract: The Red Herring is reporting that Google has made another acquisition, this time agreeing to buy Adscape Media, which provides advertising within video games, for $23 million. The article seemed to question the move, however, suggesting that the purchase “gives Google little beyond a few potentially interesting patents,” and adding, “don’t expect the Internet giant to announce big in-game ad deals with publishers like Electronic Arts anytime soon.”

headline: Victims of Success
abstract: Marshall Goldsmith, an executive coach, argues that your past success could be holding you back.

headline: Awarder of Space Prize to Add Others
abstract: The X Prize Foundation said it was starting a broad fund-raising campaign to reward other innovators.

headline: And the Oscar Winner Is Big-Event Television
abstract: Madison Avenue is already beating the drum for the next big live television event, the Oscars.

headline: Software Tool of Pirates Gets Work in Hollywood
abstract: Hollywood studios are going into business with one of their biggest tormentors: the peer-to-peer pioneer BitTorrent.

headline: Software Exploited by Pirates Goes to Work for Hollywood
abstract: Hollywood studios are going into business with one of their biggest tormentors: the peer-to-peer pioneer BitTorrent.

headline: Kaizen, That Continuous Improvement Strategy, Finds Its Ideal Environment
abstract: On the Web, continuous improvement really is continuous.

headline: Europe Cool to Apple’s Suggestions on Music
abstract: Europeans said the call to drop copy protection from music sold online seemed to be an effort to shift the focus of the debate.

headline: A Long-Delayed Ad System Has Yahoo Crossing Its Fingers
abstract: Project Panama is Yahoo’s effort to close the wide gap with Google in the race for search advertising dollars.

headline: Gordon Macklin, 78, Pioneer in Electronic Stock Trading, Dies
abstract: Gordon S. Macklin helped usher in the era of electronic trading of securities when he oversaw the development of the Nasdaq.

headline: Apple’s Chief Calls for End to Music Copy Protection
abstract: Steven P. Jobs says that dropping digital anti-piracy protection would benefit record labels and customers.

headline: A Boston Marketing Stunt That Bombed, or Did It?
abstract: Guerrilla marketing has become more popular but the Turner Broadcasting campaign left the network scrambling to apologize.

headline: After Long Dispute, Two Apples Work It Out
abstract: Apple Inc., the maker of the iPod, and Apple Corps, the guardian of the Beatles’ music interests, have settled their trademark fight over their shared name.

headline: Learning to Play the System and Use That Monopoly Money
abstract: More travelers are thinking of frequent-flier miles as a little like Monopoly play money, and online booking sites are thinking up new ways to both earn and use the miles.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Net Jumps 26% in the Quarter
abstract: Notebook computers flew off shelves over the holidays, helping to bolster Hewlett-Packard’s lead atop the PC heap.

headline: Cellphone Ads May Take Off Soon
abstract: Experts say it is only a matter of time before the 2.2 billion mobile phone users around the world consider it natural to tune into a 15-second spot.

headline: Ads Drive Sharp Surge in Earnings at Google
abstract: Google reported a sharp rise in both sales and profit, driven by blockbuster growth of its search-driven advertising business.

headline: Consumers Have Allies on the Web
abstract: Consumer advocacy takes on renewed power as it moves into a new form, the blog.

headline: Jobs Calls for End to Music Copy Protection
abstract: Apple’s chief said record companies should allow songs to be sold online without anticopying software, in part because the technology does not stop piracy.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Webdenda.

headline: Exxon Mobil Just Wants to Be Loved
abstract: If Exxon Mobil doesn’t learn to talk more straightforwardly about its beliefs, it will never stop being the world’s whipping boy.

headline: What Could Bog Down the Bull
abstract: Markets celebrated the Fed’s action but analysts warned that the road ahead promises to be a long, hard slog as corporate profits are starting to slow.

headline: Upgraded Version of Xbox 360 to Be Introduced by Microsoft
abstract: The new version is an appeal to an elite class of hard-core game players who would like a little more of everything.

headline: Microsoft Agrees to Buy Maker of Voice-Recognition Software
abstract: The deal to buy Tellme Networks was said to be worth more than $800 million, making it Microsoft’s biggest acquisition since 2002.

headline: Microsoft Executive Leaving
abstract: The Microsoft executive who had led the effort to close the gap on Google is leaving the company.

headline: Microsoft to Open Its Online Gaming Service to Windows Users
abstract: Xbox Live, Microsoft’s gaming network that serves some six million Xbox users, is scheduled to be opened to PC gamers on May 8.

headline: Microsoft in First Technology License Deal
abstract: Microsoft said it had signed its first agreement to license its technology, almost three years after European Union antitrust regulators ordered the software company to share data to increase competition. Microsoft said the deal, with Quest Software of California, was meant to comply with an antitrust order issued in March 2004 that demanded licensing of software that helps desktop computers communicate with servers. But the deal was met with skepticism from adversaries, who questioned how a company with a longstanding relationship with Microsoft could be considered a rival. The European Commission threatened Microsoft last week with fines as high as 3 million euros ($3.9 million) a day for failing to comply with the order.

headline: Microsoft Prize of $10,000 to Promote Xbox Games
abstract: Microsoft plans to announce a contest to develop the next great digital diversion for the company’s Xbox 360.

headline: Searching for Michael Jordan? Microsoft Wants a Better Way
abstract: Trying to catch up with Google, Microsoft says it will change the way computer users search.

headline: Europeans Threaten More Fines for Microsoft
abstract: The European Commission said Microsoft was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system.

headline: A New Cable to Connect
abstract: What is a high-definition multimedia interface?

headline: Researchers Track Down a Plague of Fake Web Pages
abstract: Microsoft researchers say they have traced the companies and techniques behind thousands of spam Web pages.

headline: Patent Fights Are a Legacy of MP3’s Tangled Origins
abstract: The $1.5 billion settlement against Microsoft is only one result of the music format’s tangled history.

headline: A Laptop With Vista That Seems Just Like a Fully Upgraded PC
abstract: Acer’s TravelMate 2480-2779 laptop costs about $550 and runs Vista without complaint.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Speech Technology Company
abstract: Confirming reports that it was close a deal, Microsoft said Wednesday that it would buy Tellme Networks, an speech-recognition technology company. In a statement, Microsoft said that it plans to integrate Tellme’s products into its mobile offerings, with a long-term goal of integrating the technology into the rest of its lineup.

headline: More Analysis of a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
abstract: Microsoft could jumpstart its online business through a purchase of Web giant Yahoo , but such a deal could also “open the door to potentially unmanageable risks,” analysts at UBS said in a report Thursday. The analysts are just the latest to consider whether Microsoft should buy Yahoo. Speculation about such a deal has only increased with Google‘s recent moves deeper into the software business.

headline: Europeans Threaten More Fines for Microsoft
abstract: The European Commission on Thursday threatened Microsoft with millions of euros in new fines in a long-running antitrust dispute, saying the company was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system. The commission issued a “statement of objections,” asking Microsoft to respond to a complaint that it was still not complying with a decision three years ago that the company had abused its dominant market position.

headline: Yet More Musings on a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
abstract: For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world. John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them. But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound “crazy”: a joint venture between the two companies to create a “search monetization” business.

headline: Microsoft in Deal to Buy Tellme, Report Says
abstract: Microsoft is close to acquiring Tellme Networks, a privately held maker of products that bridge the worlds of speech recognition and the Internet, in a deal that could come as early as this week, according to CNet News.com.

headline: Benchmark Reaps Rewards of Microsoft’s Tellme Deal
abstract: Microsoft‘s move to buy Tellme for about $800 million represents a boon for Benchmark Capital, as well as Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, but no home run on the order of Google, says The Red Herring.

headline: Paul Allen’s Firm to Seek Banking Investments
abstract: Vulcan Capital, the venture-capital vehicle of Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, is creating a joint venture with Bankers’ Capital Group to look for investments in the banking sector in the southeast United States. Bankers’ Capital was launched last year by a group of executives that cleaned up troubled bank Flag Financial and sold it to RBC Centura, the Financial News reports.

headline: DoubleClick Said to Consider Sale
abstract: DoubleClick, an online advertising company controlled by a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, is exploring a sale and is in talks with potential suitors including Microsoft, the Wall Street Journal reported. DoubleClick was publicly traded in 2005 when it agreed to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman for about $1.1 billion. The firm is hoping to get at least $2 billion in a DoubleClick sale, a source told the Journal.

headline: The Name Game (Plus Typos)
abstract: Companies like Microsoft are filing lawsuits against outfits they say engage in a practice called “domain swiping.”

headline: Benchmark Signals Gaming Plays With New Hire
abstract: Mitch Lasky, who as chief executive of Jamdat led the company to the top of the cellphone-games market, is leaving his post as head of Electronic Arts‘s mobile-games unit to join Benchmark Capital as a general partner. The move suggests that Benchmark, a Silicon Valley venture firm that just celebrated the sale of portfolio company Tellme Networks to Microsoft, will be considering more investments in gaming startups.

headline: Apple TV Has Landed
abstract: Apple TV can connect your computer to your TV without wires — as long as you have a wide-screen TV.

headline: Analyst Sees AOL Deal on the Horizon
abstract: Will Time Warner log out of AOL?

headline: Apple Cult Becoming a Religion
abstract: Apple is finally being taken seriously not just by the true believers, but by just about everybody.

headline: Slow Down, Brave Multitasker, and Don’t Read This in Traffic
abstract: Think you can juggle the phone, e-mail, instant messages and work? New research shows the limits of multitasking.

headline: Time Change a ‘Mini-Y2K’ in Tech Terms
abstract: Companies are scrambling to reset computing devices as daylight saving time begins three weeks earlier.

headline: Palm Responds to the iPhone
abstract: The maker of hand-held computers has hired a top software designer to respond to the challenge posed by Apple’s new iPhone.

headline: No Raise, but No Tears, for Warren Buffett
abstract: The chief executive at Berkshire Hathaway took home the same $100,000 in 2006 that he has been earning for 25 years.

headline: Bridging the Computer-to-TV Divide
abstract: More by David Pogue on the early attempts to bridge the gulf between computer and TV.

headline: Google C.E.O. Plays Down Deal Talk
abstract: Just because Google spent $1.65 billion to acquire YouTube and is swimming in cash doesn’t mean that Google will seek a major deal again anytime soon, according to its chief executive. Reuters said that at Morgan Stanley’s technology conference, Eric Schmidt, responding to a question by analyst Mary Meeker, said that it’s “highly unlikely” the company will change course on how it uses cash.

headline: Patent Dispute Pits Tech Companies Against V.C.’s
abstract: A rift has arisen among larger technology companies and smaller venture capital firms over whether dramatic changes to U.S. patent law are necessary, CNet News.com reported Thursday. The differences in opinion played out during a Thursday hearing in the House of Representatives’ Small Business Committee, which doesn’t have the power to write patent laws but aimed to explore the small-business implications of Congress’ ongoing push for sweeping changes in the area.

headline: No Raise, but No Tears, for Warren Buffett
abstract: While many companies are starting tie the pay of chief executives to stock performance, don’t expect Berkshire Hathaway to jump on the bandwagon anytime soon. For Warren Buffett, Berkshire’s chief executive, such an arrangement would be a gold mine. His company’s stock is valued at more than $106,000 a share. And last year, it rose 24 percent in value. But in a regulatory filing Thursday, the company said that “neither the profitability of Berkshire Hathaway nor the market value of its stock are to be considered in the compensation of any executive officer.”

headline: As Mobile Phones Grow More Complex, Carriers Insist on Fewer Operating Systems
abstract: Multiple systems have hampered the growth of new services, mobile phone executives say.

headline: Looking for the Chicago Connection in a Satellite Radio Deal
abstract: Should the proposed merger of satellite radio operators XM and Sirius come to pass, who should get the credit? According to the New Yorker’s James Surowiecki, that would be Milton Friedman.

headline: Google Adds a Safeguard on Privacy for Searchers
abstract: Google is taking steps to make anonymous the logs it keeps of all searches that people conduct.

headline: NBC, News Corp. Plan Their Own YouTube
abstract: Several media giants are teaming up to fight YouTube on its own turf. News Corp. and NBC Universal plan to announce as soon as Thursday that they are creating an online video site stocked with TV shows and movies, plus clips that users can modify and share with friends, according to The Los Angeles Times.

headline: Updating Devices for Daylight Saving
abstract: Since the starting and ending dates for daylight time are changing this year, do I need to adjust my computer system clock manually?

headline: Old Programs on a New System
abstract: I’m going to be buying a computer soon. Will my old Windows programs run on the new Vista operating system?

headline: Fortress Mints Billionaires, Just in Time for Forbes
abstract: Hedge fund managers are known for making well-timed trades. The managers at Fortress Investment Group, the first United States hedge fund firm to go public, seem to have a knack for well-timed I.P.O.’s as well. Fortress held its initial public offering the morning on February 9 — which just happens to have been the cutoff date for inclusion in Forbes’ annual list of the world’s billionaires. As a result, five Fortress executives have made the latest list, which Forbes rolled out on Friday, with just a few hours to spare.

headline: Finding Safe Picks in a Downturn
abstract: The sharpest reversals of fortune in the stock market could be experienced in what have been some of the hottest sectors.

headline: Who Will Dial Up a Deal for Palm?
abstract: As Palm works with Morgan Stanley to weigh its options for the future, analysts continue to speculate over who would pick up the struggling maker of Treo cellphones. Yet analysts quoted by MarketWatch on Tuesday tried to douse rumors that Nokia, Palm’s largest competitor, would sweep up the company.

headline: Greenberg’s P.R. Firm Sues for $2 Million
abstract: A public relations company hired who says it was hired to buff up the sullied reputation of Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, is suing Mr. Greenberg’s company, C.V. Starr, for allegedly refusing to pay a $2 million bill.

headline: More Talk of a Time Warner Revamp
abstract: Carl Icahn must be smiling.

headline: New Effort to Tap Technology to Aid the Service Economy
abstract: The creation of the Service Research and Innovation Initiative represents the latest step to promote an emerging field called “service science.”

headline: Google’s Buses Help Its Workers Beat the Rush
abstract: The sheer scale of Google’s new shuttle program for its employees befits the company’s oversize ambitions.

headline: A New Rush to Go Public
abstract: Business 2.0 reports that we are about to witness a new round of technology companies racing to go public.

headline: Dell Reports It Has Found ‘Misconduct’
abstract: Dell said “evidence of misconduct” had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years.

headline: Installing Adobe Reader
abstract: I can’t seem to download Adobe Acrobat so I can print some rebate forms. What can I do?

headline: This Air Sickness Bag Is Brought to You by ...
abstract: Initial worries that advertising would annoy airplane passengers have now been allayed, US Airways and its advertising partner say.

headline: Software by Microsoft Is Nearly Free for the Needy
abstract: Microsoft plans to offer a stripped-down version of Windows, Office and other software for $3 to people in developing nations.

headline: Microsoft, Trying to Avoid a European Fine, Defends Demand for Royalties
abstract: Microsoft filed documents defending its demand to be paid royalties for releasing some software code to competitors.

headline: Microsoft Urges Review of Google-DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Microsoft contends that Google’s $3.1 billion deal to buy DoubleClick would hurt competition in the online advertising market.

headline: Strong Quarter at Microsoft, and an Upbeat ’08 Outlook, Bring Wall St. a Sigh of Relief
abstract: Microsoft’s results suggested that early sales of its new Windows Vista operating system were off to a solid start.

headline: Microsoft Brings Instant Chat to TV Screen, Through Games
abstract: The Windows Live Messenger will be available on the Xbox 360, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television.

headline: Two Phones, One Calendar
abstract: Is there a way for two Treo 600 smartphones to synchronize with a single Microsoft Outlook profile?

headline: PC Games, Once Down, Show Signs of Rebound
abstract: PC video game titles, once the mainstay of video gaming, are showing signs of a comeback.

headline: Big Money in Little Screens
abstract: Google, Microsoft and Yahoo have trained their sights on cellphones as the next great battleground in the Internet search wars.

headline: Moving Day for That Vista Machine
abstract: Transferring files is one thing, but software is another matter altogether.

headline: Closing a Stubborn Folder
abstract: When I turn on my Windows XP computer, the folder C:\windows\system32 opens automatically every time. Why is this and how do I stop it?

headline: A Photo Trove, a Mounting Challenge
abstract: The new chief executive for Corbis is expected to respond to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its sales.

headline: A Misfired Memo Shows Close Tabs on Reporter
abstract: A Wired magazine reporter was accidentally sent a memorandum written by the company’s public relations firm to coach Microsoft executives on how to handle his questions.

headline: Supreme Court Sides With Microsoft in Patent Case
abstract: AT&T had sued Microsoft, alleging that computers running Windows infringed on AT&T’s speech technology. The ruling restricts the reach of patent holders overseas.

headline: Microsoft Urges Review of Google-DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Is Microsoft‘s objection to Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for online advertising company DoubleClick just a case of sour grapes? Microsoft and AT&T, both veteran defendants of epic antitrust battles in the United States and Europe, is urging regulators to consider scuttling Google’s plan to buy DoubleClick.

headline: DoubleClick May Entice Buyers With Ad Exchange
abstract: If Google and Microsoft are circling DoubleClick — a bidding feud that has been reported but never acknowledged by any of the parties — it may be based partly on a new initiative that the online advertising firm announced Wednesday.

headline: DoubleCick Deal Puts Spotlight on Rivals
abstract: Google‘s $3.1 billion acquisition of online advertising firm DoubleClick drove up shares of other Internet ad firms. What was behind the rise? Many investors were betting that Microsoft (which was reportedly also in the running for DoubleClick) and Yahoo would be driven to make deals of their own to keep up with Google.

headline: Web Measurement Firm ComScore to Go Public
abstract: ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions. ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.

headline: The Trouble With Home-Networking
abstract: The Times’s David Pogue illustrates why wireless home-networking remains one of life’s frustrations.

headline: Google Buys an Online Ad Firm for $3.1 Billion
abstract: Google agreed to its largest acquisition Friday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick for almost double what it paid for YouTube last year.

headline: Mexican Midas Edges Out Oracle of Omaha on Forbes List
abstract: Look out Bill Gates, here comes Carlos Slim Helu. The Mexican telecoms mogul has breezed past Warren Buffett and is gaining on the Microsoft co-founder on the list of the world’s richest men, according to Forbes.

headline: China Surges, BlackBerries Fail and Sallie Gets Suitors
abstract: Blackberry users’ thumbs were idle; private equity investors got a thumbs up from Sallie Mae; and a jury turned thumbs down on Joseph P. Nacchio.

headline: Apple Says It Will Delay OS X Release for 4 Months
abstract: Quality issues will delay the release, an uncharacteristic schedule slippage that is particularly embarrassing for Apple.

headline: Intel Seen Using China Forum to Detail Plans on Hand-Helds
abstract: A number of  technology advances will be announced, including an initiative that could give rise to a new class of wireless hand-held computers.

headline: Google Buys DoubleClick for $3.1 Billion
abstract: The sale gives Google access to DoubleClick’s software and its relationships with Web publishers and advertisers.

headline: Profits Up 69% at Google, Exceeding Expectations
abstract: The company’s core search and advertising business continued to outpace that of Microsoft and Yahoo.

headline: Got a Zillion Songs? A Gadget to Help You Take Your Show on the Road
abstract: Harman Kardon’s Drive + Play 2 lets you control a portable music player via a wireless control knob that can be mounted wherever convenient.

headline: Murdoch Is Taking MySpace to China — as a Start-Up
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation is bringing MySpace.com to China, a latecomer that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up.

headline: WPP In Talks for 24/7 Real Media, Report Says
abstract: An Internet ad firm 24/7 Real Media is on the auction block and has already been talking to Martin Sorrell’s WPP Group, the world’s second-largest ad company, among other potential suitors, The New York Post reported.

headline: Consumer Group Cries Foul on Google’s DoubleClick Deal
abstract: A consumer group asked the Federal Trade Commission on Friday to investigate and block Google’s proposed $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick unless the companies improve consumer privacy protections.

headline: Murdoch Is Taking MySpace to China
abstract: The News Corporation signed a deal to license the brand  in the world’s fastest-growing Internet market.

headline: Moviemaking With VCD
abstract: How do I copy short videos taken with a digital camera to a CD-R that can be played on a CD/DVD player?

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: QUARTERLY REPORTS A decline in oil and gas prices is expected to translate into lower profits for the big oil companies. Earnings are scheduled to be reported by BP (Tuesday), ConocoPhillips (Wednesday), Exxon Mobil (Thursday) and Chevron (Friday). Lower oil prices may help the profits of transportation companies, including the airlines JetBlue (Tuesday), UAL (Wednesday) and US Airways (Thursday).

headline: E-Mail Innovator Plans to Enlist in the Wireless Campaign of the Patent Wars
abstract: Freedom Mail will make it possible to view and respond by cellphone to messages sent to almost any e-mail account.

headline: Blogs Blog About Blog Tracker’s Sale Prospects
abstract: Technorati is known for its software that searches and indexes thousands of blogs. So the company is presumably quite aware of the buzz making the rounds on the Net, in which bloggers are speculating that Technorati is positioning itself for a sale. Technorati has denied those rumors, but the denials may only be fanning the flames. After Michael Arrington of TechCrunch (the blog that broke the news that Google might buy YouTube) wrote about the situation, he appended his post with this update quoting Technorati’s chief executive:

headline: Yahoo to Buy Online Ad Company Right Media
abstract: Weeks after Google spent $3.1 billion to buy the Internet advertising company DoubleClick, a rival search giant is reaching into its wallet in a bid to compete. Yahoo has agreed to pay about $680 million to acquire the rest of Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace, in part to bolster its position as a seller and broker of ads outside its own sprawling network of Web sites, The New York Times reported.

headline: The Greater (and the Lesser) Considered at the Ad Summit
abstract: The highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the 2007 management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

headline: DoubleClick to Set Up an Exchange for Buying and Selling Digital Ads
abstract: The exchange will bring Web publishers and ad buyers together on a Web site where they can participate in auctions for ad space.

headline: Google Buys DoubleClick for $3.1 Billion
abstract: Google reached an agreement Friday to acquire DoubleClick, the online advertising company, from two private equity firms for $3.1 billion in cash, the companies announced, an amount that was almost double the $1.65 billion in stock that Google paid for YouTube late last year.

headline: AOL Moving to Increase Revenue It Gets From Search Ads
abstract: AOL plans to introduce a service Monday to sell ads that will appear next to its search results, which are powered by Google’s Internet search engine.

headline: Google Seeks Clearer Path to State Data
abstract: Four states have joined forces with Google to make information from their Web sites more directly accessible through Internet searches.

headline: Yahoo to Buy Ad Company in Bid to Compete With Google
abstract: Yahoo plans to acquire Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace, in part to bolster its position as a seller and broker of ads.

headline: The Dow May Be at Its High, but Its Performance Is Still Lacking
abstract: Only half of the stocks in the Dow are higher than in 2000, while the number of rising stocks in the S.& P. is triple the number of losers.

headline: Run on Wall Street Sends Dow Above 13,000
abstract: The rally has defied skeptics who thought stocks were due for a harder slog as the economy slows.

headline: The Pangs of Two Becoming One
abstract: Google’s $3.1 billion deal for the online advertising firm DoubleClick could put the company at odds with itself.

headline: I.B.M. Profit Is Up, Despite Slow U.S. Sales
abstract: The company’s strategic shift toward higher-margin software and services is making gradual progress.

headline: With A.M.D., Riding Waves of Volatility
abstract: Any change in market conditions would vary the size of Intel’s profit, but for A.M.D. it can mean the difference between a big profit and a big loss.

headline: Apple Zooms Past Rivals, With 88% Profit Growth
abstract: The company surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players.

headline: Custom Icons for Windows Vista
abstract: Is there a way to change folder icons in Windows Vista from something besides those annoying manila folders?

headline: Macintosh and iPod Drive Apple
abstract: Apple surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit.

headline: Chinese Political Prisoner Sues in U.S. Court, Saying Yahoo Helped Identify Dissidents
abstract: The company is accused of abetting the commission of torture by helping Chinese authorities identify political dissidents who were later beaten and imprisoned.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Online Ad Company
abstract: The plan to purchase aQuantive for $6 billion, at an 85 percent premium, comes after acquisitions of other firms by WPP Group, Google and Yahoo.

headline: Microsoft to Release New Version of Halo Video Game on Sept. 25
abstract: The company is hoping that Halo 3 will increase the Xbox 360’s momentum in the gaming market.

headline: Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site
abstract: The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.

headline: Rumors Fly on Microsoft and Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google.

headline: Touch Screen in a Table Is the Latest Wrinkle in Computers
abstract: Microsoft plans to unveil a new computing device called Surface, featuring a 30-inch screen embedded in an acrylic tabletop.

headline: Moving Web-Based Software Offline
abstract: Google will make applications like Gmail and Docs and Spreadsheets available offline, in a move that will challenge Microsoft.

headline: For Jobs and Gates, a Night to Reminisce
abstract: Bill Gates and Steven P. Jobs appeared in public to relive old battles and speculate about the future of digital culture and technology.

headline: Firefox and the Anxiety of Growing Pains
abstract: The people behind Firefox have a dilemma: What happens when an open-source project starts to become successful?

headline: Internet Giants Vie to Snap Up Web Ad Firms
abstract: Microsoft’s $6 billion acquisition of aQuantive signaled its struggle to build an Internet ad business on its own.

headline: Google’s One-Stop Search to Yield Text and Images
abstract: In a new approach, citations from news reports, images and video will be combined in results of a single query.

headline: Windows Upgrade for Smartphones Improves Search and E-Mail Features
abstract: Windows Mobile 6 is now available as a free download for owners of the T-Mobile Dash.

headline: Gates Discusses Software, but Talk of a Yahoo Deal Persists
abstract: Bill Gates spoke to marketers and advertising agencies in Seattle amid rumblings about a deal between Microsoft and Yahoo.

headline: Microsoft in Early Talks With Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo are in talks about a joint venture or some other form of cooperation, according to people briefed on the talks. The discussions are part of a continuing dialogue that the two companies have been holding for more than a year, but are still in preliminary stages, these people say.

headline: Microsoft: Tight-Fisted No More?
abstract: Microsoft had about $28 billion in cash and short-term investment on March 31, an amount the CIA World Factbook tells us is more than twice the gross domestic product of Iceland. But despite its riches, the software giant has shied away from large acquisitions, especially in the past five years or so. That is part of the reason Friday’s $6 billion cash bid for online advertising company aQuantive was so surprising. (The 85 percent premium it agreed to pay was something of a shock as well.)

headline: Microsoft: We Don’t Need Yahoo
abstract: With an agreement to buy aQuantive under its belt, Microsoft is playing down rumors — in the air for at least a year, most recently stoked by the New York Post — that it might try to buy Yahoo. “We have all of the pieces we need to move forward” in the online-advertising business, Yusuf Mehdi, Microsoft’s chief advertising strategist, said Wednesday at a Goldman Sachs  Internet conference in Las Vegas.

headline: Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site
abstract: Microsoft said Wednesday that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by Tribune, Gannett and McClatchy. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.

headline: Much Ado About Microsoft's Surface Computer
abstract: Microsoft's version of the multi-touch computer adds one very cool, though impractical, twist: interaction with other electronics.

headline: Microsoft Is Said to Consider a Bid for 24/7
abstract: Microsoft has emerged as a contender to buy the online advertising firm 24/7 Real Media in an effort to stay competitive with online rivals Google and Yahoo, The New York Post reported Tuesday. Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that Microsoft is considering a bid of about $1 billion, a hefty premium over the $600 million value that analysts have given the firm.

headline: Microsoft Pays Up for Online Advertising Firm aQuantive
abstract: Microsoft said Friday it would buy aQuantive, an online advertising firm, for $66.50 a share in cash. The deal, valued at $6 billion, was easily Microsoft’s largest acquisition ever and the price represented an eye-popping 85 percent premium to aQuantive’s closing price Thursday.

headline: Gates Discusses Software, but Talk of a Yahoo Deal Persists
abstract: Bill Gates, Microsoft‘s chairman, spoke to hundreds of marketers and advertising agencies in Seattle on Tuesday amid rumblings about his company’s struggle to compete against Google in online advertising and about its efforts to court Yahoo for some sort of partnership.

headline: 24/7 Media Confirms Hiring Investment Bank
abstract: The online marketing firm 24/7 Media on Wednesday disclosed that it has hired Lehman Brothers to help it assess “strategic alternatives,” adding credence to rampant speculation that the company is up for sale. The New York Post reported this week that both WPP Group, the London-based advertising and marketing group, and software gaint Microsoft were “leading contenders” to buy 24/7, which has a market capitalization of about $560 million.

headline: Are Online Ad Firms Worth Top Dollar?
abstract: The recent frenzy of deals for online advertising firms — Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick, WPP‘s $649 million purchase of 24/7 Real Media, Microsoft‘s $6 billion move on aQuantive — has some industry observers wondering if a whiff of desperation isn’t in the air.

headline: Dynegy Sells Plant to Gates-Backed Venture
abstract: A joint venture between Cascade Investments, a private equity firm controlled by Microsoft‘s chairman, Bill Gates, and PNM Resources will buy a gas-fired power plant in Texas from Dynegy for $467.5 million.

headline: Before the aQuantive Deal, Lots of Well-Timed Trades
abstract: Whether it was because of sheer luck or an inside tip, options traders made some big bets on aQuantive on Thursday — just in time to cash in on the company’s $6 billion deal to be acquired by Microsoft. Trading in aQuantive’s options has been active for weeks, driven in part by the rampant takeover speculation surrounding many independent Web advertising firms since Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick in mid-April. But according to Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, activity in aQuantive’s call options went through the roof on Thursday, with a volume of 9,363 contracts, or more than five times the average volume on the previous five days.

headline: Are Online Ad Firms Overpriced?
abstract: The debate continues: Are the recent deals involving online-advertising firms — Google–Doubleclick, Microsoft–aQuantive, WPP–24/7 Real Media — signs of a bubble, or wise, strategic, long-term plays?

headline: Yahoo Said to Consider Bid for Britain’s Bebo
abstract: Yahoo is working on a takeover offer for Bebo, the most popular social networking Web site in Britain, and is willing to pay up to $1 billion to seal the deal, according to The Telegraph.

headline: In Fierce Competition, Google Finds Novel Ways to Feed Hiring Machine
abstract: Pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests are meant to create excitement around a company and impress potential recruits as young as college freshmen.

headline: M&A Extends Markets’ Bull Run
