abstract: Corporate takeovers helped spur the Dow Jones industrial average to its 24th record close this year on Friday, even as the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index came within striking distance of its record high. The latest takeover news, including deals involving marquee names like General Electric and Microsoft, signaled that the enormous amount of liquidity that has lubricated global stock markets in recent months is still in good supply. “The M.& A. activity and earnings seem to be holding up better than expected. I think you’re going to see more of this,” Bill Dwyer, chief investment officer at MTB Investment Advisors, told The Associated Press.

headline: To Lure Top Talent, Google Finds Novel Ways to Recruit
abstract: As competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields intensifies, companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo frequently find themselves going after the same candidates, as well as running up against myriad Silicon Valley start-up companies that have been pumped up with venture capital in recent years.

headline: Yahoo Hires Thomas Weisel Co-founder as Finance Chief
abstract: Even as rumors swirl that Yahoo might be heading for some kind of deal with Microsoft, the Internet giant has picked a technology deal maker as its next chief financial officer. Yahoo announced Tuesday that it had hired Blake J. Jorgensen, a co-founder of the technology-focused investment bank Thomas Weisel Partners, as its finance chief. He will succeed Susan L. Decker, who took control of the company’s advertising operations in December amid mounting competition from its archrival Google.

headline: High Court Puts Limits on Patents
abstract: The Supreme Court made it more difficult to get a patent on new products that combine elements of existing inventions.

headline: Disable the Messenger
abstract: I keep getting a message that says “Critical error message — Registry damaged and corrupted.” Is this a virus?

headline: A Media PC That Can Stand Up Next to the Television
abstract: The Shuttle X200M, an update to the X100 media PC, looks great next to the TV.

headline: Sun Plans Version of Java for Web-Linked Cellphones
abstract: Sun Microsystems will revamp its Java software to compete more effectively in the market for Internet-connected mobile phones.

headline: Vornado Goes East and West for a Deal
abstract: Steven Roth’s hopes of establishing a beachhead on the West Coast were dashed earlier this year when he lost the high-stakes contest to acquire Equity Office Properties and its nationwide portfolio of prime office buildings to the Blackstone Group.

headline: Palm to Sell Device That Won’t Fit in the Palm
abstract: The company reversed itself and said that it would begin selling a two-handed laptop-size machine called the Foleo.

headline: Advertising Group WPP Takes 24/7 Real Media
abstract: A week after confirming that it hired an investment bank to explore “strategic alternatives,” 24/7 Real Media has decided that a sale is the way to go. The company, which provides online marketing services, said it agreed to be bought by advertising and marketing firm WPP Group for $11.75 per share in cash, or about $649 million net of cash acquired. The sale of 24/7 is just the latest in a string of deals involving online advertising companies: Google recently bought DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, and Yahoo  paid $680 million for the part of Right Media that it didn’t already own.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: A DAY OFF All banks and stock markets in the United States are closed today in observance of the Memorial Day holiday. They will reopen on Tuesday.

headline: For New M.B.A.’s, Diplomas and Deal Wisdom
abstract: Stephen M. Case has been making a lot of public apologies lately. Less than a year ago, in an interview with TV talk-show host Charlie Rose, the co-founder of America Online conceded that he was “sorry” for advocating the ill-fated 2000 merger of AOL and Time Warner.

headline: Google C.E.O. On Dealmaking Strategy
abstract: Google, which last month announced a deal to buy online ad firm DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, said that while it has become more comfortable doing big acquisitions, it still sees small technology deals as its primary thrust for buying businesses.

headline: Google Deal Said to Bring U.S. Scrutiny
abstract: The F.T.C. has opened an antitrust investigation into Google’s planned $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick.

headline: Scrutiny Aside, Google’s DoubleClick Deal Is Likely to Pass Muster
abstract: There was little doubt that the Federal Trade Commission would thoroughly investigate Google‘s planned purchase of DoubleClick, but, says BusinessWeek, there’s even less doubt that the FTC will eventually sign off on the $3.1 billion deal for the online advertiser.

headline: With New Hire, Yahoo Sends Out Deal Vibe
abstract: By hiring a veteran investment banker, Blake Jorgensen, as its chief financial officer, Yahoo sent out signals that there is deal making in its future, but analysts and industry observers seemed unable to decide what kind.

headline: Out of Chaos, Order. Or So Google Says.
abstract: A strategy announcement by Google is less a shift than a new message — a way for the company to talk about its initiatives in a way shareholders can readily understand.

headline: In Game of Games, Wii Outshoots PlayStation
abstract: The sales gap between the Nintendo Wii and Sony’s competing PlayStation 3 widened during April.

headline: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection
abstract: The online store, to be introduced later this year, will allow people to play music on almost any personal device.

headline: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection
abstract: The online store, to be introduced later this year, will allow people to play music on almost any personal device.

headline: E.U. Probes Google Over Data Retention Policy
abstract: Google has been warned that it may be violating European Union privacy laws by storing search data for up to two years.

headline: Internet Meets Large Screen
abstract: The long-predicted convergence of the Internet and the broadcast world is accelerating, but finding the right hardware to make the leap from the PC to the living room still requires some thought.

headline: To the Glee of South Korean Fans, a Game’s Sequel Is Announced
abstract: Blizzard Entertainment said that it was developing a sequel to its popular computer strategy game, StarCraft.

headline: Microsoft to Alter Windows Vista
abstract: The changes are in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of the operating system is anticompetitive.

headline: Tip of the Week: Undoing Changes in Microsoft Word
abstract: Want to undo a whole bunch of changes in a Microsoft Word document — without having to repeatedly hit Control-Z (Command-Z on the Mac) to back up one change at a time?

headline: Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Dept.
abstract: A company the government once tried to break up has been repeatedly defended by the Bush administration against charges of anticompetitive conduct.

headline: A Keyboard Made for Those in Need of a ‘Kill Aliens’ Command
abstract: The keyboard comes in jet black and has blue L.E.D. backlights that cast an eerie glow through and around the keys.

headline: A Dog or a Cat? New Tests to Fool Automated Spammers
abstract: Several Internet companies, including Microsoft and eBay, are working on new ways to keep spammers from infiltrating their sites.

headline: Sony’s Other Games Division Makes Push in New Direction
abstract: Sony has a long and colorful history of failure on the Internet, but there has been a bright spot.

headline: Competing as Software Goes to Web
abstract: In the battle between Apple and Microsoft, two men are in charge of competing efforts to ensure that the PC’s basic software stays relevant in a Web-centered world.

headline: Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Department
abstract: Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google.

headline: Google Seeks Ruling on Microsoft Oversight
abstract: Google is pressing for an extension to the Justice Department’s oversight of Microsoft‘s business practices, which for the most part is set to expire in November, according to a court filing Monday.

headline: Google v. Microsoft, In and Out of Court
abstract: Google loses a round against Microsoft in court, but takes another blow against one of Microsoft’s most sensitive areas: corporate e-mail.

headline: Google v. Microsoft: What’s the Better Workplace?
abstract: Circulating online, the thoughts of an employee who’s worked at both places, comparing the offices, pay and perks.

headline: NBC Studied Dow Jones Bid With Microsoft
abstract: General Electric‘s NBC unit and Microsoft explored making a joint bid for Dow Jones but decided against it about a week ago, according to news reports Monday.

headline: Microsoft Takes Stake in Chinese Game Maker
abstract: Microsoft will take a stake in Shanghai-listed Changhong Electric and work with the firm to jointly develop entertainment products that can be accessed via the Internet, Changhong said. Changhong Electric said in a statement on Monday that Microsoft would take a 94-million-yuan ($12.3 million) stake in the firm by purchasing 15 million new shares.

headline: Microsoft Picks Up Data Management Firm
abstract: Microsoft said Thursday it had acquired Stratature, a privately held company that specializes in so-called master data management software. Through the acquisition, Microsoft will build master data management tools into its Office System line.

headline: Microsoft and Yahoo Deals to Come Under Scrutiny, Report Says
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission reportedly wants to take a look at a few online advertising acquisitions, not just Google‘s planned deal to acquire DoubleClick.

headline: With Zenter Deal, Google Makes Its Own PowerPoint
abstract: Google has acquired an online slide presentation company, Zenter, filling out its web-based office software portfolio with an application similar to Microsoft‘s popular PowerPoint.

headline: Yahoo Good, Google Better (a Lot Better)
abstract: It’s become a monthly ritual with few surprises. Web audience measuring firms report numbers for Web search traffic in the United States. Yahoo does well. Google does a lot better. Microsoft and others barely hold on, or worse.

headline: G.E., Dow Jones and the MSNBC Factor
abstract: As General Electric casts around for partners in a possible rival bid for Dow Jones, its chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, might want to keep five letters in the back of his mind: MSNBC.

headline: Palm Investor Sees Hand-Held Free-for-All
abstract: The private equity investment in Palm Inc. is a gamble that the history of two companies in the personal computer industry won’t repeat itself.

headline: Apple Releasing a Windows Browser
abstract: A Windows-based Safari Web browser opens a new front in Apple's rivalry with Microsoft.

headline: In Hot Ad Deal Environment, Are Big Agencies the Next Target?
abstract: How far will Google, Microsoft, Yahoo or other Internet powerhouses go in their effort to dominate digital advertising, the fastest-growing part of the marketing business?

headline: New Palm Investor Sees Hand-Held Free-for-All
abstract: The private equity investment in Palm, announced Monday, is just the latest indication of the intense new competition that will increasingly blur the lines between telecommunications, computing and entertainment during the next several years. The stakes are so high that none of the major players in any of those three industries can afford to be left out.

headline: Some Bloggers Blur Some Lines
abstract: The decision by a blog-advertising network to deploy its writers to produce marketing copy for Microsoft and Cisco may have set back the efforts of professional bloggers to gain credibility.

headline: Bancrofts Said to Prepare New Proposal for Murdoch
abstract: The family that controls Dow Jones is preparing to submit a new set of proposals to News Corporation on how to protect The Wall Street Journal’s editorial independence in a potential sale, The Journal reported. Separately, The Times of London, which is owned by News Corporation, reported Tuesday that General Electric is still considering an offer for Dow Jones after talks of a joint bid with Microsoft broke down.

headline: In Praise of Proprietary Elitists
abstract: The prevailing orthodoxy in technology circles is that openness is not only good thing, but a winning strategy. Open innovation, we’re told, is the way of the future. Sharing, not hoarding, is the path to not only virtue but success.

headline: Web Browsing Without Windows
abstract: How do I get the video and animation to work on Web sites when I am not using a computer running Windows or Microsoft’s Internet Explorer browser?

headline: G.E. and Pearson Decide Against Dow Jones Bid
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation remains the sole bidder for the company, owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: They’re Partners. They’re Rivals. They’re Both.
abstract: General Electric‘s NBC Universal with Pearson and Hearst until recently considering partnering for Dow Jones. News Corporation-MySpace-Yahoo. News Corp.-NBC. Universal.

headline: Pearson Is Said to Seek a Partner for a Takeover of Dow Jones
abstract: Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, is exploring a rival takeover offer for Dow Jones and has discussed a joint bid with G.E. and the Hearst Corporation.

headline: Today’s Teens, Today’s Entrepreneurs
abstract: Michael S. Dell sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.

headline: For One Analyst, Facebook Is a Screaming Buy
abstract: The main thing about Facebook, Pali Research analyst Richard Greenfield wants to make clear, is that it is “not just for college students — if you have not signed up or have not used it lately, you should.” And if you are a big media company, he has another piece of advice: Buy the company.

headline: iTunes and Vista, Playing Nice
abstract: If I buy a new PC with Windows Vista, can I move my iTunes music over to it and still have it work reliably?

headline: G.E. and Pearson Explore Bid for Dow Jones
abstract: After making an overture to Microsoft about a joint bid for Dow Jones, the General Electric Company, the parent of NBC, is now exploring that idea with Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, according to reports on Monday. The talks are still preliminary, and Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion offer for Dow Jones represents a “a very high threshold,” The New York Times said. The Wall Street Journal quoted several sources describing the possibility of a deal as a “long shot.”

headline: V.C.’s Have a Crush on IceBreaker
abstract: IceBreaker has landed $7.2 million in new financing, money that the Bellevue, Wash. startup will use to continue marketing its mobile dating service, Crush or Flush. It also plans to use funds to bolster a research and development center in Beijing, where the company employs more than 20 people and is looking to add more.

headline: A Makeover at Ask.com: A New Look and More
abstract: Ask.com will present answers to queries in a three-panel screen that includes standard links but also lists related searches and results from blogs.

headline: Another Management Shake-Up at Revver
abstract: Revver, a video-sharing Web site, said Thursday that its chief executive, Steven Starr, has stepped down in the struggling venture-backed company’s second executive shakeup in the past six months.

headline: Fever Builds for iPhone (Anxiety Too)
abstract: Steven P. Jobs has succeeded in building expectations for what some have called “the God machine.”

headline: Now It’s Spam on Stationery
abstract: Foiled by software that blocks advertisements in images, spammers now have found a new way to pitch their pills and penny stocks: e-mail stationary. b

headline: Addenda
abstract: Accounts.

headline: A Latin American Fortune Is Assembled
abstract:
CARLOS SLIM’S EMPIRE

Forbes magazine recently named the Mexican tycoon Carlos Slim Helú the second-richest man in the world.

headline: Some on Journal Staff Voice Wish That Different Bidder Would Emerge
abstract: A small group of reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal raised an outcry against Rupert Murdoch’s plan to buy Dow Jones.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: DETROIT RETHINKS ITS POSITION American automakers have reversed years of stalwart opposition to any legislation to increase fuel economy standards, and are now willing to accept a modest increase in mileage standards in the hopes of silencing calls for even tougher targets.

headline: Friends Again, Sort of . . .
abstract: The Boston standoff between Google and eBay appears to be over. The result of the confrontation: only minor scrapes and bruises for Google.

headline: Fixing Silent Movies in Windows
abstract: I cannot play a DVD on my computer’s Windows XP operating system. I see the picture, but there is no sound. What is keeping my movies silent?

headline: The Next Technology Buyout Deals?
abstract: Private equity firms, on the hunt for new areas of business as dealmakers crowd up the old ones, have been increasingly looking to the technology sector. With that in mind, analysts at UBS have built a model for looking at hypothetical leveraged buyouts of technology companies and ranking potential targets by how profitable they might be.

headline: Yahoo’s C.E.O. Change Reignites Deal Chatter
abstract: As Yahoo announced late Monday that Terry S. Semel was stepping down as its chief executive, at least two big questions immediately arose: Is the Internet giant in play? And will shareholder activists jump into the game?

headline: Technology Group Seeks to Save Power
abstract: Google and Intel are leading a consortium of companies in an effort to reduce the amount of power wasted by personal computers.

headline: Palm Is Said to Sell Stake to Equity Firm in Revamping
abstract: Palm, the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal on Sunday to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company, The New York Times reported.

headline: Cramer on Murdoch: Patience Will Pay Off
abstract: James Cramer says he knows first-hand how badly Rupert Murdoch wants Dow Jones. Writing this week in New York magazine, Mr. Cramer, the former hedge fund manager who is now host of the “Mad Money” show on CNBC, tells the story of how Mr. Murdoch called him 11 years ago to discuss the notion of a bid for Dow Jones, which publishes The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Listing Top Jobs but Charging Candidates to Seek Them
abstract: A growing number of niche sites devoted to high-end jobs are finding that applicants will shell out a few dollars — or a few hundred — for access to job ads.

headline: Microsoft Offers a Web-Based Strategy
abstract: Executives said they would add Internet services to Microsoft’s desktop applications to respond to the growing threat posed by rivals like Google.

headline: Microsoft’s Profit Rises Despite Xbox Charge
abstract: Microsoft said it eked out a gain in net profit despite taking a $1 billion charge to pay for repairs to its Xbox 360 game consoles.

headline: Microsoft Game Chief Moves to Electronic Arts
abstract: After overseeing the rising fortunes of the Xbox 360 game console, Peter Moore will run the sports division of the leading game publisher.

headline: Microsoft’s Gates Plans Leave Amid Great Change
abstract: Bill Gates, who co-founded Microsoft, still intends to step away next year as planned. But so far, Mr. Gates, the company’s chairman, is showing no sign of fading away.

headline: Microsoft Plays Up Family Appeal of Xbox
abstract: Microsoft announced a deal to distribute films from the Walt Disney Company on Microsoft’s Xbox Live Internet service and outlined a broader array of games.

headline: Microsoft to Spend $1.15 Billion for Xbox Repairs
abstract: Microsoft on Thursday cited “an unacceptable number of repairs” to its Xbox 360 for the charge, and announced an extended warranty for the video game console.

headline: With Tools on Web, Amateurs Reshape Mapmaking
abstract: New tools are allowing people with minimal skills to do what only professional mapmakers were able to do before.

headline: F.B.I. and Chinese Seize $500 Million of Counterfeit Software
abstract: The arrests and seizures came at a time American politicians and executives are pressing China to take strong measures to curb software piracy.

headline: In Battle of Consoles, Nintendo Gains Allies
abstract: Momentum is building for the Wii from Nintendo among its crucial allies: game developers and publishers.

headline: Google Buys a Manager of E-Mail
abstract: Taking further aim at one of Microsoft’s core franchises, Google said that it would acquire Postini for $625 million in cash.

headline: Sony Cuts PlayStation 3 Prices as Many Xboxes Fail
abstract: Sony will lower the price of the PlayStation 3 by $100, hoping to take advantage of rivals’ missteps.

headline: Today in Business
abstract: ALCOA QUESTIONED ON ALCAN BID Alcoa said that United States antitrust regulators had asked for more information about its $27.8 billion hostile takeover bid for a Canadian competitor, Alcan. Alcoa said it would comply with the request from the Department of Justice “as soon as possible,” without saying what details it would provide. Alcoa reiterated that it intended to complete the takeover this year. The offer expires Tuesday and can be extended. Alcan has urged shareholders to reject Alcoa’s bid, saying it is too low. (BLOOMBERG NEWS).

headline: Xbox Offers a Forum to Reach Gamers Where They Live
abstract: Since November, Xbox LIVE Marketplace has offered video-on-demand downloads of movies and download-to-own episodes of television shows.

headline: Microsoft’s Ad Exchange
abstract: Microsoft buys AdECN, an ad exchange to give a boost to its online advertising business.

headline: Google v. Microsoft (again)
abstract: Google and Microsoft downplay the competition between each other — at least when it comes to software applications.

headline: Digg Digs Microsoft; Buries Google
abstract: Microsoft inks advertising deal with Digg, the popular user-controlled news site displacing Google.

headline: Microsoft Game Chief Moves to Electronic Arts
abstract: After overseeing the rising fortunes of the Xbox 360 game console, Peter Moore will run the sports division of the leading game publisher.

headline: Microsoft Offers Privacy Options for Its Search Engine
abstract: There is nothing like a little regulatory scrutiny to get Internet companies talking about privacy, even if some of their words ring somewhat hollow.

headline: Quick Bits: Microsoft Works Free, IAC Disappoints
abstract: Also in the news today: an iTunes milestone, an open-source start-up, and a Web company’s acquisition.

headline: Are Consoles Getting Cheaper, or Is the Talk Just Cheap?
abstract: Is the XBox 360 dropping in price?

headline: Yahoo Completes Right Media Buy
abstract: Yahoo took control of advertising exchange Right Media on Thursday for about $700 million, The Associated Press reported. The acquisition gives Yahoo a head start on rivals Google and Microsoft in the race to build more powerful marketing vehicles.

headline: Web and Search Numbers
abstract: Microsoft reverses its slide in search share by offering a contest. The second notable development in the Web measuring front is an announcement by Nielsen/NetRatings that it will put more emphasis on reporting the time users spend on each page, rather than counting page views

headline: The Most Privacy-Friendly Search Engine on the Web Is…
abstract: Microsoft and other major Internet companies are changing their privacy policies in the face of regulatory scrutiny.

headline: E3: Watching Movies on Your Game Box
abstract: At E3, the video game conference, Microsoft and Sony both talk up the use of their game boxes to download movies from the Internet.

headline: Quick Bits: Monday Morning Tech News
abstract: Quick Bits: The day’s news about the F.C.C., Microsoft, Monster, Verizon, Adobe, NowPublic.

headline: Business Intelligence Software Grows Up
abstract: A new report from IDC shows Microsoft and Oracle giving new competition to the leaders in this rapidly growing market.

headline: Quick Bits:  A News Roundup
abstract: The morning headlines, with news about Microsoft, Yahoo, Twitter, Comcast, the BBC, and HBO.

headline: Mircosoft Buys Ad Exchange AdECN
abstract: On the heels of its aQuantive purchase, Microsoft on Thursday announced it has bought AdECN, a company that is a technology platform for buying and selling display advertising. AdECN provides an ad exchange, like electronic stock trading markets, that allows publishers and advertisers to broker the sale of display advertising.

headline: Keeping Up With the Googlers
abstract: Microsoft buys two data centers in California in its race to keep up with Google’s processing might.

headline: Nokia Gobbles Up Twango
abstract: Twango, a media-sharing Web site founded by five former Microsoft employees, announced Monday that it had been acquired by the cell phone giant Nokia. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: With Hefty Fine, EU Sends Telefonica a Strong Message
abstract: European Union regulators on Wednesday fined Telefónica, the Spanish telecommunications company, 151.85 million euros ($207.17 million), saying it had unfairly squeezed rivals by setting wholesale Internet access prices too high. The Associated Press reported that the hefty fine, which is second only in Europe to the 497 million euros fine against Microsoft, was a reflection of Telefónica’s knowledge that it was breaking EU antitrust rules.

headline: E3: Nintendo’s Massive Product Demo
abstract: At the E3 game conference in Santa Monica this week, Nintendo continued to be in unaccustomed role of 800 pound gorilla. The popularity of its Wii platform prompted a price cut by Sony. And Microsoft was reeling after admitting that there were defects in many of its Xbox 360 systems.

headline: Online Advertising: What’s Left to Buy?
abstract: Exponential is a prime candidate, but the chief executive says, “no thank you.”

headline: An Ultramobile PC, All of Six Inches Long, Is an Importer’s Latest Find
abstract: The Raon Everun ultramobile PC, which starts at $799, has a 4.8-inch touchscreen and a full mini-keyboard with touchpad.

headline: Nokia, Without Fanfare, Introduces a Superphone Without Contract Obstacles
abstract: What makes Nokia’s N76 smartphone has a powerful processor and an operating system that lets it run a number of programs including one that reads Microsoft Office files.

headline: Standing Ground in a Dispute With Apple Over Music
abstract: The Universal Music Group of Vivendi told Apple that it would not renew its annual contract to sell music through iTunes, executives briefed on the matter said.

headline: A Desktop PC That’s Short on Bells and Whistles, but Long on Savings
abstract: The Impact GC3502 computer from Everex, $298, consumes less power than the average desktop computer, potentially saving money on the monthly electric bill as well.

headline: Congress to Examine Google-DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Google executives are expected to be called to testify before House and Senate subcommittees about the company’s planned $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick, a deal that is already facing close scrutiny from federal antitrust regulators.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Gunning for Licensing Rights to Local Search
abstract: The stock surges for Local.com because it was granted two patents related to local searches and free, ad-supported 411 services. It’s potentially a huge business that companies like Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and others are fighting to dominate.

headline: Thin-Client Boom, Finally?
abstract: Inexpensive terminal-style machines are back because the user experience is better.

headline: VMware Loads Up and Intel Helps
abstract: VMware, the hot software company owned by EMC, filed for an initial public offering today. Intel agreed to buy a 2.5 percent stake in the company, which has raised the ire of Microsoft, long an Intel ally.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: COMPANY REPORTS Earnings season gets into full swing, particularly for technology, financial and drug companies. Reports will come from Charles Schwab and Mattel (Monday); Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, Novartis, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Altria, AMR, Delta Air Lines, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Pfizer, Southwest Airlines and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Bank of America, Bank of New York Mellon, Continental Airlines, Dow Jones, First Data, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Motorola and Wyeth (Thursday); and Boston Scientific, Caterpillar and Citigroup (Friday).

headline: IGA Worldwide Grabs $25 Million
abstract: IGA Worldwide netted $25 million in Series B fuding in a round led by KTB Ventures and Peacock Equity, a joint venture between General Electric Media, Communications and Entertainment and NBC Universal.

headline: Hunting for Targets in Business Intelligence
abstract: Business Objects and Cognos have already bought companies that offer business intelligence software through the software-as-a-service model. Business Objects picked up Nsite Software for $4 million in November, according to regulatory filings. Cognos paid $10.5 million Celequest a few months later, its filings show.

headline: Congress to Examine Google-DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Google executives are expected to testify about their planned $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick, a deal facing scrutiny from federal antitrust regulators.

headline: AOL May Buy Online Advertiser Tacoma, Report Says
abstract: AOL is planning to bulk up its ad offerings with a deal for Tacoda, an online ad firm that uses behavioral targeting to track Web users’ habits, The New York Post reported. The deal, which could be announced as early as Tuesday, will see AOL pay between $200 million and $300 million.

headline: Jerry Yang’s Ecosystem: A Fertile Climate for Buzzwords
abstract: Jerry Yang promised to “win” in his first conference call with investors Tuesday. But he didn’t say what game he thinks Yahoo is playing.

headline: When a Mouse Leaves the Ground, Is It a New Animal?
abstract: The Logitech MX Air can be wielded in the air and become a gyroscopic pointer with just a flick of your wrist.

headline: Facebook Makes First Buy
abstract: Rumors may still be swirling over a takeover of Facebook, but the social network itself has struck a deal — for another company. In its first acquisition since its founding three years ago, the Internet’s second most popular social networking site has purchased Parakey, a start-up which had been trying to bridge the gap between information hosted on the Web and data stored on computer hard drives.

headline: Microsoft Settles a Dispute Over a Feature in Its Browser
abstract: Microsoft said Thursday that it had settled an eight-year patent dispute relating to a feature that allows embedded links in its browser that resulted in a $521 million jury verdict against it.

headline: A Resource Center Even a Microsoft Hater Can Love
abstract: Microsoft has compiled an extensive resource center for small businesses, with topics like customer service and human resources.

headline: Google and Microsoft Look to Change Health Care
abstract: Two candidates for Web supremacy are working up their plans to improve the nation’s health care.

headline: European Legal Circles Await Ruling by Top Appeals Court on Microsoft
abstract: Europe’s top appeals court will announce its decision Sept. 17 on Microsoft’s appeal of Europe’s largest antitrust case ever.

headline: $1.5 Billion Verdict Against Microsoft Is Set Aside
abstract: A federal district court judge delivered a major setback to Alcatel-Lucent by setting aside a jury’s judgment against Microsoft in a patent infringement lawsuit over digital music technology.

headline: Ad Growth for AOL Called Vital to a Remake
abstract: A precipitous slowdown in advertising growth has raised new questions about AOL’s transformation plans.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares in the software company VMware surged 76 percent, as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft.

headline: Xbox 360 Out of Order? For Loyalists, No Worries
abstract: Owners of the Microsoft Xbox 360 have watched their machines break down. But the game Halo 3 could redeem the company going into the holiday selling season.

headline: Take-Two Delays Grand Theft Auto IV
abstract: The company said that the new version of the game wouldn’t be released until the second quarter of 2008, a move likely to have a widespread impact on the video game industry.

headline: Tough Delay for Big Game by Take-Two
abstract: The video game maker said it would delay the release of Grand Theft Auto IV until the second quarter of 2008, likely impacting the entire industry.

headline: Keyboard for Xbox Speeds Typing
abstract: The Chatpad for Microsoft’s Xbox attaches to the underside of the 360’s controller without interfering with the controller’s comfortable feel in the hands.

headline: Content Makers Are Accused of Exaggerating Copyright
abstract: An association of companies, including Google and Microsoft, allege that overstated copyright warnings may intimidate consumers from making legal use of copyrighted material.

headline: Microsoft Buys Parlano
abstract: Microsoft announced on Wednesday plans to acquire Parlano, a developer of group chat applications for large corporate customers. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Will Microsoft Elbow in on XenSource Deal?
abstract: As the dust settles on an active week in virtualization software, some observers speculated that Microsoft could attempt to top Citrix Systems’ $500 million bid for virtualization specialist XenSource.

headline: Sony v. Microsoft (With Helmets)
abstract: Some games are performing better on the Xbox 360 than on the PlayStation 3. Are developers having trouble mastering the PS3’s quirks?

headline: Google Goes After Microsoft Again
abstract: With an alliance with Sun Microsystems , Google ups the ante in its efforts to offer a competitor to Microsoft Office.

headline: Changing Technology Politics: Cisco-Microsoft
abstract: Cisco and Microsoft join hands in peace and harmony, sort of.

headline: Sony v. Microsoft (With Helmets): The Sequel
abstract: Another explanation for the slow pace of video game releases for the Sony PlayStation 3.

headline: Microsoft’s Ballmer Dodges Yahoo Deal Talk
abstract: Try as he might, not even veteran interviewer Charlie Rose could get Microsoft‘s chairman and chief executive, Steve Ballmer to disclose whether the company continues to mull an acquisition of Yahoo.

headline: After Microsoft, Hunting the Next Big Thing
abstract: Would-be inventors, take note: Nathan Myhrvold, a former chief technology officer at Microsoft, is behind a fund that has raised $355 million in what seems to be an effort to back new technologies in their infancy. Mr. Myhrvold knows a thing or two about getting in early: He was part of Microsoft’s original brain trust and once led its research arm.

headline: Skype: Microsoft Update Took Us Down
abstract: Skype explains that its service went down for two days last week after a routine Microsoft patch forced masses of users to restart their computers at the same time.

headline: Mircosoft Closes $6 Billion for aQuantive
abstract: Microsoft has completed the largest purchase in its history, sealing its $6 billion takeover of the Internet advertising firm aQuantive.

headline: Cracking Open a Spreadsheet
abstract: My desktop computer runs Microsoft Windows XP Home Edition — which includes Microsoft Works Spreadsheet — but I cannot open Excel spreadsheets. How can I open them?

headline: As the Market Wobbles, VMware Is Bullish on Its Offering This Week
abstract: EMC plans to raise $1.1 billion this week in an offering for its VMware unit. Analysts say VMware’s technology is wanted by big corporations, ahead of competitors, and trouble for Microsoft.

headline: Sony Defeats Truman
abstract: A prediction that Sony might beat Microsoft in game console sales doesn’t quite pan out. The Nintendo Wii stays on top, of course.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Quick Bits: AT&T Sorry About Censorship, Fraudsters Invade Second Life
abstract: In the news today: Google and Microsoft battle with online storage, Universal Music tries to assert control, Comcast offers free Web video, and more.

headline: A Prognosticator Misses the Mark
abstract: Sony may be a consumer electronics giant, but its public relations folks aren’t so powerful when it comes to prognostication.

headline: Quick Bits: Better Late Than Never
abstract: With news on Microsoft, Vizio and Apple.

headline: Whispers From Sony About a July Surprise
abstract: Sony indicates that the latest figures for video game console sales, due out Thursday, could bring it some good news about its PlayStation 3.

headline: Why Can’t We Compute in the Cloud?
abstract: Cloud computing is not some fluffy idea.

headline: CIRCUITS: A Laptop That Lets Students Take Notes Two Ways
abstract: Parents and students seeking a back-to-school computer may want to consider a tablet PC. These convertible devices, which allow you to switch from keyboard to pen input, are ideal for note-taking.

headline: Quick Bits: Dell Tries Zing, Steve Case Sells Lime, Palm Hears Silence
abstract: Hot stories today from Microsoft, Apple, Palm, Buy.com, Dell and more.

headline: Quick Bits: Cheap Computers in China; Google Gives and Takes Away
abstract: Hot stories today involving the usual suspects: Yahoo, Google, Microsoft, Amazon.com, Answers.com and the Senate.

headline: Coming Soon: Web Video in High Definition
abstract: Adobe updates its popular Flash video player to support high-definition video.

headline: It Was Sony in the Dining Room With a Candlestick
abstract: With Grand Theft Auto IV delay, conspiracy theories abound. Maybe its publisher, Take-Two Interactive, is afraid of Microsoft’s Halo 3. Or maybe it is the flaws of Sony’s PS3.

headline: Tip of the Week: Open-Source Computer Programs
abstract: If you’re on a budget and not afraid of working without telephone support, consider open-source software.

headline: Ask.com on the Upswing
abstract: Searchers are more satisfied with Ask.

headline: Allen to Sell DreamWorks Stake
abstract: The billionaire Paul Allen is selling the majority of his stake in DreamWorks Animation SKG and stepping down from the board of the animation company he helped bankroll in its infancy.

headline: Decision on Google Deal May Shape Web
abstract: The behind-the-scenes battle over federal approval of Google‘s proposed $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick could shape the Internet’s future, The Los Angeles Times wrote. At stake is control of the growing online advertising market, estimated at $21.7 billion this year.

headline: In Google Earth, a Service for Scanning the Heavens
abstract: After turning millions of Internet users into virtual explorers of the world, the Internet search giant is now hoping to turn many of them into virtual stargazers.

headline: ComScore Counts Ads and Plans to Count TV Viewers
abstract: ComScore is going to measure how many ads each Web site displays. And it is hoping to get into the TV ratings business too.

headline: Quick Bits: Hasta La Vista, Vista?
abstract: This is going to have to be really quick today. If you are stuck in an elevator today with some techie, you can probably fake it with this:

headline: Big Holder Considers Buyout of Charter
abstract: The billionaire Paul G. Allen may try to buy or recapitalize Charter Communications, the cable company he controls, according to a regulatory filing yesterday.

headline: MTV, RealNetworks to Mount Challenge Against iTunes
abstract: MTV Networks said it would fold its floundering digital music service into a venture with RealNetworks, owner of the Rhapsody music subscription service.

headline: Why Can’t We Compute in the Cloud? Part 2
abstract: How a hard drive crash provoked thoughts of cloud computing.

headline: Two Monitors, One PC
abstract: Is there a way to connect two monitors to a Windows XP computer so I can keep my e-mail window up in one and do the rest of my work on the other?

headline: Quick Bits: Power Marriage Edition
abstract: Ad Networks are Hot. Facebook is hot. So Facebook Ad Networks are boiling hot. VideoEgg is starting one. After all, online video is so last year. [TechCrunch]

headline: Mash Up the Corporation
abstract: Serena Software plans to let people outside a company’s IT department build applications themselves, taking a bottom-up approach.

headline: Allen Considers Charter Buyout
abstract: The billionaire Paul G. Allen may try to buy or recapitalize Charter Communications, the cable company he controls, according to a regulatory filing Wednesday.

headline: Halo 3 Arrives, Rewarding Gamers, and Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft hopes that the new version of Halo, which is exclusive to the Xbox 360, will persuade more consumers to choose its game machine over others.

headline: Microsoft Takes Aim at Google’s Ad Supremacy
abstract: Microsoft is taking solid aim at a business that is arguably outside its core competence: advertising.

headline: Microsoft Ruling May Bode Ill for Other Companies
abstract: Experts said a European antitrust ruling might signal problems for companies like Apple, Intel and Qualcomm.

headline: As Europe Debated, Microsoft Took Market Share
abstract: Top lawyers for Microsoft and the European Commission are to learn whether the company has persuaded the court to overturn a record $690 million fine and antitrust ruling.

headline: European Court Rejects Microsoft Antitrust Appeal
abstract: Europe’s second-highest court upheld today a 2004 antitrust ruling that found the software company had abused its dominance in operating systems.

headline: I.B.M. to Offer Office Software Free in Challenge to Microsoft’s Line
abstract: The company plans to announce the creation of I.B.M. Lotus Symphony, free programs for word processing, spreadsheets and presentations.

headline: Microsoft Is Said to Consider a Stake in Facebook
abstract: The company is considering an investment of between $300 million and $500 million for less than 5 percent of Facebook.

headline: Panel Rejects Microsoft’s Open Format
abstract: A panel of software experts unexpectedly rebuffed Microsoft’s bid to have its open document format, Office Open XML, recognized as an international standard.

headline: Microsoft Is Rebuffed by Standards Body
abstract: The company’s Office Open XML document fails to meet two criteria for a standards designation.

headline: Microsoft Favored to Win Open Document Vote
abstract: Amid intense lobbying, Microsoft is expected to squeak out a victory this week to have its open document format, Office Open XML, recognized as an international standard.

headline: Software via the Internet: Microsoft in ‘Cloud’ Computing
abstract: The company plans to make available free software that connects its Windows operating system to software services delivered on the Internet.

headline: New-Look Search Sites Aim to Close Google Gap
abstract: Microsoft is launching a new look for some of its Live Search results in an attempt to win more of the search business from Google.

headline: Halo 3 Mimics Halo 2, With Some Improved Graphics
abstract: Quick action, varied weaponry and lots of enemies. Sound familiar?

headline: Politely Refusing Word’s Help
abstract: When I am making lists in Microsoft Word, the program automatically capitalizes the first letter of each word when I press the return key. How can I make it stop doing this?

headline: Whiting Out the Ads, but at What Cost?
abstract: A software program that blocks ads is a two-edged sword: It stops annoyances for consumers, but it threatens to break down the business model that helps pay for Web content.

headline: Microsoft Loses European Appeal
abstract: In a stinging rebuke to the world’s largest software maker, the second-highest European court rejected Monday a request by Microsoft to overturn a 2004 European Commission antitrust ruling that the company had abused its dominance in computer operating systems.

headline: Europe’s Latest Blow to Microsoft
abstract: The rejection of Microsoft’s appeal of its antitrust case in Europe means the company will face restrictions when it seeks to add new features to Windows. It will have a harder time keeping secrets too.

headline: Microsoft Video Crossing Platforms
abstract: Microsoft is expected to announce a new Internet T. system that works on televisions and computers at the Digital Life Conference today.

headline: M.I.A.: ‘Veterans of the War Against Microsoft’
abstract: Pondering the meaning of a mysterious sign in Microsoft’s New York offices.

headline: Microsoft Said to Consider a Stake in Facebook
abstract: Some people laughed at Mark E. Zuckerberg when he reportedly turned down a $900 million offer last year for Facebook, the social networking Web site he founded three and a half years ago.

headline: Yahoo-Microsoft Chatter Rises Again
abstract: School kids aren’t the only ones returning from vacation. Dog-eared speculation about a potential deal between Yahoo and Microsoft is back as well.

headline: Yahoo-Microsoft Chatter Rises Again
abstract: An analyst’s report has given new life to the speculation about an acquisition of Yahoo by Microsoft.

headline: Microsoft Said to Wage Behind-the-Scenes War on Google Deal
abstract: Microsoft executives and a public-relations firm retained by the software giant are waging a quiet campaign to persuade Internet companies, advertisers and regulators to oppose Google‘s planned $3.1 billion acquisition of online advertising specialist DoubleClick, according to press reports.

headline: History Lesson: A Facebook Stake May Be Worth Little to Microsoft
abstract: Facebook would be lucky to take $500 million from Microsoft for a 5 percent stake. But Microsoft’s history of cable investments may dissuade it from such a deal.

headline: Zuckerberg Sightings Fuel Deal Speculation
abstract: Industry watchers are so hyped-up over the news that Microsoft may invest in Facebook that it has led to Gawker-Stalker-like sighting reports.

headline: Senators Scrutinize Google’s DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Microsoft is fiercely opposed to Google‘s proposed $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising firm DoubleClick. But the transaction drew no outright opposition from United States senators at a hearing Thursday, which focused on the deal’s potential threats to competition and consumer privacy.

headline: Image and Reality in the Search Wars
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo have improved their search engines. But it will take both technology and marketing to convince Google users to switch.

headline: Micrsoft’s Ballmer Gets $1.3 Million Pay Package
abstract: Microsoft‘s chief executive, Steve Ballmer, received a pay package valued at about $1.3 million for fiscal 2007, a year in which profit at the world’s largest software maker topped $14 billion, according to documents filed Friday.

headline: VMware Marches onto the Hardware
abstract: Hewlett-Packard, Dell, IBM and others will bake VMware’s software onto the the motherboards of their server computers, striking another blow against Microsoft.

headline: New Push Into China by N.B.A.
abstract: In a move certain to highlight the growing importance of China to both the National Basketball Association and the sport, the N.B.A. plans to announce Wednesday the formation of a Chinese subsidiary.

headline: Bebo Adds Yahoo as a Friend
abstract: Bebo, the British social network, chose Yahoo to sell advertising in the United Kingdom and Ireland. It’s a midsized deal that Yahoo can afford.

headline: Google to Sell Web-Page Ads Visible on Mobile Phones
abstract: The company said that its new product would establish a cellphone advertising network in which Google would match ads with the content of mobile Web pages.

headline: Casual Fans Are Driving Growth of Video Games
abstract: The $13 billion video game industry is counting on new customers this Christmas, as gaming growth is coming largely from outside traditional demographics.

headline: Google’s Washington Hazing for Its DoubleClick Deal
abstract: A Senate panel will look at Google’s proposed acquisition of DoubleClick on Thursday. After a lot of discussion about privacy, the consensus seems to be that the deal will be approved this fall.

headline: Yahoo Buying Zimbra, an E-Mail Service for Businesses
abstract: The deal, for $350 million in cash and stock, is the second sizable acquisition Yahoo has announced this month.

headline: Stalking the Next Virtualization Deal
abstract: VMware‘s spectacular I.P.O. and the acquisition of XenSource have only increased the already intense interest in virtualization software.

headline: Apple Reactions: The Future of Wireless Audio and Video
abstract: The iPhone Touch may represent the future of media use: audio and video that can be played both from local storage and from a vast server with everything.

headline: Will Facebook Go Back to the V.C. Well?
abstract: An average of 200,000 new users sign up for Facebook each day, according to the company’s own statistics. So it should not be surprising that social-networking site is attracting a crowd of would-be investors as well.

headline: MySpace and the Facebook Factor
abstract: The price tag for Facebook, the second-largest social-networking site on the Web, just keeps rising. But what does that mean for MySpace, which is the No. 1?

headline: V.C.’s Leave $10 Million Message on Snapvine
abstract: Snapvine, a service that allows users to add and receive voice messages directly on their MySpace pages, has been growing like a weed since it started last summer, with more than 5 million installations on MySpace, Facebook, Bebo and other sites.

headline: SCO, a Software Maker, Seeks Bankruptcy
abstract: The SCO Group, the software maker that sued International Business Machines for copyright infringement, filed for bankruptcy Friday, 10 days after conceding that much of the case should be dropped.

headline: House Passes Bill to Curb Suits by Patent Owners
abstract: The legislation, supported by technology and financial services companies, would make patents harder to obtain and easier to challenge.

headline: Sir Howard’s Download Mess
abstract: Sony’s zigzag approach to online video shows that Howard Stringer has yet to take control of the sprawling conglomerate.

headline: Yahoo Will Sell Ads for British Site
abstract: Yahoo has forged an advertising partnership with Bebo, owner of the most popular social Web site in Britain.

headline: AOL Moving Headquarters to New York
abstract: AOL will move its headquarters from Dulles, Va., next spring as tries to retool itself as an advertising company that competes with the likes of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft.

headline: Yahoo to Buy Business E-Mail Service
abstract: Yahoo said Monday that it was buying Zimbra, a start-up that provides Web-based e-mail to businesses and institutions, as it seeks to extend the reach of its popular e-mail service and better compete with Google.

headline: Stop Completing My Thoughts
abstract: When I address an e-mail to “Mary,” my program lists all the Marys to whom I have ever sent messages. Is there a way to eliminate the name of a person I no longer wish to see on this list?

headline: SCO, a Software Maker, Is Seeking Bankruptcy
abstract: The SCO Group, the software maker that sued I.B.M. for copyright infringement, filed for bankruptcy yesterday, 10 days after conceding that much of the case should be dropped.

headline: Moving Downtown: AOL Seeks New Image
abstract: AOL will move its headquarters from Dulles, Va., next spring as it tries to retool itself as an advertising company that competes with the likes of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft.

headline: The World According to VMware
abstract: One month after staging one of this year’s most successful initial public offerings, VMware is throwing itself a party.

headline: Microsoft Buys Stake in Facebook
abstract: The investment ends two months of jockeying among Microsoft, Google and Yahoo for the right to invest in and forge close ties with the fast-growing social networking Web site.

headline: Microsoft Is Yielding in European Antitrust Fight
abstract: European regulators hailed the deal as a breakthrough that should create more competition, especially for server software that powers corporate data centers and the Internet.

headline: Microsoft Earnings Send Stock Soaring
abstract: Microsoft reported surprising strong quarterly sales and profit growth, well ahead of Wall Street’s expectations, which sent its stock up 12 percent in after-hours trading.

headline: Microsoft Concedes in European Antitrust Case
abstract: In a move regulators hailed as a breakthrough for freer competition, the software giant will share technical information with its rivals on terms it had resisted.

headline: Microsoft to Pay $240 Million for Stake in Facebook
abstract: Microsoft prevailed in a high-profile technology industry battle with Google and Yahoo to invest in the social networking upstart.

headline: Federal Court Extends Oversight of Microsoft Until January
abstract: A federal court’s oversight of Microsoft has been extended through January to give a judge time to consider a motion to extend that oversight for another five years.

headline: Microsoft Reports Strong Gain on Sales of PC and Server Software
abstract: Microsoft reported surprisingly strong quarterly profits and sales growth in its core software products, sending its stock up 12 percent in after-hours trading.

headline: Halo Games Maker to Be Independent of Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft said Friday that it would give up its controlling stake in Bungie Software, returning the company to independent ownership.

headline: Microsoft Offers System to Track Health Records
abstract: Microsoft’s long-anticipated drive into the consumer health care market will offer free personal health records that can be managed on the Web.

headline: Microsoft to Increase Ad Business
abstract: Steve Ballmer, the company’s chief executive, said Tuesday that advertising would become 25 percent of Microsoft’s business within a few years.

headline: Microsoft Rolls Out Personal Health Records
abstract: Microsoft is starting its drive into the consumer health care market by offering free health records on the Web.

headline: Microsoft Updates Its iPod Competitor
abstract: Microsoft has revamped its slow-selling Zune digital music players and created a MySpace-style social-networking site in its drive to compete with Apple.

headline: Storing Files on the Internet, Microsoft Style
abstract: Microsoft is moving to follow an industry trend led by Google by offering more software delivered over the Internet as a service.

headline: Libraries Shun Deals to Place Books on Web
abstract: Several major research libraries have rebuffed offers from Google and Microsoft to scan their books, instead signing on with a nonprofit effort.

headline: As for Music, Gates’s Taste May Not Be Adventurous but His Strategies Are
abstract: In an interview, Bill Gates expressed surprise that the music industry had failed to turn digital music into a big moneymaker.

headline: In Facebook, Investing in a Theory
abstract: Thousands of software developers are creating features for Facebook, the fast-growing social network, many hoping to strike it rich alongside Facebook’s own employees.

headline: Microsoft Catches Jellyfish.com
abstract: Microsoft, still bulking up to pry more of the online advertising market from Google, has acquired a Web site called Jellyfish.com that has struck unconventional ad deals with big retailers such as Target and Best Buy.

headline: Microsoft Sings a New Zune
abstract: It’s hard to imagine anyone reading about the latest Zune models from Microsoft and putting them at the top of their Christmas wish list.

headline: Microsoft to Target Small Deals
abstract: Microsoft Chief Executive Steve Ballmer said on Thursday the company aims to pursue an independent path, focusing on up to 20 smaller acquisitions of $50 million to $1 billion each annually rather than mega-deals.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Global Care
abstract: Microsoft is giving a booster shot to its Health Solutions Group, announcing on Monday plans to acquire a clinical workflow software developer, Global Care Solutions.

headline: Microsoft’s $30 Billion Vista Bump
abstract: Better-than-expected earnings, mainly from strong sales of Windows Vista, caused Microsoft shares to surge as much as 12 percent after hours, reaching a six-year high.

headline: Microsoft to Spin Off ‘Halo’ Creator Bungie
abstract: Microsoft plans to spin off Bungie Studios, creator of the blockbuster “Halo” video game trilogy, but said Friday it would maintain close ties with the company and retain a minority stake in it.

headline: Microsoft Wins One in the War Against Google
abstract: Microsoft said it would invest $240 million in Facebook. The money will help Facebook challenge Google and by extension help Microsoft.

headline: Microsoft to Pay $240 Million for Facebook Stake
abstract: Microsoft has won a high-profile technology industry battle with Google and Yahoo to invest in the social networking upstart Facebook.

headline: Microsoft Chief Ices Hot Facebook Chatter
abstract: Microsoft‘s chief executive, Steve Ballmer, played down reports that the software maker might buy a stake in the social-networking site Facebook. “We are so delighted to be the advertising sales partner for Facebook,” Mr. Ballmer told Bloomberg News at an advertising event in Paris on Tuesday. “Everything else is just press, idle speculation.”

headline: Microsoft Launches Support Program for British Start-Ups
abstract: Microsoft is lending a helping hand to British companies with “high potential” with a new program to support start-ups.

headline: Facebook’s Minority Report
abstract: Facebook is about to pick between offers from Google and Microsoft to buy a small share in the company at a huge value. This is great for Facebook, but for the potential investors, it is somewhere between irrelevant and insane.

headline: Bill Gates Presents the One (Really Big) Ringy Dingy
abstract: On Tuesday, Bill Gates will introduce new software to integrate communications by voice, video and instant messaging.

headline: In Facebook Race, Google Said to Be Hiking Price
abstract: Microsoft and Google are each vying to take a stake of between 5 percent and 10 percent in Facebook, with a deal expected to be announced in the next 24 to 48 hours, according to The New York Post.

headline: The Halo Over Xbox
abstract: Halo 3 sold 3.3 million copies in its first 12 days on the market, helping Microsoft’s Xbox 360 edge out the Nintendo Wii as the top-selling game console in September.

headline: The Greed of Facebook
abstract: In taking Microsoft’s money to hire a battalion of engineers to take on parts of Google, Mark Zuckerberg is embracing the 1999 rallying cry: Go big or go home.

headline: How Apple Can Keep Its Value
abstract: With a market value of $162 billion, Apple is now the most valuable computer maker in the world, and it is the fourth most valuable technology company, after Microsoft, Google and Cisco. It will have to battle all of them to stay on top of the tech world.

headline: Google and Friends to Gang Up on Facebook
abstract: A week after losing out to Microsoft in a bid to invest in Facebook, Google is hitting back.

headline: The Back Door Into Facebook Ads
abstract: Although Microsoft has locked up banner ad space on the site, companies like AdBrite still see opportunities in other areas of Facebook.

headline: Facebook’s Rapid Stock Appreciation
abstract: The share price that Facebook has used for its employee stock options rose more than 30-fold between January 2006 and August 2007. It’s likely to experience another steep jump in value after Microsoft’s investment is factored in.

headline: Google’s DoubleClick Deal Expected to Win Approval
abstract: Antitrust experts predict that Google‘s purchase of the advertising company DoubleClick for $3.1 billion will be approved by regulators despite vehement opposition from competitors Microsoft and Yahoo, Reuters reported.

headline: Harvard Grads Ink Deal for ‘Facebook Book’
abstract: As industry observers wait for the next move in reported deal talks between Facebook and Microsoft, another, albeit considerably smaller, deal related to social networking site has been signed.

headline: Ignition Revs Up With $675 Million
abstract: Ignition Partners, the venture capital firm founded by former Microsoft and McCaw Cellular executives, has raised $675 million that it will use to bankroll as many as 40 new private companies.

headline: Tip of the Week: Making Edits in Print Preview
abstract: If you are taking one last look at a document in Microsoft Word’s Print Preview mode and notice a typo, you do not have to leave the Print Preview screen to fix it.

headline: A Cloudbook on the Horizon
abstract: The $299 eeePC is a lightweight portable computer that is meant for browsing Web sites and running Internet applications.

headline: Google Gives Some Hints About Social Network Plan
abstract: Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, said the company plans to use the social information implicit in Gmail and its other services to improve its search engine.

headline: What GPhone?
abstract: Google is getting into the phone software business, competing with Microsoft, rather than the cellphone business, competing with Apple, Nokia and the rest.

headline: With a Keyboard and a Pop-Up Screen, Is This a Computer or a Cellphone?
abstract: The AT&T Tilt is shaped like a candy bar has a sliding keyboard, 2.8-inch touchscreen and a processor running at about 400 megahertz.

headline: Facebook’s Stock Options
abstract: Can Facebook lure the hottest talent with the prospective of becoming millionaires with stock options? Some people suggest the $15 billion valuation of the company will make it harder to get rich, really rich, there.

headline: Google Analyst Day (3): Staying Friends With Facebook
abstract: Eric Schmidt, Google’s chief executive, told analysts and reporters he hoped to work with Facebook, even though it had taken an investment from Microsoft.

headline: As Apple Gains PC Market Share, Jobs Talks of a Decade of Upgrades
abstract: Apple’s share of the personal computer market is surging, driven in part by what analysts call a halo effect from the iPod and the iPhone.

headline: Bill Gates Has Joined Facebook! He Has Friends!
abstract: Bill Gates has a Facebook page, or at least humorist Jenny Lyn Bader imagines he does.

headline: In India, Poverty Inspires Technology Workers to Altruism
abstract: Corporations have made India a laboratory for extending modern technological conveniences to the world’s poor.

headline: The Real History of WYSIWYG
abstract: A former Xerox hardware designer says his wife coined the term, which describes most modern software interfaces.

headline: Facebook Chief Says Financing Deal Is Near
abstract: Facebook‘s chief executive and founder, Mark Zuckerberg, said Wednesday that while an initial public offering of the social-networking site is still “years out,” it is making progress on a “financing.”

headline: The iPhone?  Microsoft Shrugs
abstract: Highlights from Bits, the technology blog.

headline: Microsoft Challenges the iPod (Again)
abstract: The new Zune photo/video/music player fixes many mistakes that made the original Zune a washout.

headline: Being Skeptical of Green
abstract: Consumers who think they can help improve the environment should be careful when it comes to their purchasing decisions and avoid relying on labels.

headline: Mouse With a Memory Can Be Used for File Storage
abstract: The Mobile Memory Mouse 8000 from Microsoft has a U.S.B. transceiver that doubles as a one-gigabyte flash drive for storing and transferring files.

headline: Sprechen Sie Deutsch, Vista?
abstract: Is it possible to change the language of the menus and dialog boxes in Windows Vista?

headline: Software for Rent
abstract: Salesforce.com wants to become a platform like Microsoft’s Windows operating system, a product so popular that it is the foundation for a veritable ecosystem of software developers.

headline: The Public Face of Wal-Mart’s Health Care Program
abstract:
Linda Dillman, who oversees Wal-Mart’s health care system, answers questions about changes the company has made in the program.

.

headline: Computer Servers for Home Use Can Help Get a Grip on All Those Photo, Music and Video Files in the PC Attic
abstract: Powered by Microsoft’s Windows Home Server software, Hewlett-Packard’s MediaSmart Server is intended for the home.

headline: Tip of the Week: Check Spelling Automatically
abstract: Do you often forget to proofread your outgoing Outlook messages?

headline: Drivers Can Drive You Crazy
abstract: I keep getting an error message and my Windows XP computer has to be restarted in order to work. What is causing this?

headline: Two Hard Drives Double Your Fun
abstract: I saw a new laptop for sale with two hard drives — why is that? What is the advantage?

headline: Circuits: A Computer That Works With Google, Not Microsoft
abstract: The new Everex gPC TC2502 computer runs GOS, a version of Linux specially designed to run Google applications like GMail and Google Documents.

headline: Microsoft’s Search Aspirations Revive Yahoo Chatter
abstract: It doesn’t take much to rekindle speculation about a tie-up between Microsoft and Yahoo. Analysts, investors and bloggers have long discussed the pros and cons of this as yet strictly hypothetical pairing. So when a Microsoft executive went on the record Thursday about wanting to triple the size of his company’s Internet search business, it was more than enough to get the rumor mill creaking back into action.

headline: Microsoft’s Windows Live Yahoo Hotmail Problem
abstract: Why the numbers and the strategy simply don’t work for Microsoft to combine with Yahoo.

headline: J Allard: Microsoft’s Plan to Be King of All Media
abstract: Microsoft is building an online service that will be the back end for all sorts of communication and entertainment, linking XBox games, Zune music, video and cellphones.

headline: The Back of Henry Blodget’s Envelope
abstract: Microsoft’s MSN division is worth $10 billion, Henry Blodget calculates. That’s not enough to trade for much of Yahoo, but giving up control may be the best bet for Microsoft.

headline: J Allard: Dancing Around the Cellphone Question
abstract: Microsoft hopes to respond to the iPhone with better software, but it may not make the phones itself.

headline: J Allard: The Failures of the Zune and the Record Labels
abstract: The first generation of the Zune achieved its goal of “failing fast,” says J Allard, who is in charge of the product at Microsoft. It wasn’t helped, he said, by flawed business models from the record labels.

headline: Barry Diller’s Bill Gates Imitation
abstract: IAC has just introduced 236.com, a fake news site. Seen that idea before? So did Barry Diller, who, like Microsoft, is trying to profit from the ideas of others.

headline: Merrill Lynch Sues Over Racist E-Mails
abstract: Merrill Lynch is subpoenaing an Internet service provider and Microsoft to identify the sender of “explicit racial remarks” in e-mail messages to black investment bankers within the company, a spokesman for the investment bank said.

headline: Walking Off Into the Vista
abstract: Sure, Vista is annoying. But even more annoying is Microsoft’s word processing software. And that’s one more compelling reason for a move to cloud computing.

headline: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
abstract: Mozilla has come to resemble a Silicon Valley start-up more than a scrappy collaborative underdog.

headline: Dell on the Rebound?
abstract: Forrester, a research firm, says Dell is on the mend with its corporate customers. It also finds resistance to Windows Vista among corporations.

headline: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
abstract: Only a couple of years ago, Firefox was the little browser that could – an open-source program created by thousands of contributors around the world without the benefit of a giant company like Microsoft to finance it.

headline: Republicans Raise Privacy Concerns Over Google Deal
abstract: Representative Joe Barton, the senior Republican on the House Commerce Committee, and other GOP lawmakers are apparently having second thoughts about Google‘s $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick and are calling for a hearing into the privacy aspects of the proposed merger.

headline: Digg Said to Be Close to Sale
abstract: Digg, a popular news site where readers rank stories, was the subject of renewed takeover rumors on Wednesday, as the Valleywag blog, citing anonymous sources, said a “major media player” was close to acquiring it for $300 million to $400 million. Digg’s chief executive declined to comment to CNET News.com on the rumor.

headline: For All You Smartphone Users With Big Thumbs: Motorola’s New Q Global Aims to Encourage You to Type
abstract: Motorola’s Q Global smartphone can sync your e-mail with Microsoft Outlook on your PC, and you can transfer Office documents between a PC and the device.

headline: Barry Diller Asks and Google Answers With Cash
abstract: As Barry Diller pares down IAC/InterActiveCorp, the remaining company’s coffers will get a lot fatter with a new $3.5 billion five-year advertising deal with Google.

headline: Google Hits European Hurdle on DoubleClick Deal
abstract: In what will no doubt be welcome news to the likes of Microsoft and Yahoo, European regulators refused Tuesday to approve Google‘s $3.1 billion purchase of the Internet advertising company DoubleClick. They ordered a review of the deal amid opposition from rivals, publishers and consumer groups.

headline: Initiate Systems Tries I.P.O. Route
abstract: Initiate Systems, a master data management company, filed this week to raise up to $75 million in an initial public offering. But, The 451 Group asks, could an M&A event still be in its future?

headline: Don’t Give Up on Leopard (Despite the Bugs)
abstract: Even as Apple mocks the problems of Windows Vista, its own OS X Leopard is causing system crashes and other problems.

headline: Google Enters the Wireless World
abstract: Google announced that it is leading an industry alliance to transform mobile phones into powerful computers.

headline: In Big Map Deals, Google Can’t Be Found
abstract: Google, where are you?

headline: Accel Closes $520 Million Investment Fund
abstract: Early-stage venture capital firm Accel Partners announced the final closing of its 10th investment fund with $520 million on Monday.

headline: F.T.C. Member Vows Tighter Controls of Online Ads
abstract: Because of the increased tracking of people’s Internet activities by marketing firms, a member of the Federal Trade Commission vowed to exert more controls over online ads.

headline: A Little Attack Ad for Apple
abstract: Apple’s attack ad on Microsft’s Vista retains the bemused attachment of the already-classic campaign.

headline: F.T.C. Member Vows Tighter Controls of Online Ads
abstract: Because of increased tracking of people’s Internet habits by marketing firms, a member of the Federal Trade Commission has vowed to exert more controls over online ads.

headline: One Other Little Dance
abstract: With Google’s introduction of a cellphone operating system, it adds another front of competition with Apple, even though Eric Schmidt, Google’s chief executive, serves on Apple’s board.

headline: Digital Camera for the PlayStation 3 Is Watching, and Listening, While You Play
abstract: Last week, Sony released its long-awaited PlayStation Eye, a digital camera that lets players interact with some games using body motions.

headline: The Higher Value of Eyeballs
abstract: Highlights from Bits, the technology blog updated all day at nytimes.com/bits.

headline: Reaching for Apple, Falling Short
abstract: T-Mobile’s new Shadow smartphone is supposed to be a communications powerhouse, but there are some drawbacks.

headline: Is It Spelled Yahoogle or Yoogle?
abstract: Like that other search company, Yahoo is trying to build ties to researchers who can develop better ways to use huge clusters of computers.

headline: Google Hits European Hurdle on DoubleClick Deal
abstract: European regulators refused Tuesday to approve Google’s $3.1 billion purchase of the Internet advertising company DoubleClick.  Instead they ordered a review of the deal.

headline: Google Enters the Wireless World
abstract: Google said Monday that it is leading a broad industry effort to develop new software technologies aimed at turning cellphones into powerful mobile computers.

headline: Mad About Facebook, or Just Plain Mad?
abstract: A venture capitalist crazy for Facebook may be just plain crazy, according to some of his Silicon Valley compatriots.

headline: Which Advertiser Is on Your Friend List?
abstract: At a meeting called by the F.T.C., Esther Dyson wondered whether the way people are controlling information on social networks shouldn’t also apply to advertising.

headline: Readers Answer Some of Pogue’s Imponderables
abstract: Readers respond to some of life’s little questions that don’t seem to have good answers.

headline: Gmail Is More Than Just Mail
abstract: Is it true you can use your Gmail address for instant messaging?

headline: Facebook Is Marketing Your Brand Preferences (With Your Permission)
abstract: The social networking site now sells ads that display people’s profile photos next to commercial messages that are shown to their friends about items they purchased or registered an opinion about.

headline: Things Turn Ugly in the ‘Hacks vs. Flacks’ War
abstract: A magazine editor, tired of public relations e-mail spam, strikes back.

headline: Britain: Microsoft Buys Map Service
abstract: Microsoft said it had agreed to acquire MultiMap, an online map service based in London, in an attempt to compete more effectively with the search services of Google.

headline: Global Market for Cellphone Ring Tones Is Shrinking
abstract: After years of double-digit growth rates, the global ring tone market appears to have come to the end of its crescendo.

headline: Tip of the Week: Increasing the Speed of a Vista-Operated PC
abstract: If you have a spare U.S.B. flash drive you can use it to give your Windows Vista-operated PC an extra cache of memory to help increase speed.

headline: Simplify the Controllers, and Everyone’s a Video Gamer
abstract: As the battle for the living-room screen escalates, there are signs that Sony and Microsoft are seeing the importance of simplified controls as well.

headline: Going Public Caps Dream for a Maker of Software
abstract: If all goes well, Evan Goldberg will have come a long way from the overcrowded Silicon Valley apartment that served as NetSuite’s first office nearly 10 years ago.

headline: Faster Chips Are Leaving Programmers in Their Dust
abstract: Newer computer chips with multiple processors require dauntingly complex software and programmers are having a hard time keeping up.

headline: What Next, Having the Office Christmas Party at Home?
abstract: For years, equipment once normally found only in the office has been migrating into the home, from answering machines and water coolers to laser printers and PCs. Now, in a quirky new campaign, Microsoft is hoping to sell America on the idea of bringing servers in-house.

headline: Web Browser in Windows Is at Center of Complaint
abstract: Less than three months after Microsoft lost a landmark antitrust case in Europe, a Norwegian software company filed a new complaint Thursday, challenging the software giant’s bundling of its Web browser with its Windows operating system.

headline: Viacom Dumps DoubleClick for Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft and Viacom team up on ads and content, and Google quickly points to the deal as evidence that the online ad market is plenty competitive.

headline: Microsoft’s Arguments Against Google-DoubleClick Marriage
abstract: It is well known that Microsoft has been leading a heated effort to block Google from purchasing DoubleClick.

headline: In Its Race Against Google, Microsoft Buys MultiMap
abstract: Microsoft said it had agreed to acquire MultiMap, an online map service based in London, in an attempt to compete more effectively with the search services of Google and to collect more revenue from online and mobile advertising.

headline: Paul Allen to Bid in Spectrum Auction
abstract: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen has applied to bid in an upcoming U.S. auction of coveted wireless airwaves, according to auction documents released late Tuesday.

headline: Would You Buy a Telephone From a Company Named Ribbit?
abstract: A startup takes an entire telephone company switchboard and makes it available over the Internet. This allows programmers to develop applications that combine telephone calls and other data.

headline: The Year in Technology M&A
abstract: Microsoft, Oracle, I.B.M. and a host of private equity firms helped drive technology mergers and acquisitions to a fourth consecutive record year in 2007. The introduction to The 451 Group’s Technology M&A Outlook report lists the year’s significant deals, identifies M&A drivers and looks at the outlook for 2008.

headline: 2007: What’s the Best M&A Deal of the Year?
abstract: Let’s face it. Private equity firms hogged the deal-making spotlight in 2007, first with their high-flying buyouts and then with their frantic efforts to salvage them.

headline: Google’s Market Share Grows and Grows and Grows
abstract: Google’s share of the search market keeps growing, and no one seems willing to bet that will change soon.

headline: Russian Firm Buys LiveJournal
