abstract: The owner of LiveJournal, a blogging and social-networking site, agreed Sunday to sell the company to SUP, a Russian online media firm.

headline: Questions We Thought, But Didn’t Ask, in 2007
abstract: As the year ends, we ask the questions that perplex us the most.

headline: Vivendi to Acquire Activision
abstract: Vivendi said Sunday that it planned to acquire a controlling stake in Activision in a deal that creates a rival to Electronic Arts as the world’s largest independent video game publisher.

headline: Bits
abstract: Highlights from Bits, the technology blog.

headline: F.T.C. Approves Google-DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Antitrust regulators approved Google‘s $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick, clearing the way for a formidable combination in the burgeoning online advertising sector.

headline: What Should Apple Do With its Piggy Bank?
abstract: Apple has put an additional $5 billion in the bank over the last year, giving it more cash than any company other than Microsoft and Cisco. Should it make acquisitions, pay a dividend, buy its stock back, or just look at the money pile up in the vault?

headline: A Year Later: Chat on AIM through GMail
abstract: Gmail users can now have instant-message conversations with users of AOL’s AIM system, fulfilling a key term of the deal in which Google invested $1 billion in AOL. The message services of Yahoo and MSN are linked to each other but not to Google or AOL.

headline: Ask.com Puts a Bet on Privacy
abstract: The fourth-largest search engine company will begin a service Tuesday called AskEraser, which allows users to make their searches more private.

headline: F.T.C. Approves DoubleClick Deal
abstract: The proposed Google merger could still be held up in Europe, where personal privacy has more legal protections than in the United States.

headline: Oracle Beats Wall Street’s Expectations for Quarter
abstract: The business software firm recorded some of its sharpest quarterly growth in a decade, easing fears it would be bruised by the mortgage crisis.

headline: Vivendi to Acquire Activision
abstract: The deal would create a rival to Electronic Arts as the  largest independent video game publisher.

headline: Congressman Says Google Is Resisting Deal Inquiry
abstract: Representative Joe Barton of Texas said on Wednesday that Google had rebuffed requests by his staff for a meeting as part of an investigation into the company’s $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick.

headline: News Corp. Sells Fox Stations to Oak Hill
abstract: The News Corporation said it would sell eight of its owned-and-operated Fox network affiliated television stations to private equity investment firm Oak Hill Capital Partners for about $1.1 billion in cash.

headline: Congressman Says Google Is Resisting Deal Inquiry
abstract: Representative Joe Barton of Texas said on Wednesday that Google had rebuffed requests by his staff for a meeting as part of an investigation into the company’s $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick.

headline: Privacy Groups Question F.T.C. Chairwoman’s DoubleClick Ties
abstract: Two privacy groups asked the chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission to recuse herself from the commission’s review of Google’s merger with DoubleClick. The chairwoman’s husband works at a law firm representing DoubleClick.

headline: Senior Executive Is Leaving Cisco Systems
abstract: Cisco Systems‘ chief development officer, Charles H. Giancarlo, widely seen as a top candidate for chief executive, announced on Thursday that he was quitting the company, leaving the race for leadership wide open.

headline: Putting a Price on the Drudge Report
abstract: The Drudge Report isn’t for sale — at least, not that we know of. But that didn’t stop Duff McDonald, writing in the latest issue of Portfolio magazine, from playfully speculating about the value of Matt Drudge’s Web site, a gossipy gathering of links, news and scoops that has been around for more than a decade and can still make waves in Washington.

headline: A Year Later, the Same Scene: Long Lines for the Elusive Wii
abstract: Nintendo has been unable to keep up with demand for the Wii, its intensely popular video game machine, costing the company hundreds of millions of dollars in potential sales.

headline: My Spooler Isn’t Spooling
abstract: I keep getting error messages about my “spooler” when I try to print documents from my Windows Vista-operated computer. What does this mean, and what can I do to fix it?

headline: Palm Gives Sinking Feeling to Elevation Partners
abstract: It has only been two months, but Elevation Partners‘ investment in Palm has been anything but uplifting so far. Elevation, a private equity firm whose founders include rock star Bono, invested $325 million in Palm in a deal that closed Oct. 24. Since then, Palm’s stock has lost nearly half of its value, after adjusting for a special dividend it paid out to shareholders.

headline: Fighting It Out on the Battlefield and on the Court
abstract: In the real-time strategy game Universe at War: Earth Assault, aliens are once again marveling at the scrappy humans’ ability to survive.

headline: In Restless Pursuit of Craigslist’s Success
abstract: Kijiji is trying to capitalize on eBay’s clout to compete with the Web’s most spectacularly successful underdog, Craigslist.

headline: Hong Kong Billionaire to Pony Up for Facebook, Report Says
abstract: Li Ka-shing may have agreed to write a $60 million check to help Facebook founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg build out his fast-growing social networking site, but a media company controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire denies that the money went through them.

headline: Apple Making Deals for Web Video Rentals
abstract: Apple’s sputtering efforts to be a major purveyor of video downloads may get a boost in 2008 from an agreement with 20th Century Fox for digital movie rentals.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Webdenda.

headline: Nokia and Universal’s Proposed Music Tax
abstract: The “Comes With Music” program just announced by Nokia, under which some cellphones will be bundled with the right to download an unlimited number of songs for a year, offers an interesting model for the music business.

headline: Wal-Mart Pulls Plug on Movies via the Web
abstract: Wal-Mart said it had ended the business because Hewlett-Packard, a chief technology partner, had decided to discontinue essential infrastructure for the service.

headline: Beyond Sheep-Throwing: Rhapsody on Facebook
abstract: The new Facebook application for the Rhapsody music service shows some of the advantages of integrating powerful applications into Facebook’s environment.

headline: NetSuite Raises I.P.O. Price Range
abstract: NetSuite‘s stock sale, expected later this week, is one of the most anticipated offerings coming out of Silicon Valley. And it just got bigger.

headline: The Depth of eBay’s Problems 1: Disappointed Buyers
abstract: After a post suggesting that Amazon buy eBay, Bits readers revolt with a litany of complaints about eBay. The site, they say, has such bad customer service and is so riddled with fraud that Amazon should stay away.

headline: With Wii and DS, Nintendo Has 2 Hit Game Devices
abstract: While shoppers are still lining up to buy Nintendo’s Wii, its older portable sibling, the Nintendo DS, is the best-selling game machine in the United States.

headline: Laugh at the Web Clips, Then Buy the Gel
abstract: With the increasing interest among marketers in embedding brands in entertainment programming, a viral campaign is arriving that spoofs the concept — while at the same time playing up the product.

headline: In the DVD War Over High Definition, Most Buyers Are Sitting It Out
abstract: Even as prices fall, neither Sony’s Blu-ray nor Toshiba’s HD DVD, has gained an advantage.

headline: A Voice to Guide You on the Road
abstract: Searching for G.P.S. models that fulfill three requirements that may keep a driver from grunting, panting and swearing.

headline: Tip of the Week: Shortcuts for Microsoft Word
abstract: Microsoft Word includes keyboard shortcuts for quickly inserting the current date and time into your documents and memos.

headline: Microsoft Delivers Strong Earnings and Outlook
abstract: Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profit gains that surpassed Wall Street’s expectations, and delivered an optimistic outlook.

headline: Microsoft Delivers Strong Growth and Includes a Sunny Forecast
abstract: The company’s strong quarterly results and optimistic outlook suggest that a weakening economy will not slow it down.

headline: In Europe, Microsoft Again Faces Inquiries
abstract: Europe’s antitrust regulator has opened two new investigations into claims that Microsoft has abused its dominant market position.

headline: Leader of Microsoft’s Office Business Is Retiring
abstract: Jeff Raikes, a 26-year veteran of Microsoft, plans to retire later this year and the company announced that it was reaching outside its ranks for his successor.

headline: Microsoft Forges Ties to Studios
abstract: Microsoft announced partnerships with Walt Disney, NBC Universal and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to boost online video sales.

headline: Microsoft Bids for Search Software Firm
abstract: Microsoft’s $1.2 billion bid for a Norwegian search software company is seen as an effort to add tools to its lucrative Office products and fend off Google.

headline: Microsoft Bids for Norwegian Search Engine Firm
abstract: Microsoft bid $1.2 billion for Fast Search and Transfer, based in Oslo, in an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products.

headline: Formatting Lost in the Mail
abstract: When I format my e-mail with italic, underscore or boldface, my recipient can’t see it. I have Microsoft Outlook set to compose in HTML, so why can’t my recipient see the message as I sent it?

headline: Resizing Drives, for Extra Room
abstract: I have a problem that other PC users may share: what to do when your C drive runs out of space?

headline: Wipe Your PC for Safety’s Sake
abstract: Is there software to restore a Windows XP computer system to “pre-ownership” state?

headline: Microsoft M&A Guru to Leave
abstract: A day after signing a $1.2 billion deal to buy a Norwegian search company, Fast Search and Transfer, Microsoft confirmed that Bruce Jaffe, the firm’s mergers and acquisitions architect, will be leaving the company at the end of February.

headline: A FAST Deal for Microsoft Search
abstract: Microsoft’s $1.2 billion acquisition of Fast Search and Transfer, the Norwegian enterprise search vendor, may bolster its technology and its relationships with big companies and Web publishers.

headline: No More New Things From Microsoft
abstract: At his last C.E.S. keynote, Bill Gates offers some content partnerships, a few cool demos and a handful of modest product tweaks. In other words, Microsoft has little new to offer in the exploding world of consumer electronics.

headline: With Fast Search Deal, Microsoft Aims at Google
abstract: Microsoft‘s $1.2 billion bid on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company, was seen mainly as an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products, but was also being done, analysts said, with an eye toward fending off Google.

headline: Logitech Shares Jump on Microsoft Bid Rumors
abstract: Shares in the Swiss-based computer peripherals maker Logitech International rose more than 12 percent on Thursday amid speculation Microsoft would make a takeover bid, traders told Reuters. Spokesmen for Logitech, the world’s largest maker of computer mice, and Microsoft were not immediately reachable for comment.

headline: Should Microsoft Put Plaxo in Its Address Book?
abstract: Microsoft made a big splash with its $240 million deal to buy a sliver of Facebook. Now, some industry observers think the software giant should consider another social-networking deal. This time, the focus is on Plaxo, an early entrant into the social-networking field that was overtaken by rivals and is looking to fetch as much as $100 million in a potential sale of the company.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Norway’s Fast Search for $1.23 Billion
abstract: Microsoft agreed to buy Norwegian online-search software maker Fast Search & Transfer for 6.6 billion kroner ($1.23 billion) as it adds products that help companies mine information on the Internet.

headline: Microsoft Ruling: Split Decision, Two More Years of Oversight
abstract: It would require a microscope to detect changes in Microsoft’s behavior or in the software market as a result of the consent decree extended Tuesday by a federal court.

headline: The European Challenge to Successful Companies
abstract: Setting ground rules for competition is one thing, but seeking to determine outcomes is another. In European antitrust, there is more a doctrine of “reining in” powerful companies than in the United States

headline: Yahoo’s Core Value Is Falling
abstract: An analyst runs through the numbers and shows just how far Yahoo has slumped. Will its poor stock performance make it a takeover target?

headline: AT&T and Other I.S.P.’s May Be Getting Ready to Filter
abstract: An AT&T executive says the company is considering the use of anti-piracy filtering technologies on the network level.

headline: CNBC Video: Banding Together to Raise AIDS Awareness
abstract: A rock star, a software tycoon and a computer hardware impresario walk into a Swiss village …

headline: New Questions for a New Year
abstract: A list of tech-industry questions that might get answers this year.

headline: Tip of the Week: How to Reduce Scrolling
abstract: If your finger is tired of turning the wheel in the middle of a computer mouse to roll through a page, press down on the scroll-wheel button.

headline: If Sony BMG Drops D.R.M. for Music, D.R.M. Is Gone
abstract: The concept of digital right management software limiting consumers’ use of downloaded music may be coming to an end.

headline: Tracking the World’s Appetite for Innovation
abstract: In its quest for what it calls “new metrics for the knowledge economy,” a nonprofit research group has come up with an index of global innovation confidence.

headline: Internet to the TV? Me Too!
abstract: Microsoft reached some new agreements to allow delivery of new movie and television content over the Xbox Live service and MSN online. It must mean the connected home – the holy matrimony between hardware and downloadable content – finally is at the altar.

headline: How Much for a Firefox I.P.O.?
abstract: Analysts and pundits have already speculated about how much hot Web phenoms such as Facebook would be worth if and when they go public. Now, Henry Blodget — he of the $400 Amazon.com stock prediction — has trained his eye on one of the browsers used to view those sites.

headline: Ad Infuse Gets $12 Million Injection
abstract: Ad Infuse on Wednesday became the latest mobile advertising upstart to tap into growing investor interest in the slowly emerging mobile ad market. Ad Infuse, a startup based in San Francisco, said it got $12 million from SoftBank Capital, ComVentures, and Storm Ventures.

headline: The Passion of Steve Jobs
abstract: Apple’s chief executive talks up his company’s latest products and offers some frank thoughts about his competitors.

headline: Sony Profit Increases 25 Percent
abstract: Sony said its profit rose in the final three months of 2007, helped by robust sales of televisions and computer games.

headline: Wiki Citizens Taking on a New Area: Searching
abstract: Jimmy Wales, co-founder of Wikipedia, is launching an Internet search engine based on the same voluntary collaboration that drives the online encyclopedia.

headline: Opportunists Said to Be Circling Yahoo
abstract: While Yahoo‘s co-foundersm Jerry Yang and David Filo, may not want to sell the struggling Internet company, its stock price is so low that the duo may not be able to fend off a takeover offer without compromising their fiduciary duty to shareholders, according to The New York Post.

headline: The Week’s Economic Reports
abstract: The release of existing-home sales numbers on Thursday highlight a slow week for economic data.

headline: As Electronics Show Grows, Some Scale Back
abstract: The annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas has become a challenging place to introduce new products.

headline: Should Yahoo Go into Deal Mode?
abstract: A move by Yahoo to announce layoffs when it discloses quarterly earnings next week is unlikely to appease investors eager for the Internet company to take more aggressive, if potentially riskier, steps to jump-start its business.

headline: Video Podcasts: The Sleeping Giant on AppleTV
abstract: A footnote to Apple’s presentation–the ability of the AppleTV to play video podcasts–may be the most important announcement because it opens a path for free, ad-supported programs from many sources to get onto televisions.

headline: Yahoo Makes a New Play for Ads on Mobile Phones
abstract: Yahoo plans to announce it has opened up some of its key mobile software and services to outside publishers and programmers.

headline: Google Earnings Fall Short of Expectations
abstract: Google said that its profit jumped 17 percent in the fourth quarter, but the earnings fell short of analysts’ expectations, and the company’s shares fell after hours.

headline: New Tools to Bolster Mac’s World
abstract: Macintosh sales rise and two new software programs fill big holes in the computer’s landscape.

headline: But You Know, Apple Is Really Just One of Us
abstract: C.E.S. doesn’t want to be overshadowed by Apple. So executives here point out that Apple is part of the club.

headline: Facebook Scores New European Investment
abstract: Facebook has attracted yet another strategic investor, raising millions of euros to fuel its European expansion, from three German brothers who made their fortune building Internet companies.

headline: Live From Davos 2008
abstract: The usual crowd of A-list names is here, or soon will be — political heavyweights, business bigwigs and prominent academics who have come together in the Swiss resort town of Davos for the World Economic Forum.

headline: Amazon Consolidates in Growing Area of Seattle
abstract: Amazon.com, the world’s largest online retailer, will soon finally have one place to call home.

headline: Yahoo’s Vision-Goes-Here Strategy
abstract: Jerry Yang and Sue Decker sounded like they were talking only to analysts filling out spreadsheets on their conference call Tuesday. Yahoo’s shares plunged, and the company’s customers and employees are left to wonder what’s next.

headline: Intel Quits Effort to Get Computers to Children
abstract: Intel and the One Laptop Per Child group had a rocky relationship from the start in their short-lived effort to get inexpensive laptops into the hands of the world’s poorest children.

headline: Mozilla Names New Chief, but Reaffirms Open-Source Commitment
abstract: John Lilly, the chief operating officer of Mozilla, the developer of the open-source browser Firefox, will succeed Mitchell Baker as the firm’s chief executive.

headline: Anxiety Crashes the Party at Davos
abstract: This year, the World Economic Forum is actually going to be about the world economy. Which is not to say that there won’t be fun.

headline: Ruminating Over Identity at Sundance
abstract: The places young people find online to hang out are less fake than the lives they live with their parents, their teachers, even their real-life friends. It makes their lives more real, said panelists discussing technology and how it changes us.

headline: Microsoft to Share More Technical Secrets
abstract: Seeking to satisfy European antitrust officials, Microsoft said on Thursday that it would open up and share many more of its technical secrets with the rest of the software industry.

headline: Europe Fines Microsoft $1.35 Billion
abstract: Regulators issued the fine for failing to comply with a 2004 judgment that Microsoft had abused its dominance.

headline: Microsoft Said to Plan Proxy Fight for Yahoo
abstract: In part of a hard-nosed takeover campaign that Microsoft began two weeks ago, the company has begun preparing for a proxy fight to oust Yahoo’s directors.

headline: Microsoft to Share More Technical Secrets
abstract: Seeking to satisfy European antitrust officials, Microsoft said it would open up and share many more of its technical secrets with the rest of the software industry and competitors.

headline: Microsoft Gets Record Fine and a Rebuke From Europe
abstract: Regulators issued the company a $1.35 billion fine for failing to comply with a 2004 judgment that it had abused its dominance.

headline: A Little Piece of Microsoft Aids Small Business
abstract: Office Live Small Business gives the nation’s 25 million small businesses the same online tools that the big boys use, and it shows Microsoft can still produce fresh ideas and polished work.

headline: Microsoft Reassigns Several Top Executives
abstract: The company placed new executives in charge of operations facing fierce new competition from Google, Apple and cellphone makers.

headline: Yahoo Chief Explains Rejection of Microsoft Bid
abstract: Jerry Yang explained his company’s rejection of Microsoft’s buyout offer in a letter to shareholders late Wednesday outlining why he believed the bid was too low.

headline: Microsoft to Buy a Maker of Consumer Smartphones
abstract: Microsoft said it would acquire Danger, a maker of consumer smartphones, an indication that the software giant is quickly moving to expand its mobile strategy.

headline: After Rejection by Yahoo, Microsoft Hints at a Fight
abstract: Hours after Yahoo officially rejected Microsoft’s takeover bid, calling it too low, Microsoft called Yahoo’s response “unfortunate” and said its proposal was “full and fair.”

headline: Yahoo Expected to Reject Microsoft’s Takeover Bid
abstract: Yahoo’s board decided that Microsoft’s $44.6 billion hostile bid undervalues the company, people involved said.

headline: Microsoft Signals Fight for Yahoo Isn’t Over
abstract: Microsoft is devising ways to raise the stakes in the fight for Yahoo now that its original proposal has been rejected.

headline: Yahoo Bidder Wants a More Aggressive Microsoft
abstract: With Yahoo’s board rejecting Microsoft’s bid, it will fall to Christopher P. Liddell, an outsider to the software industry, to plot Microsoft’s next steps in the bitter battle.

headline: Facing Free Software, Microsoft Looks to Yahoo
abstract: Internet-centered programs that compete with the core products of Microsoft are a driver of its bid for Yahoo.

headline: Yahoo’s Directors Discuss How to Face Microsoft Bid
abstract: Presentations from Yahoo’s management and its bankers argued that the company was worth more than what Microsoft has offered.

headline: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid
abstract: Whatever the outcome of Microsoft’s bid for Yahoo, the move and Google’s countermoves mark  an escalation in the confrontation between the two companies.

headline: Google and Microsoft Take Up Battle Stations
abstract: With Microsoft hoping to buy Yahoo, Google has begun to lay the groundwork to try to delay or derail any deal.

headline: Google Works to Torpedo Microsoft Bid for Yahoo
abstract: Google is making an unusually aggressive effort to block Microsoft’s $44.6 billion hostile bid for Yahoo.

headline: Another Difficulty for a Microsoft-Yahoo Marriage: Recruiting
abstract: In an industry that favors start-ups, a faint stodginess clings to Microsoft and Yahoo that could impede their  ability to draw top engineering talent.

headline: Microsoft Adds Research Lab in East as Others Cut Back
abstract: As other high-tech companies cut back on their research labs, Microsoft continues to increase its ranks of free-rein thinkers.

headline: Microsoft Bids $44.6 Billion for Yahoo
abstract: The deal would reshape the Internet consumer services business, where both companies have struggled to compete with Google.

headline: Eyes on Google, Microsoft Bids $44 Billion for Yahoo
abstract: If consummated, the deal would instantly redraw the competitive landscape on the Internet and escalate the battle between Microsoft and Google.

headline: Yahoo Offer Is Strategy Shift for Microsoft
abstract: Google’s dominance has forced Microsoft to concede that it did not get its Internet business right.

headline: Outlook Versus Outlook Express?
abstract: What does Outlook do that Outlook Express doesn’t do? Is there any reason to buy Outlook?

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
abstract: An explanation of why deals fail: It’s about timing.

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting Rid of That Nagging Balloon
abstract: If you’re tired of Windows XP nagging you to clean up unused icons from your desktop, you can pop that little yellow balloon for good.

headline: Of All the Hurdles to a Merger, View on Technology Is the Highest
abstract: A smooth integration between Microsoft and Yahoo will not be a matter of simply swapping one set of software or hardware for another. It may hinge on changing deep-seated mind-sets.

headline: Little Room for Yahoo to Maneuver
abstract: Many Yahoo shareholders are waiting for a higher bid than that offered by Microsoft, but analysts say it is increasingly unlikely.

headline: Moving Outlook: Mail to a Mac
abstract: Is there a way to move the Microsoft Outlook file (e-mails, contacts and calendars) between a PC and a Mac?

headline: Tip of the Week: Google’s Keyboard Shortcuts.
abstract: If you spend too much time pointing and clicking just to read your Gmail on the Web, check out Google’s set of keyboard shortcuts.

headline: Limiting Power on a Shared PC
abstract: What’s the difference between sharing a PC on an Administrator user account and a Limited user account?

headline: Sending an S O S for a PC Exorcist
abstract: I leaped up from my desk vowing to commit the most sensational attack of revenge in the history of the personal computer industry.

headline: Is It Too Late for Yahoo?
abstract: Jerry Yang faces pressure as he decides whether to try to rescue the company from Microsoft, or accept its bid to purchase Yahoo.

headline: Using the Old to Open the New
abstract: I sometimes get Microsoft Word documents with a .docx file extension. What is this format, and is there a way to open them with Word 2003?

headline: The Art of Giving a Bear Hug
abstract: In a letter outlining Microsoft’s  hopes to Yahoo C.E.O. Jerry Yang, Microsoft C.E.O. Steven Ballmer followed a storied tradition on Wall Street: the bear hug letter.

headline: A Giant Bid That Shows How Tired the Giant Is
abstract: The proposed Yahoo deal is a confirmation that Microsoft has become exactly what Bill Gates used to fear — sluggish and bureaucratic.

headline: Deal That May Create More, Not Less, Competition
abstract: Advertising and media executives said that Google has become so dominant in the online advertising market that a combined Microsoft and Yahoo might be the only way to produce a legitimate competitor.

headline: Microsoft’s Letter to Yahoo
abstract: Below, the text of Microsoft‘s letter to the board of directors at Yahoo, proposing to buy the Internet company for $44.6 billion, or about $31 per share in cash and stock.

headline: Google’s Microsoft Fixation
abstract: Google has raised antitrust questions about Microsoft’s proposed acquisition of Yahoo. Google has long feared Microsoft, but that deal could well be a boon because it would further slow down its already poky rivals.

headline: Microsoft-Yahoo Media Roundup
abstract: The weekend was rife with media speculation about Microsoft‘s Yahoo bid and how it could play out. The San Francisco Chronicle wondered about the fates of “dozens” of overlapping Internet services at the two Web giants, and Reuters suggested that a combined Microsoft and Yahoo would be a “Noah’s Ark of a Web company” — one with two of everything. Vindu Goel, writing in the San Jose Mercury News, suggested that integration could be such a distraction that it works in favor of archrival Google.

headline: Microsoft and the Art of the Bear Hug
abstract: In sending a public letter to his intended takeover target, Microsoft‘s Steven Ballmer became the latest acquisition-hungry chief to try the time-honored “bear hug.” In this case, there were definitely claws behind his warm and fuzzy words to Yahoo, as DealBook explains in its latest column in The New York Times.

headline: Discussing Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid
abstract: Upon its announcement Friday at 6:30 a.m., Microsoft‘s $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo quickly became Topic A in the tech and media circles. But with so many intricacies in the deal, there’s a lot to dissect and digest.

headline: A Guide to Yahoo’s Unlikely Alternatives to Microsoft
abstract: Yahoo is searching for any alternative to being swallowed by Microsoft. It has been talking to News Corporation, Time Warner and Google, among others. None of these talks appear likely to be able to fend off a deal with Microsoft.

headline: Figuring Out Microsoft’s Next Move
abstract: Yahoo‘s lukewarm response to Microsoft‘s offer has put the ball in Microsoft’s court. What will it do next?

headline: Microsoft’s Inner Thoughts on Online Advertising
abstract: You can be sure that Microsoft will use the antitrust arguments it made against Google’s recent deal for Doubleclick again to claim that it simply had no choice but to shell out $44.6 billion for Yahoo.

headline: Will Microsoft’s Executive Shuffle Scare Yahoo?
abstract: Microsoft’s new reorganization splits responsibility for its online offerings between four executives, most of whom also are responsible for parts of the Windows operating system. That resembles the complex organization at Yahoo, which bred the infighting and paralysis, that many Yahoo employees blame for its ills.

headline: Microsoft-Yahoo, From Rumor to Reality
abstract: Investors were quick to respond to Microsoft‘s bid to buy Yahoo – they bought up plenty of the Internet company’s stock on Friday, pushing Yahoo’s share up by nearly 50 percent to $28.38 by the end of the day.

headline: How Microsoft Could Go Hostile
abstract: Bear hug letters are an art form. They are designed to put an unwilling takeover target on notice that they are no longer safe, but to fall short of being blatantly hostile.

headline: More at Stake in Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid
abstract: Microsoft has been justifying its $44 billion bid for Yahoo as a way to build sufficient scale in the search and advertising business to counter the Google juggernaut.

headline: Microsoft to Authorize Proxy Fight at Yahoo
abstract: In an escalation of its fight for Yahoo, Microsoft will authorize a proxy fight at the Internet company this week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Unless Yahoo quickly reverses course and enters into talks, Microsoft would then seek to nominate a slate of directors to Yahoo’s board by March 13, the final deadline for nominations, and pursue a lengthy campaign to oust the board.

headline: China Law Could Impede Microsoft Deal for Yahoo
abstract: In August, a Chinese antimonopoly law takes effect that will extend the nation’s economic influence far beyond its borders.

headline: Yahoo Seeks Way to Block Microsoft
abstract: In a move that could delay a proxy contest, Yahoo said it was extending the deadline for nominating directors to its board.

headline: Yahoo Looks at New Way to Survive
abstract: As it scrambles to avoid defeat in its battle with Microsoft, Yahoo may try to seek more time to find other partners or persuade Microsoft to raise its offer.

headline: Hollywood Producer Set to Make Shows for Xbox
abstract: Microsoft announced a deal with a company headed by Peter Safran, the veteran Hollywood producer and talent manager, to produce original shows for distribution on the system.

headline: Tip of the Week: Hiding Your Mouse Pointer
abstract: If you find that mouse pointer on screen distracting while you’re typing on your Windows machine, you might be able to hide it.

headline: A Push to Limit the Tracking of Web Surfers’ Clicks
abstract: The use of target advertising on the Internet is being challenged by members of the New York State Assembly.

headline: Industry Giants Try to Break Computing’s Dead End
abstract: Intel and Microsoft said that they planned to finance two groups of university researchers to start over and design a new generation of computing systems.

headline: Leaving Vista for Windows XP
abstract: I recently bought a laptop but it only came with Windows Vista, which I find troublesome. Can I remove Vista and install Windows XP instead?

headline: Yahoo Extends Nomination Time
abstract: Yahoo has amended its bylaws to give shareholders who want to nominate directors more time to do so, as it tries to buy time to explore alternatives to an unsolicited buyout offer from Microsoft.

headline: New Ad Accounts
abstract: Microsoft taps Crispin Porter & Bogusky for its new campaign.

headline: Pondering Microsoft’s Options
abstract: Yahoo‘s announcement Wednesday that it would delay its nominations deadline poses an interesting question for Microsoft. Does Microsoft wait until the announcement of the meeting date and the nominations deadline to start a proxy contest or does it attempt to nudge Yahoo by nominating directors beforehand (i.e., now)?

headline: Court Hands Setback to Microsoft
abstract: The Supreme Court handed Microsoft a defeat on Monday by refusing to rule on its request to halt an antitrust suit against it.

headline: Should Microsoft Be Selling, Not Buying?
abstract: As Microsoft looks to buy Yahoo to shore up its search business, a recent column in The New York Times suggested that Microsoft might consider acquiring SAP instead — a move that would bolster its business-software unit, which sells under the brand Microsoft Dynamics.

headline: Microsoft Buys Virtualization Start-Up
abstract: The latest in a spate of deals for virtualization start-ups is Microsoft‘s acquisition of Kidaro, an Israeli developer of desktop virtualization software for enterprises.

headline: Microsoft and Yahoo Said to Be Holding Talks
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo are holding informal merger discussions, marking a shift from the “radio silence” that previously existed between the two companies, according to several news reports.

headline: Microsoft Loses Its In-House Yahoo Executive
abstract: Joanne Bradford, the Microsoft executive in charged of running the company’s MSN portal, has quit to join a Los Angeles advertising company.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Web Ad Analysis Company
abstract: Microsoft plans to buy Rapt, plugging a hole in its suite of tools for Web publishers and advertisers, the software giant said Friday. Microsoft did not say what it would pay for the privately held San Francisco company.

headline: Approval of DoubleClick Deal May Help Microsoft

headline: Microsoft Would Not Rush to Merge Yahoo Technology
abstract: Microsoft would not rush to merge its technology platform with Yahoo‘s after a takeover of the Internet company, even if meant delaying some of the potential benefits to shareholders from any deal, Microsoft’s chief software architect told The Financial Times.

headline: China Law Could Impede Microsoft Deal for Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft‘s hostile takeover attempt against Yahoo may encounter an unexpected hurdle in August after a Chinese antimonopoly law takes effect that will extend the nation’s economic influence far beyond its borders.

headline: Microsoft Said to Hire Bear C.E.O. as Adviser in Yahoo Pursuit
abstract: Microsoft has brought in some muscle to help it clinch a deal for Yahoo The software maker has enlisted Bear Stearns‘s chief, Alan D. Schwartz, to advise it on the $42 billion deal, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Murdoch Says He Won’t Go Up Against Microsoft for Yahoo
abstract: One of Yahoo‘s long-shot white knights in its struggle to avoid being taken over by Microsoft closed the chances down entirely.

headline: The Yahoo Cross-Over Effect, Revisited
abstract: After the high-pitched news releases and the posturing are over, the fate of Microsoft‘s bid for Yahoo may come down to what the majority of Yahoo’s shareholders want.

headline: Betting on a Sweetener for Yahoo
abstract: Remember Yahoo?

headline: What If Yahoo’s Earnings Disappoint?
abstract: While some Yahoo investors might be waiting for a richer bid from Microsoft, some industry observers have been speculating that the software giant might be waiting for its opportunity to table a lower bid.

headline: Yahoo Backs Earnings Outlook
abstract: Can Yahoo fend off Microsoft with a Power Point presentation?

headline: Yahoo Looks at New Way to Survive
abstract: As it scrambles to avoid defeat in its battle with Microsoft, Yahoo may try to put a little more time on the clock.

headline: Will Europe Let Google Out of the Penalty Box?
abstract: European regulators are preparing to approve Google’s proposed acquisition of DoubleClick, according to wire reports. The delay was caused by complaints from Microsoft, which may not look so important now that the company is trying to buy Yahoo.

headline: Yahoo Decides to Release a Rosy Forecast
abstract: Yahoo has released a rosy outlook for the next two years, hoping to give investors a better understanding of why the company is not willing to sell itself to Microsoft for less than $45 billion.

headline: Google’s DoubleClick Deal Said to Receive E.U. Approval
abstract: European regulators plan to approve Google‘s proposed $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick without conditions, rejecting complaints by Microsoft that the deal would hurt competition, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Alibaba Said to Shop Yahoo Stake to Avoid Micorosft’s Grasp
abstract: China’s Alibaba Group is seeking investors to buy the 39 percent stake in the Internet company held by Yahoo, according to Reuters, outlining a plan that could stop Microsoft from getting the Alibaba stock.

headline: An Alternative to PDF
abstract: What is this thing called XPS Document Writer in the printer settings on my Vista computer?

headline: Bringing Outlook and Gmail Closer Together
abstract: A new service allows people to use Microsoft’s Outlook and Gmail interchangeably.

headline: I.B.M. Says It Won’t ‘Do a Yahoo’

headline: Enterprise Search Deals: More to Come?
abstract: Microsoft‘s recent acquisition of FAST Search & Transfer is one of the latest and largest deals in the enterprise search space.

headline: Europe Approves Google’s Merger With DoubleClick
abstract: European regulators approved Google’s $3.1 billion takeover of the online advertising company, the final hurdle to a deal that would strengthen Google’s already powerful position on the Web.

headline: Hostility Has Its Rewards
abstract: “They are copying us,” Oracle‘s Larry Ellison says of Microsoft and Electronic Arts. “Others would be foolish not to try.”

headline: The Battle Today for What You Can Do on Your Phone Tomorrow

abstract: As big Web companies expand in the advertising business, can they use information provided when users set up e-mail or other accounts in ads? None do now. AOL, Yahoo, Google and Microsoft all say they could use more data in ads in the future.

headline: Hostility Has Its Rewards
abstract: In Silicon Valley, where entrepreneurialism is a religion, people have long taken a dim view of acquisitions.

headline: A Year of Cashing Out

The focus of the article is transactions — public offerings, mergers or even inheritances — that yielded cold, hard cash.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Hostile Tendencies
abstract: In journalism, three examples usually makes a trend. By that rule, Morgan Stanley has hopped onto the hostile bid bandwagon.

headline: Google Gets Its DoubleClick
abstract: Google said it completed its $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick, a merger that rivals such as Microsoft and Yahoo had fiercely opposed. It took Google nearly a year to close the hotly debated deal: The final obstacle fell away Tuesday when European regulators approved the transaction.

abstract: It turns out people really don’t want to watch ads.

headline: No Break in the Standoff of Microsoft and Yahoo
abstract: The deadline that Microsoft imposed on Yahoo to reach a negotiated merger agreement passed April 26, and the two companies are still not talking.

headline: Microsoft Shows Gains, but Also Weaknesses

headline: Profit Declines, but Microsoft Tops Forecast

headline: Microsoft Reveals a Web-Based Software System

headline: For Microsoft, Holding Yahoo Talent May Be Costly
abstract: A look at that deal suggests that the hidden cost of “flight insurance” against employee defections may also be a reason Microsoft has resisted raising its bid.

abstract: The new service’s software technology, called Clearflow, is an ambitious attempt to apply machine-learning techniques to the problem of traffic congestion.

headline: Yahoo Answers Microsoft With Yet Another No

headline: Yahoo Rejects Microsoft Bid Again
abstract: Responding to a letter from Microsoft that threatened to lower the price of its buyout offer, Yahoo called Microsoft’s bid too low.

headline: Microsoft Said to Be Standing Pat on Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft, which remains steadfast in its refusal to raise its bid for Yahoo, is growing increasingly frustrated with the company’s refusal to enter into negotiations.

abstract: Microsoft, which remains steadfast in its refusal to raise its bid for Yahoo, is growing increasingly frustrated with the company’s refusal to enter into negotiations.

abstract: Yahoo’s is expected to reject merger negotiations with Microsoft and explain why its board believes the current offer price is too low.

abstract: Microsoft has won an international standards designation for its open-document format, ending a yearlong battle with software rivals.

abstract: You can quickly save an error message — and save yourself the trouble of trying to remember what it said when talking to a technical support person.

headline: Commentary: What Microsoft Must Do Next

headline: Why Microsoft Leaked Its Big Yahoo Plan
abstract: Hmmm.

headline: News Corp. May Join Yahoo Bid With Microsoft

The combination, which would join Yahoo, Microsoft’s MSN and News Corporation’s MySpace, would create a behemoth that would upend the Internet landscape, The Times said.

headline: Microsoft’s New Threat to Yahoo: We’ll Buy Someone Else

Far from signaling it might raise its bid for Yahoo, it dangled the threat over the weekend that it could lower its offer and formally go hostile — and possibly both at the same time. For good measure, Steven Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, also set the clock ticking on a three-week deadline for Yahoo to agree to a deal.

And with $29 billion in the company bank account, Steve Ballmer simply isn’t ready to accept that. As a result, it is likely to proceed with its bid for Yahoo despite the many risks.

headline: Yahoo Profit Tops Expectations
abstract: Yahoo’s results give the company ammunition to argue anew that Microsoft’s takeover offer undervalues the company.

headline: Is Yahoo the Odd Man Out?

abstract: Microsoft’s chief executive told employees that the company would announce in “short order” which of three paths it would choose in its pursuit of Yahoo.

headline: Yahoo Chief Says Microsoft Was the Stubborn One

abstract: Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, is said to be considering boosting his company’s bid to $32 a share, but some at Yahoo want more.

abstract: Carl Icahn, the corporate raider turned activist investor, is gambling to bring Microsoft back to the bargaining table and buy Yahoo.

abstract: Carl C. Icahn is considering a proxy fight for seats on Yahoo’s board in hopes of pushing the company to restart talks to sell itself to Microsoft.

abstract: The free downloadable software can index all of your Outlook e-mail and make messages quickly and easily searchable.

headline: Will Microsoft Really Walk?

headline: Microsoft’s Letter to Yahoo

headline: Microsoft-Yahoo: Not Dead Yet?

That leaves all kinds of other possibilities, including joint ventures, partnerships or a deal to acquire just a piece of Yahoo.

abstract: Unable to reach a deal with Microsoft, Yahoo turned to an alternative search advertising partnership with its rival Google, which was announced Thursday afternoon.

abstract: Since Yahoo went public in 1996, the company has had new owners — its shareholders — but it is unclear whether Jerry Yang, the company’s co-founder and chief executive, knows this.

abstract: I have so many programs on my PC that it takes me forever to find them in the Windows XP All Programs menu. Is there a way to customize the order they appear?

abstract: The lawsuit against Yahoo’s board over its rebuff of Microsoft’s $47.5 billion buyout bid was made public by a judge who said that Yahoo had not shown good reason to keep it confidential.

headline: Yahoo’s Post-Microsoft Exodus
abstract: For more than two years, executives and other senior employees have been leaving Yahoo at a steady, persistent trickle.

headline: Yahoo + Google – Microsoft: The Morning After
abstract: As Yahoo’s shares continued to fall Friday, an analysis of the Microsoft-Yahoo-Google situation suggests that the long saga isn’t over yet.

headline: Yahoo + Google – Microsoft: The Morning After
abstract: From our colleagues at Bits:

headline: Microsoft Said to Find Deal for Powerset
abstract: Microsoft has agreed to buy Silicon Valley semantic search engine Powerset, Venture Beat reported. The acquisition price is rumored to be slightly more than $100 million with an announcement expected in July.

headline: Microsoft’s Internal Letter about Yahoogle
abstract: In the wake of Yahoo‘s decision to embrace a Google partnership in its ad search business, many have wondered what Microsoft will do next.

headline: Microsoft Picks Up Ad Tech Firm
abstract: Microsoft said on Wednesday it had purchased privately held digital television advertising technology company Navic Networks. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Has Microsoft Sent Yahoo Into a Death Spiral?
abstract: The more people who leave Yahoo, the less stable it becomes, leading to more questions about its leadership, less new business, delayed products and still more departures.

headline: False Alarm: Microsoft Is NOT in Talks with Yahoo Again
abstract: Yahoo ‘s shares surged Tuesday afternoon after TechCrunch reported that Microsoft is back in talks to buy the company. Yahoo’s stock was up more than 2 percent on the news.

headline: Yahoo Picks Google Deal Over Microsoft
abstract: The talks are dead. Really, this time they are dead.

headline: Microsoft Buys TV Ad Technology Company
abstract: Microsoft buys TV advertising specialist Navic Networks to boost its digital advertising offerings.

headline: Yahoo Investor Asks Microsoft to Take Offer to Shareholders
abstract: An investor with a minority stake in Yahoo urged Microsoft on Thursday to take its most recent offer for a partial investment directly to Yahoo shareholders and prove its merits.

headline: Yahoo to Shareholders: Google Is Better for Us Than Microsoft
abstract: In a letter to stockholders, Yahoo defends its recent decision to sign a search advertising partnership with Google and urges them to vote for the existing board of directors.

headline: Microsoft Won’t Go on Internet Shopping Spree, Chief Says
abstract: Microsoft will not seek to make a spate of other Internet acquisitions in the wake of its failed bid for Yahoo, the company’s chief executive told The Financial Times.

headline: Et Tu, Intel? Chip Giant Won’t Embrace Microsoft’s Windows Vista
abstract: Intel, Microsoft’s long-time partner in the development of the personal computer, has decided that it won’t upgrade most of the computers used by its employees to Microsoft’s Vista operating system.

headline: Sincerely Yours, Carl
abstract: Today, Carl Icahn, the activist investor, sent the following letter to Yahoo’s chairman Roy Bostock.

headline: Icahn vs. Yahoo: The Latest Exchange
abstract: Carl Icahn said that Yahoo should offer to sell itself to Microsoft for nearly $49.5 billion and laid out his plan for the company, where he to succeed in taking control of it. Interestingly, Yahoo didn’t say the price was too low.

headline: And the Award for Best Deal-Maker Goes to …
abstract: Forget about Microsoft being a “disciplined” investor. Or Yahoo successfully defending itself. The best deal maker in the Microsoft-Yahoo saga is clearly Google.

headline: Icahn Wants New Chief for Yahoo
abstract: The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company’s board with his own slate of directors.

headline: Yahoo Embraces Google; What Now, Mr. Icahn?
abstract: Deal talks between Yahoo and Microsoft may really be over this time, but what about Carl C. Icahn’s proxy battle against Yahoo management?

headline: Yahoo Decides Not to Split Its Ad Baby in Two
abstract: Yahoo has ended all talks with Microsoft about a potential transaction. While that’s bad news for Carl Icahn and friends, Yahoo’s decision not to split the company and sell the search advertising piece to Microsoft makes a lot of sense.

headline: Yahoo Stock Outpaces the S.&P. 500
abstract: If a Yahoo shareholder had bought the stock in January at about $19 a share, the price before Microsoft unveiled its original offer to buy the company, he’d still be doing better than the market in general.

headline: Yahoo Shareholders Seek Repeal of Severance Plan
abstract: An employee severance plan put in place by Yahoo to protect workers after a merger with Microsoft should be rescinded immediately, according to a brief filed by plaintiffs in a shareholder lawsuit against Yahoo and its directors.

headline: Yahoo’s Tin Parachutes
abstract: On Thursday, Chancellor William B. Chandler III in the Delaware Court of Chancery unsealed the amended complaint in the Delaware shareholder class action lawsuit filed against Yahoo‘s board. The complaint alleges that Yahoo’s board breached its fiduciary duties by acting to obstruct Microsoft‘s offer to acquire Yahoo.

headline: Icahn to Yahoo: ‘Stop Dancing’ and Sell
abstract: Carl Icahn has picked up his pen again. The activist investor on Friday fired off another letter to Roy Bostock, Yahoo‘s chairman, extending a public war of words in which each side has accused the other of warping the facts to their own ends.

headline: Yahoo Makes New Pitch to Shareholders as Stock Drops Further
abstract: Yahoo once again makes the case to shareholders that its existing directors are better equipped to lead the company forward than an alternate slate proposed by Carl Icahn.

headline: Another Yahoo Overhaul as It Tries to Right Itself
abstract: Under pressure from many shareholders for its poor performance and for its failure to complete a deal with Microsoft, Yahoo is doing something it has done several times before: reorganizing itself.

headline: Yahoo’s Chairman Fires Back at Icahn
abstract: Yahoo’s chairman refutes Carl Icahn’s accusations, saying they are based on “unsubstantiated allegations” that “grossly misstate” the record.

headline: Yahoo Takes the Gloves off in Fight With Icahn
abstract: While Carl C. Icahn has been uncharacteristically mum on whether he plans to proceed with his proxy battle with Yahoo management, the Internet search giant’s top brass has apparently decided to try to cut him off at the pass.

headline: Taking Yang to Task
abstract: In an open letter to Jerry Yang published Saturday, The New York Times’ Joe Nocera lacerates the Yahoo chief to task for his muddled handling of Microsoft’s bid to buy the search giant, as well as his decision to throw his company into Google’s arms.

headline: Icahn Sees ‘Some Merit’ in Yahoo-Google Deal
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire financier who launched a proxy battle in May to replace the board of Yahoo in the wake of its failed deal to be acquired by Microsoft, said on Sunday the subsequent deal Yahoo forged with Google “might have some merit.”

headline: Microsoft Seeks an Ad Friend in Facebook
abstract: It failed in its pursuit of Yahoo. It is paying people to use its search engine. Now Microsoft thinks it has found a source of users for its foundering search service: Facebook.

headline: Head of Microsoft’s Online Efforts Departs
abstract: Kevin Johnson’s exit comes as Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, is shaking up top-level staff in a bid to improve Microsoft’s Internet search and ad business.

headline: Microsoft Profits Are Hurt by Big Expenses
abstract: The company’s profits rose for the quarter based on strong PC sales in developing markets and rising demand from corporate customers.

headline: In Bid for Yahoo, Microsoft Turns More Aggressive
abstract: Shareholders searching for détente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsoft’s new proposal to buy Yahoo’s search business.

headline: Microsoft Is Icahn’s Ally in Pursuit of Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft said on Monday that it was still interested in a deal, as long as Yahoo replaces its board.

headline: Microsoft Buys Online Concern
abstract: Microsoft said on Tuesday that it would buy Powerset Inc., an Internet search company, the latest in a string of acquisitions aimed at bolstering its position online.

headline: Leftover Ad Space? Exchanges Handle the Remnants
abstract: Because there are usually lower fees, buying off exchanges tends to be cheaper -- though more labor-intensive -- than buying through networks.

headline: A Media Powerhouse Everyone and Nobody Knows
abstract: Aviv Nevo took a modest inheritance and parlayed it into a fortune by investing in media and Internet companies.

headline: Exorcise the Demons That Come Preinstalled
abstract: Call it junkware. Or bloatware or demoware or adware. It’s the software preinstalled on new Windows computers. In other words, marketers are using the computer you just bought as a billboard.

headline: Yahoo’s Revenue Rises a Bit, but Profit Falls 18%
abstract: Yahoo said that its revenue in the second quarter grew a sluggish 6 percent from the same period a year earlier as profits fell.

headline: Yahoo Deal Wards Off Proxy Fight
abstract: Yahoo’s board and management earned a reprieve after a weekend deal ended a bruising and acrimonious fight for control of the company with Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Large Yahoo Shareholder Backs Board
abstract: Yahoo got a show of support on Friday from one of its biggest shareholders for its efforts to defend itself against a proxy fight by the activist investor Carl C. Icahn.

headline: In Surprise, 2 Tech Titans Disappoint
abstract: Google and Microsoft issued quarterly results on Thursday that disappointed investors.

headline: Little Interest in Buying AOL as the Unit Is Shopped Again
abstract: Amid all the maneuvering over the fate of Yahoo, Time Warner is again exploring whether it can persuade either Microsoft or Yahoo to buy its AOL unit.

headline: Nintendo and Sony Unveil Games
abstract: The Japanese video game titans announced wide-ranging new games and services at the E3 convention on Tuesday but did not alter their overall strategies in the fast-growing game market.

headline: From the Inside, Jerry Yang Looks Out for Yahoo
abstract: At a mogul retreat, there was sympathy for Yahoo’s founder and new questions about Microsoft’s judgment.

headline: The Afterlife of Windows XP
abstract: Now that Windows XP is retired, will Microsoft still put out security patches for the system?

headline: Google, Zen Master of the Market
abstract: Microsoft challenged the rules on competition and antitrust law. Now, it’s Google’s turn.

headline: Keeping Graphics in Their Place
abstract: It seems easy enough to add images into a Microsoft Word file, but how can these graphics be pasted down so that they do not slip all over the place when text is added?

headline: Digital Pens to Write on Any Paper
abstract: Two new digital pens don’t need special paper to write on. But there are a few glitches.

headline: Microsoft Acquires Powerset
abstract: As rumored last week, Microsoft said on Tuesday that it would buy Powerset The Internet search company acquisitions is the latest in a string of purchases aimed at bolstering Microsoft’s position online.

headline: Microsoft: Machiavellian or Muddled?
abstract: Microsoft’s latest statement that it might or might not be interested in buying all or part of Yahoo if Yahoo’s shareholders replace the company’s board is either cunningly devious or deeply confused.

headline: For Microsoft, There’s No Place Like Enterprise
abstract: Steve Ballmer is charging after Apple and Google, which mainly sell to individuals. He may be ignoring the best path to continued sucess for Microsoft, enterprise customers.

headline: Microsoft Tries to Polish Vista
abstract: Microsoft is said to be starting an expensive campaign to reassure consumers that its Vista operating system isn’t all that bad.

headline: Microsoft Seeks an Ad Friend in Facebook
abstract: Microsoft has tried various tactics to expand its share of the lucrative online search business.

headline: Microsoft Is Icahn’s Ally in Pursuit of Yahoo
abstract: Updated: Carl C. Icahn is claiming a new backer in his proxy fight at Yahoo: Microsoft.

headline: Head of Microsoft’s Online Efforts Departs
abstract: Kevin Johnson, the executive in charge of Microsoft‘s struggling online business, is leaving the company. Microsoft announced Wednesday evening that Mr. Johnson was departing to become chief executive of Juniper Networks.

headline: The New ‘Odd Couple': Microsoft and Icahn
abstract: Yahoo warned shareholders Thursday not to trust the “odd couple” of Microsoft and Carl C. Icahn. The three entities are embroiled in a proxy fight for control of Yahoo’s board.

headline: In Bid for Yahoo, Microsoft Turns More Aggressive
abstract: Shareholders searching for détente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsoft’s new proposal to buy Yahoo’s search business, one the Internet company swiftly rejected on Saturday.

headline: Microsoft Said to Still Pursue Yahoo Deal
abstract: Microsoft is preparing a new bid for Yahoo‘s search business and has approached other media companies about joining it in a deal that would effectively lead to Yahoo’s breakup, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

headline: Can Steve Ballmer Organize Microsoft to Succeed?
abstract: Kevin Johnson leaves Microsoft after having revived neither of his two main units: Windows and Microsoft’s online operation. That may have been too much for one person, particularly because of the way Microsoft organizes itself.

headline: Yahoo Rejects Microsoft-Icahn Search Proposal
abstract: Yahoo said on Saturday night that it had rejected a renewed proposal by Microsoft – together with the activist investor Carl C. Icahn – to buy the beleaguered Internet company’s search business.

headline: AOL Talks with Microsoft or Yahoo Said to Pick Up
abstract: Time Warner‘s discussions to merge or sell its AOL Internet division with Microsoft or Yahoo have taken on new urgency ahead of Yahoo’s Aug. 1 shareholders meeting, a source familiar with the discussions told Reuters on Tuesday.

headline: Microsoft, Yahoo Mull Media Partner Options: Sources
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo have been holding separate talks with other potential media partners after their negotiations with each other broke down, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources.

headline: If Microsoft Opens the Xbox Is an App Store for Apple TV Next?
abstract: Microsoft is opening the Xbox to independent developers. This raises the question about whether all sorts of set top boxes, such as Xbox, Tivo, Apple TV, could be open to applications that offer interactive television and information services as well as games.

headline: Which Way Is Up? Yahoo, Microsoft and Icahn Can’t Agree
abstract: Microsoft, Yahoo and Carl C. Icahn can’t even agree on the basic facts about what happened last weekend. No wonder they can’t engineer some kind of deal.

headline: Advertisers Bite Back at Regulators, and Microsoft Snipes at Google-Yahoo Deal
abstract: The Internet Advertising Bureau is trying to rally small firms to block new regulations on online advertising. Meanwhile, Microsoft criticizes the Google-Yahoo ad partnership ahead of a Senate hearing Tuesday on the deal.

headline: Yahoo’s Stock Falls as Deal Hopes Dim
abstract: Is Yahoo‘s Microsoft premium evaporating?

headline: Listening, But Little Interest, as AOL Is Shopped Again
abstract: Amid all the maneuvering over the fate of Yahoo, Time Warner is again exploring whether it can persuade either Microsoft or Yahoo to buy its AOL unit.

headline: The View From Where Jerry Yang Sits
abstract: At last week’s annual Allen & Company mogul retreat, the topic du jour was the ongoing tussle for control of Yahoo.

headline: Google and Yahoo Defend Ad Alliance at a Hearing
abstract: At a Congressional hearing, Google and Yahoo lawyers argued that their advertising partnership did not violate antitrust laws and would help to keep Yahoo competitive.

headline: No Price Cuts Planned for Playstation 3
abstract: The chairman of Sony, Howard Stringer said the company did not need to lower the price of the game console in response to a possible $50 cut in the Microsoft’s Xbox 360.

headline: A Tale of Two Uninvited Bids
abstract: Yahoo is one of the best-known Internet properties, and Anheuser-Busch is an icon of the beer business. Both companies were the targets of unsolicited takeover bids. In each case, there was an attempt to remove the target company’s board.

headline: Beware of ‘Odd Couple,’ Yahoo Tells Shareholders
abstract: Yahoo is pulling out the stops — and leaning heavily on the bold and underline buttons — in its effort to portray Carl Icahn and Microsoft as an inept tag team intent on short-changing them by selling the company (or its crown jewels) for less than a fair price.

headline: Yahoo’s Mixed Results May Not Tip Scales
abstract: With the slowing economy taking a toll on the online advertising business, Yahoo said Tuesday that its net income dropped by nearly 19 percent in the second quarter from a year ago as revenue grew at a sluggish 6 percent rate.

headline: Ballmer’s Catch-22 Problem With Search Ads
abstract: In the hallways of Microsoft’s analyst conference Thursday, Steve Ballmer teased investors with talk of a top secret online innovation. He spoke later about a plan to put more ads on search pages.

headline: ‘Ludicrous’ vs. ‘Ridiculous': Icahn and Yahoo Trade Barbs
abstract: Say what you want about Yahoo‘s tense dealings with Carl Icahn — at least the two sides have no trouble saying how they really feel about each other.

headline: Hostile Tendencies, or Just a Few Big Feuds?
abstract: With InBev winning its battle for Anheuser-Busch, Yahoo bashing the latest offer from Microsoft and Waste Management making an unsolicited run at rival Republic Services, it may seem as if unsolicited and hostile deals are on the rise. But data provided by Thompson Reuters suggest otherwise.

headline: Dealbook: Legg Mason Backs Yahoo
abstract: Bill Miller, the portfolio manager at Legg Mason whose funds hold a large stake in Yahoo, said Friday that he would vote its shares in favor of electing Yahoo’s current board of directors — and not for the rival slate nominated by Mr. Icahn, who wants to sell Yahoo (or part of it) to Microsoft.

headline: Miller Suggests Yahoo Price Guarantee
abstract: Carl C. Icahn would have more support in his proxy battle against Yahoo if he pledged not to sell the company for less than $33 a share, Legg Mason portfolio manager Bill Miller said on Tuesday.

headline: Blog Posts Poke Holes in ‘Taste Test’ by Microsoft
abstract: Deserved or not, the Windows Vista operating system from Microsoft gets a bad rap. But the company’s effort to repair Vista’s reputation did not win rave reviews either.

headline: From Snapshots, a 3-D View
abstract: Photosynth, a sophisticated technology from Microsoft, turns a bunch of overlapping photos into a 3-D panorama.

headline: Tip of the Week: Deactivating Pesky Alerts in Vista
abstract: Windows Vista is designed to thwart malicious programs, but it often annoys users with constant alerts about updating software or changing settings.

headline: Web Privacy on the Radar in Congress
abstract: As advertisers grow more sophisticated about behavioral targeting, and as online privacy standards vary, regulators and privacy advocates are becoming concerned.

headline: An Energy Diet for Power-Hungry Household PCs
abstract: A group, including Microsoft, has launched an initiative to distribute free software to personal computer owners to help them save on energy costs.

headline: Microsoft Picks Greenfield for $486 Million
abstract: Microsoft on Friday announced its first major deal since failing to buy Yahoo , agreeing to acquire Web-based survey company Greenfield Online for about $486 million.

headline: Why a New Browser From Microsoft Matters
abstract: IE 8 is Microsoft’s answer to the renewed browser challenge. Meanwhile, Firefox is now a credible competitor to IE, with its share of the browser market having climbed to 19 percent.

headline: Microsoft, WPP May Eye Online Advertising Swap
abstract: Microsoft and WPP may be considering swapping components of two richly valued online advertising deals that they struck last year, mergers that in hindsight seem far too pricey, according to Advertising Age.

headline: Microsoft Plans Big Share Buyback, Analyst Says
abstract: After failing to win a bid for Yahoo, Microsoft plans to buy back as much as $20 billion of its stock to boost its flagging share price, according to a top-rated software analyst.

headline: Yahoo Shares Trading Below Pre-Microsoft Offer Price
abstract: Yahoo’s shares closed Thursday at their lowest point since Microsoft made its offer to buy the company, signaling ongoing investor pessimism.

headline: Rumor Control: Why I Can’t Put ‘Tibet’ in My Hotmail Address
abstract: Microsoft is not letting people choose usernames with the word “Tibet” in them when signing up for its online services. But it has an explanation — and it’s not political.

headline: Live From the Anticlimactic Yahoo Meeting
abstract: From our colleages at Bits:

headline: Yahoo’s Advisory Bill Hits $36 Million
abstract: Jerry Yang and his fellow Yahoos have spent plenty of time and energy in recent months dealing with Microsoft’s unsolicited takeover offer and the proxy fight it inspired. Now, Yahoo has shed some light on how much this upheaval has cost in actual dollars and cents — specifically, it revealed the fees it has racked up for outside advice from bankers and lawyers.

headline: A New Battle Is Beginning in Branding for the Web
abstract: Trademark issues may take on a higher profile, fueled by the escalating value of brands in general and trademark holders increasingly trying to assert their rights, especially on the Internet.

headline: Yahoo Is Still Searching for, Well, Yahoo
abstract: Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, has emerged as an unlikely survivor – at least for now, The New York Times says in a look at Mr. Yang’s moves, past and present. He beat back his Microsoft counterpart Steven A. Ballmer, whose offers to buy all or part of Yahoo were considered inadequate by Mr. Yang and his board. And he rebuffed Carl C. Icahn, the activist shareholder, who tried to seize control of Yahoo but settled for three seats on an expanded board.

headline: Pogue’s Mailbag: Questions on TiVo, HDTVs and More
abstract: David Pogue answers reader questions on his love of TiVo, speech-recognition software, Microsoft’s spell checker and more.

headline: Time Warner Blocks a Yahoo Board Choice
abstract: Time Warner said the nomination of Jonathan Miller, the former chairman and chief executive of its AOL Internet unit, violated a noncompete agreement entered with Mr. Miller.

headline: Yahoo’s Anticlimactic Shareholder Meeting
abstract: With Carl Icahn’s proxy fight for control of Yahoo’s board ending in a settlement, Yahoo’s shareholder meeting Friday is an anticlimax.

headline: Time Warner Blocks a Yahoo Board Choice
abstract: While Yahoo had negotiated its way out of a looming showdown with Carl C. Icahn at its annual shareholder’s meeting, which took place Friday, there was drama from different and unexpected quarter: Time Warner.

headline: Bill Gates’s Fund Turns Activist
abstract: Bill Gates’s investment arm has waded into a brewing takeover battle between Waste Management  and Republic Services, asking Waste Management to walk away.

headline: 2 Backed by Icahn to Join Yahoo Board
abstract: Yahoo said on Thursday that it would add the former chief executives of Viacom and Nextel Partners to its board as part of the company’s deal to avoid a proxy fight with the investor Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Google May Write Down AOL Investment
abstract: In an assessment that could lead to a substantial charge against its future profits, Google believes its $1 billion investment in advertising partner AOL is souring.

headline: The New Twist in the Hexion Story
abstract: The proposal by Huntsman shareholders to stump $500 million in no-interest financing to help close its disputed deal with Hexion — and Hexion’s swift and firm refusal — are fascinating new twists in the story, the Deal Professor writes.

headline: Yahoo Appoints 2 Icahn Allies to Its Board
abstract: Yahoo appointed Frank Biondi and John Chapple to its board as part of its settlement of its proxy fight with corporate raider Carl Icahn.

headline: Revised Tally Increases ‘No’ Votes for Yahoo Directors
abstract: Five Yahoo directors, including Jerry Yang, the chief executive, were re-elected to the board with much higher protest votes than previously reported, indicating strong shareholder dissatisfaction with the company’s performance and its failed merger negotiations with Microsoft.

headline: Tip of the Week: Conserving Paper
abstract: You can conserve paper by saving receipts from Web purchases as PDF files instead of printing them.

headline: It’s Showtime for Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo won’t be facing a proxy fight at today’s annual shareholder meeting in San Jose, Calif. But there could still be some harsh words as investors weigh in on the Web company’s rejection of Microsoft‘s takeover bid earlier this year and ask how Jerry Yang, the company’s chief executive and co-founder, plans to reverse its sinking stock and profits.

headline: Time Warner Readies AOL Units Sale, Report Says
abstract: Time Warner has finished preparing to separate AOL’s dial-up Internet business from its advertising and content unit, as the media conglomerate makes plans to potentially sell one or both operations, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

headline: Moelis & Co. Adds Private Equity Partner
abstract: Moelis & Company, the boutique advisory firm, said Wednesday that it has hired a former managing director from Fortress Investment Group‘s private equity team as a partner, in an effort to build out its buyout business.

headline: The Half-Hearted Hostile
abstract: What is it with these hostile tech deals?

headline: Russian Gang Hijacking PCs in Vast Scheme
abstract: The gang has infected thousands of PCs in corporate and government networks with programs that steal passwords and other information, a security researcher has found.

headline: Yahoo Proxy Tally Underreported Votes Against Some Directors
abstract: A firm charged with transmitting investors’ proxy votes said Tuesday that a “truncation error” resulted in an under-reporting of votes withheld from some Yahoo directors at the company’s s annual meeting on Friday.

headline: Paulson & Co. Funds Stalled in July, Report Says
abstract: Paulson & Company, the hedge fund firm whose founder, John Paulson, made a mint on bearish housing bets last year, found the going a bit rougher in July, according to The New York Post.

headline: Revised Tally Increases ‘No’ Votes for Yahoo Directors
abstract: A new tally of its board of directors’ election shows that five Yahoo directors, including the chief executive, Jerry Yang, were re-elected with much higher protest votes than initially released.

headline: Apple Imperfect
abstract: Apple’s recent problems with the iPhone, MobileMe and the Macbook Air aren’t unusual. The company has always struggled with occasional technical issues — just like its competitors.

headline: Yahoo to Let Users Switch Off Customized Ads
abstract: Yahoo said it would allow users to turn off the customization of advertising on the pages of Yahoo.com, as such advertising comes under increased scrutiny.

headline: Could Acquirers Take a Shine to Sun?
abstract: Sun Microsystems‘ worse-than-expected earnings guidance last week did a number on its stock, and The 451 Group is wondering whether the server and software company might be getting so cheap that an acquirer could come knocking.

headline: Cisco Buys E-Mail and Calendaring Start-Up for $215 Million
abstract: Cisco announced Wednesday it will acquire PostPath, a venture-backed start-up that provides open-source email and calendaring software, for $215 million.

headline: How to Travel at a Million Files a Minute
abstract: Things power users can do to make sure their Internet connections are as fast as possible.

headline: Google: We Did Not Erase Maps of Georgia
abstract: Google says it never had enough local data on Georgia to even offer a map.

headline: Is Google a Media Company?
abstract: Knol, Google’s new site where experts share knowledge on a variety of topics, has rekindled fears among some media companies that Google is edging in on their turf.

headline: Google Starts an Advocacy Campaign for More Unlicensed Spectrum
abstract: Google is being upfront about its self interest in building public pressure for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum for new high-speed wireless Internet access. The airwaves, known as “white spaces,” will be unused after TV stations switch to all digital broadcasts next February, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to decide their fate soon.

headline: Reading a Tea Leaf in the Take-Two Saga
abstract: Electronic Arts has hired Joele Frank, a specialist in public relations for mergers and acquisitions. But it’s unclear what her hiring means for the prospects of a deal between EA and Take-Two Interactive.

headline: Netbook Prices Are Now Falling
abstract: PC maker Acer saidit is cutting the price of its Aspire “netbook” to $349 from $399. It’s cutting the price of another netbook, the Linpus Linux Lite, to $329 from $379. The entire category of so-called netbooks – personal computers designed primarily for Internet use – may be headed over a price cliff, according to industry analysts.

headline: Moving Heavy Data
abstract: I need to move an enormous collection of music and photos from an old Mac to a brand-new one. How can I move my stuff?

headline: Georgia Takes a Beating in the Cyberwar With Russia
abstract: In addition to the bloody shooting war between Georgia and Russia, there is a quieter battle going on in cyberspace.

headline: Time Warner to Split AOL Ahead of Possible Deal
abstract: Time Warner said it would split AOL’s dial-up Internet and advertising businesses into separate divisions by early 2009, a move that could make a sale or merger of either business easier.

headline: Waste Management Raises Bid for Republic
abstract: Waste Management on Monday raised its unsolicited bid for a rival Republic Services, to $6.73 billion in cash as it seeks to wrest its smaller rival from an already-agreed deal with Allied Waste.

headline: Palm, Once a Leader, Seeks Path in Smartphone Jungle
abstract: Palm is trying to revive itself as business users have embraced the BlackBerry and consumers have fallen in love with the iPhone.

headline: Speak Up, a Computer Is Listening
abstract: Ever since “Star Trek,” we’ve dreamed of being able to give our computers spoken orders. NaturallySpeaking 10, available Thursday, takes some baby steps in the right direction.

headline: Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard and Nike Announce Buyback Plans for Shares
abstract: Microsoft said it would buy back $40 billion of its shares, H.P. would repurchase $8 billion in shares and Nike said it would take on $5 billion.

headline: Echoing the Campaign of a Rival, Microsoft Aims to Redefine ‘I’m a PC’
abstract: Microsoft’s new advertising campaign is an audacious embrace of the disdainful label that Apple has gleefully affixed onto users of Microsoft products: “I’m a PC.”

headline: Microsoft Works to Perfect Windows Vista
abstract: Faced with Windows Vista’s image problem, Microsoft has been working for more than a year to change the experience of buying and using computers that run its software.

headline: Microsoft Faces New Browser Foe in Google
abstract: Google will release a free Web browser called Chrome that the company said would challenge Internet Explorer.

headline: Rescuing a Web Password
abstract: The password for my Web-based mail account doesn’t work anymore and I can’t get into it. If it got hacked, what can I do?

headline: Cisco Tries to Break Out of the Data Center Role
abstract: These days, Cisco is peddling e-mail software, video conferencing systems, cable TV boxes, and other products known as unified communications.

headline: A New Zune for Serious Music Fans
abstract: Apple introduces new iPods and Microsoft offers a Zune with more bells and whistles.

headline: Attachment Woes in Vista Mail
abstract: I am having trouble getting file attachments with the Windows Mail program in Windows Vista. What might be the problem?

headline: Search Giant Wants a Share of Browser Market
abstract: Google fears that Microsoft could leverage its dominance of the browser market to promote its search business.

headline: Tip of the Week: Faking Text in Word
abstract: Creating a document in Microsoft Word and need to put in sample text to hold the space until the real copy arrives?

headline: Serious Potential in Google’s Browser
abstract: Google’s minimalist Chrome browser is built for a future that blurs the lines of Web and desktop.

headline: Microsoft Migrates From Servers to Supercomputers
abstract: Microsoft unveils improvements to its version of Windows for high-powered supercomputers, a market in which the software maker lags.

headline: Microsoft Refugee Becomes a Social Technologist
abstract: Will Poole, a veteran Microsoft executive, is leaving to focus on non-profit pursuits. His first new project: $70 computers for schoolchildren.

headline: Oracle’s Homegrown Push to Out-Collaborate Microsoft
abstract: Oracle makes its third attempt to go after Microsoft’s collaboration software with a new suite called Beehive.

headline: Forget Apple — Let’s Speculate About the Microsoft Zune
abstract: With Apple expected to unveil new versions of its iPod music player next week, what’s new with Microsoft’s Zune player? And do customers really care?

headline: Microsoft, H.P. and Nike Announce Buyback Plans for Shares
abstract: Eager to project confidence in turbulent markets, Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard and Nike announced plans separately on Monday to buy back a combined $53 billion of their companies’ stock — a move, The New York Times’s Michael M. Grynbaum noted, that could benefit shareholders and attract new investors.

headline: Hey, Microsoft Fans: What Would Your Vista Ad Be?
