abstract: The processor, named TrueNorth, may eventually excel at calculations that stump today’s supercomputers.

headline: Games for Your Itchy Trigger Finger
abstract: First-person shooters, from retro to sophisticated. Also, Foursquare’s Swarm app comes to Windows Phone.

headline: China Says Mercedes-Benz Violated Antitrust Rules in Pricing
abstract: The government said that prices for parts and maintenance for Mercedes vehicles had been set at exorbitant levels, state news media said.

headline: Amazon, Its Friends and Critics
abstract: The dispute between Amazon and Hachette has caused the usually reticent retailer start talking but made the publisher shut up. Some of the best commentary is coming from authors in the middle.

headline: Finding an App to Manage Passwords
abstract: Also, getting Kindle tech support abroad, and language translations directly from the Google search box.

headline: Apps for Sharing Secrets and Gossip
abstract: Free apps like Secret, Whisper, Random and Randid give users an opportunity to learn, be shocked or amused, or find inspiration.

headline: What Cars Did for Today’s World, Data May Do for Tomorrow’s
abstract: No matter how cutting-edge it may seem, almost every new product you see is part of a greater whole. At its heart is the cheap collection, shipment and computation of data.

headline: Morning Agenda: Standard Chartered’s Backsliding Woes
abstract: Standard Chartered to will pay a $300 million fine for backsliding. | A default swaps association has postponed a payout auction on Argentine bonds. | Grappling with the cost of corporate gadflies. | Bank of America has a sole chief operating officer.

headline: Echoes From 15 Years Ago: Ad-Supported Services, Sluggish Speeds and More
abstract: News from August 1999, when the tech industry was reaching the heights of its first boom, gives many insights into today’s tech industry. Yahoo was push ad-supported services, and consumers were complaining about sluggish Internet speeds.

headline: China Fines Japanese Auto Parts and Bearings Makers in Price Rigging
abstract: A regulator fined 10 of 12 companies a total of $200 million, a record for China. The penalties coincided with deteriorating relations between Tokyo and Beijing.

headline: Uber and Lyft Have Become Indistinguishable Commodities
abstract: Though Uber and Lyft have become bitter enemies recently, in many places, they both offer ubiquitous, cheap and mostly high-quality service.

headline: Adviser to Government in Chinese Investigation of Qualcomm Is Ousted
abstract: The adviser to a government group received “large payments” from the technology company, whose pricing is being investigated, state news media said.

headline: New Buying Strategy as Facebook and Google Transform Into Web Conglomerates
abstract: A buying spree among technology companies has revolutionized the venture capital business model, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor.

headline: Simplifying the Bull: How Picasso Helps to Teach Apple’s Style
abstract: The tech company’s highly secretive internal training program is like its products: meticulously planned, with polished presentations and a gleaming veneer that masks a great deal of effort.

headline: Barney Harford of Orbitz, on Finding a Team That Fits
abstract: Barney Harford, chief of Orbitz Worldwide, appreciates workers with deep expertise in an area who also have curiosity about their overall organization.

headline: Smartphones Overstate Their Social Intelligence
abstract: With access to our calendars, contacts and location, phones should be able to communicate with great intelligence, but often buzz at just the wrong time.

headline: Bearing Down on Data Upstarts
abstract: Box, Dropbox and Hightail are rethinking their core business models, focusing on specific industries or bolstering customer service.

headline: Wealth Managers Enlist Spy Tools to Map Portfolios
abstract: Companies like Addepar are using data-filtering techniques honed at spy agencies to help track and value clients’ diverse holdings.

headline: The Muddled Road to Overhauling Corporate Taxes
abstract: Most everyone agrees the corporate tax system is badly broken, but the debate over companies moving overseas shows how hard it will be to make changes.

headline: Harper’s Publisher Standing Firm in His Defense of Print and Paywall
abstract: John R. MacArthur, of Harper’s Magazine, is part of a small group of publishers who say they believe that the Internet is bad for writers and readers.

headline: An Emerging Price War in the World of Investment Advice
abstract: The pricing from big-name firms is particularly striking given the recent emergence of low-cost start-ups like Betterment and Wealthfront.

headline: Microsoft Windows 10 Displays a Familiar Look
abstract: Microsoft believes the next version of its operating system is such a big change that it is calling the software Windows 10, skipping the more logical product name, Windows 9.

headline: Microsoft Begins a Push Into the Polling World
abstract: The company, having done polls through video games in 2012, plans to have its automated digital assistant survey people through their mobile phones.

headline: Hurd: Oracle Takes On Microsoft in the Cloud
abstract: The opening keynote at Oracle’s annual conference will be about its“unique opportunity to be the leader of the next generation of cloud,” according to Mark Hurd, the new co-chief.

headline: Minecraft Is Expected to Be Acquired by Microsoft
abstract: Acquiring the game would give Microsoft control of an online world that has defied many modern conventions to become a blockbuster success.

headline: Microsoft Says It Will Pay $2.5 Billion for Company That Created Minecraft
abstract: Adding the world-building computer game could help bolster Microsoft’s Windows series of devices, including phones and tablets.

headline: Microsoft Introduces Three New Smartphones
abstract: The devices are the first the company has released since the completion of the acquisition of Nokia’s cellphone business.

headline: Microsoft Sees More Than Fun in a Game Like Minecraft
abstract: Microsoft’s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that gaming is central to many people’s lives, serving as an engaging mode of entertainment or merely a time killer.

headline: Copying PC Photos to an iPhone
abstract: Plus, what you can back up on a Nexus tablet.

headline: Right-Clicking Without a Mouse
abstract: Plus, how to turn your iPad off with a timer.

headline: With Talko App, Ray Ozzie Creates a Permanent Voice
abstract: Ray Ozzie, onetime chief software architect at Microsoft, has a way to make phone conversations as permanent and searchable as other Internet communication.

headline: Flipping Scanned Images
abstract: Slide images scanned upside-down or in reverse can be corrected with Windows or OS X programs, or with image-editing software.

headline: China Clamps Down on Web, Pinching Companies Like Google
abstract: Chinese authorities have tightened censorship over Internet traffic in recent weeks, and Google and its services are particularly affected.

headline: Defragmenting the Hard Drive on a Windows PC
abstract: Plus, backing up an iPhone’s photos.

headline: Daily Report: In Popular Games Like Minecraft, Tech Titans See Potential Beyond Fun
abstract: Microsoft’s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that games are central to many people’s lives, as players can spend months building estates and entire countries.

headline: Intel Shares More of Its Extreme Makeover
abstract: Apple wasn’t the only big tech outfit with something to talk about on Tuesday. Intel met with developers to discuss how it is changing from a chip-centric company to one with a variety of products and services.

headline: During a Season for New Devices, a Tough Market for Smartphone Makers
abstract: At the IFA consumer electronics show in Berlin, most of the major smartphone makers introduced new devices, features or pricing in attempts to distinguish themselves within a crowded industry.

headline: Opposition Grows in Europe to Google Antitrust Proposal
abstract: Microsoft and two trade groups for German publishers said the plan to reduce Google’s dominance of the search market was inadequate.

headline: Western Companies Appear to Push Back Against Chinese Crackdown
abstract: The U.S.-China Business Council issued a report taking aim at China’s antimonopoly law, highlighting ways it says enforcement could be improved.

headline: Former Microsoft Executive and Obama Adviser Joins Venture Firm
abstract: Kurt DelBene worked at one of the technology industry’s largest companies and helped clean up one of the government’s biggest technology messes. Now he’s focusing on smaller organizations, joining a venture capital firm, Madrona Venture Group, to help start-ups.

headline: Seattle Start-Up Factory Hires Former Amazon and Microsoft Executive
abstract: Ivy Softworks, a new start-up factory in Seattle, is seeking to create a better way of forming new tech companies. And now it has hired Brian Valentine, a prominent engineer and executive who worked for years at Microsoft and Amazon.

headline: Minecraft’s Creator, the Ambivalent Billionaire
abstract: After Microsoft’s $2.5 billion agreement to buy his company, the creator of Minecraft has written one of the most unusual, refreshingly honest letters ever written by a company founder who just became incredibly rich.

headline: Morning Agenda: Dollar General Goes Hostile
abstract: Dollar General takes its bid for Family Dollar directly to shareholders. | Microsoft near a deal for the maker of Minecraft. | Fed’s newly proposed rules put pressure on banks. | Detroit clears a bankruptcy hurdle.

headline: Tech Firms and Lobbyists: Now Intertwined, but Not Eager to Reveal It
abstract: The industry ranks near the bottom of a list that grades large corporations on how well they publicly disclose political activities.

headline: European Commission Delays Google Antitrust Settlement After Competitors’ Complaints
abstract: A plan to give competitors more equal status in the results displayed by Google searches faces further scrutiny after objections by companies like Microsoft and German publishing groups.

headline: Amazon Refreshes Its Kindle Line
abstract: The updated tablets aim at a variety of audiences: from adults who want to work on their tablets to children.

headline: Google Is Target of European Backlash on U.S. Tech Dominance
abstract: Regulators want Google to change its algorithm. If Google doesn’t comply, the settlement it reached with Europe this year may be voided and it will face antitrust charges.

headline: Examining the Amazon Way
abstract: Amazon’s accomplishments are dwarfed only by its ambitions. A former executive talks about the potential and the perils as the retailer enters its third decade, as well as why the dispute with Hachette is so important.

headline: Today in Small Business: For New S.B.A. Chief, the Honeymoon May Be Over
abstract: California passes a “Yelp Bill.” Employee health premiums rise only 3 percent. And how scared is the “dumb-watch” industry?

headline: China’s Antitrust Campaign Seen as Possible Breach of W.T.O. Rules
abstract: The United States Chamber of Commerce, in a report on Beijing’s aggressive enforcement of its antimonopoly law, raises the prospect of a formal trade complaint.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Says Wireless Broadband Could Get Stricter Oversight
abstract: Tom Wheeler said the commission was seriously considering subjecting mobile carriers to the same net neutrality regulations as providers of wired Internet service.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Bacon Bowl
abstract: How Alibaba shared the wealth with employees. Rewarding customers for writing negative Yelp reviews. And why it’s definitely time to take a break!

headline: Making the Leap From Web to Mobile Apps Easier
abstract: Most people don’t like to download mobile apps. But when they do, they spend nearly all of their time in them. A new start-up called DWNLD is promising to make it cheaper and easier for publishers to convert their sites into attractive apps.

headline: Tech Giants Embrace the Smart Home, but Consumers Remain Skeptical
abstract: At a consumer electronics conference in Berlin, a number of companies are demonstrating technology meant to connect parts of the home to computers and the Internet. But do consumers want these devices?

headline: The Food Start-Up Hampton Creek Adds Tech Talent
abstract: Hampton Creek is one of a growing array of start-ups trying to bring Silicon Valley innovation to the food business. The company has been adding high-profile talent from the technology business in recent months, the latest being Ali Partovi, an investor and entrepreneur who will be its chief strategy officer.

headline: Today in Small Business: A Positive Review on Yelp Goes Viral
abstract: Why the fast-food industry is struggling. Why so many job postings are “ridiculous.” And do older workers impede entrepreneurship?

headline: News Corp. and Google in a War of Words
abstract: The publishing giant accused the search giant of being a “vast, powerful, often unaccountable bureaucracy,” and Google fired back with a tabloid reference to a hamster sandwich.

headline: Today in Small Business: Best and Worst Cities for Hispanic Entrepreneurs
abstract: Why operating cash flow is more important than net profit. Can gas pumps be smart?

headline: Today in Small Business: Paper or Plastic?
abstract: Mayor de Blasio plans to sign an executive order expanding New York City’s living wage law. Macy’s is hiring for the holidays. How to lose $1 million a month.

headline: Alibaba, With Its I.P.O., Mints Millionaires and Risk-Takers
abstract: Alibaba has generously handed out stock to all levels of workers, creating a wealth diaspora rarely seen in China.

headline: How to Sign Up for a Skype Number
abstract: With this feature, people without Skype accounts can call those with accounts from landlines and cellphones. Also, using Spotlight to find files on a Mac.

headline: Toward a Childproof Internet
abstract: A handful of entrepreneurs are trying to build web services for young children, including at a company called Kuddle, which has a mobile photo-sharing application aimed at the elementary and middle school set.

headline: Salesforce Boss Tips His Hand on Company’s Big News
abstract: Maybe the chief executive of Salesforce did himself a favor when he gave away one of his big surprises for an upcoming show. His data analysis cloud for the masses is likely one of many, with more on the way. Can his be different?

headline: Today in Small Business: When You Don’t Love Your Company Name
abstract: How being videotaped changes employee behavior. How RadioShack missed almost every opportunity. And does Urban Outfitters offend on purpose?

headline: How to Find Special Characters on an iPad
abstract: Plus, copying files from an Android tablet.

headline: 100 Million Smart Things: A Conversation With Scott McGregor of Broadcom
abstract: The chief executive of Broadcom predicts a future of total facial recognition, DNA-based signatures and chips in our brains, and he wants his company’s semiconductors to be a part of all of it.

headline: HP Is Committed to the Cloud, Even if It Kills
abstract: Hewlett-Packard didn’t pay all that much for Eucalyptus, a maker of open source cloud computing software. But the deal said H.P. is willing to mess with its existing business lines.

headline: Nominee for European Digital Job Explains Positions in Hearing
abstract: Günther Oettinger, the nominee to be the European Union’s next digital economy commissioner, emphasized that he wanted to create greater connections across the 28-member bloc.

headline: Morning Agenda: Allergan’s Olive Branch
abstract: Allergan made a small measure of peace with its would-be acquirers. | Calpers said it would eliminate all of its hedge fund investments. | Fielding strong demand, Alibaba Group raised the price range for its I.P.O. | Beer brewers could be contemplating another round of deal-making.

headline: With New Ad Platform, Facebook Opens Gates to Its Vault of User Data
abstract: The company is introducing an advertising platform that will allow marketers to use its vast knowledge of consumers on other websites and mobile apps.

headline: Andrew Kay, Pioneer in Computing, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Kay’s company Kaypro produced the Kaypro II computer, a hit in the 1980s, but fell into bankruptcy after being left behind by an industry coalescing around the MS-DOS operating system.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Leaps Into Wearable Fitness
abstract: Microsoft is joining other companies who see wearables as a way into the wellness business without all the red tape that comes from being a true medical company.

headline: Microsoft Offers Tantalizing Signs of Progress
abstract: The software company’s acquisition of Nokia helped it beat estimates, but integration costs reduced profit.

headline: Microsoft Jumps Into the Growing Market for Wearable Fitness Technology
abstract: Microsoft is joining the companies who see wearables as a way into the wellness business without all the red tape that comes from being a true medical company.

headline: For Microsoft, Cloud Business Looks More Promising Than Mobile
abstract: Despite being a laggard in cloud computing, Microsoft has established real credibility, and now runs twice as many data centers as Amazon and six times as many as Google.

headline: Daily Report: Russian Hackers Exploit Flaw in Microsoft Windows to Spy on Governments
abstract: Russian hackers used a bug in Microsoft Windows to spy on several Western governments, NATO and the Ukrainian government, according to a computer security firm.

headline: Microsoft’s Nadella Sets Off a Furor on Women’s Pay
abstract: Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, implied during a speech on Thursday that women should not ask for pay raises, a statement that quickly put him in the hot seat.

headline: Russian Hackers Used Bug in Microsoft Windows for Spying, Report Says
abstract: The targets were often linked to the standoff in Ukraine, said iSight Partners, the computer security firm that released the report.

headline: Microsoft and Other Firms Pledge to Protect Student Data
abstract: The participating companies are publicly committing themselves not to sell information on kindergartners through 12th graders.

headline: Turning the PC Into a DVR
abstract: Plus, donating a Windows XP computer.

headline: Coming of Age in Cloud Computing
abstract: Cloud computing, particularly in the big rental businesses of Microsoft and Amazon, has been criticized as undependable and tough to manage. A number of recent announcements suggest that some companies are trying to address the issue.

headline: Exporting Video From iPhoto
abstract: And tips on removing malicious software from browsers.

headline: Tech Giants’ Earnings and Eurozone Bank Stress Tests
abstract: Apple, IBM, Microsoft and Yahoo will report quarterly results, and the results of the eurozone banks’ tests are approaching.

headline: Poodle Bug Marks Third Major Security Flaw Discovered This Year
abstract: On Tuesday, researchers disclosed details of a security bug that could make web browsing sessions on a public network vulnerable to hackers.

headline: Hiding History in Firefox
abstract: Plus, how to make the move from the iPhoto app in iOS 8.

headline: Salesforce Makes Its Big Data Move
abstract: Salesforce kicked off its annual conference with a product aimed at developers who want to build visualization tools for sales and marketing people. That’s probably a big and underserved market.

headline: Satya Nadella’s Advice on Raises Stirs Wider Discussion Among Women
abstract: Even as many barriers have fallen for working women, they continue to be treated differently on the job, particularly when negotiating a raise.

headline: Today in Small Business: the Rookie Cookie
abstract: A restaurant learns what happens when you tell customers to pay what God wants them to pay, Microsoft’s chief executive says it’s O.K. for women to ask for a raise, and new restaurants are making Detroit a “culinary oasis.”

headline: Decline in PC Sales Starts to Slow; Largest Makers See Growth
abstract: Analysts say that the PC business is shrinking less slowly than in the last couple of years. It may even be poised for a period of moderate growth, at least for the large companies. Smaller ones may be in trouble.

headline: Antitrust Nominee in Europe Promises Scrutiny of Big Tech Companies
abstract: Margrethe Vestager, the nominee to become the next antitrust chief for the European Union, signaled that she would look more deeply into whether amassing data entrenched the strength of digital companies like Google.

headline: Longtime Microsoft Executive Opens Cloud Database Start-Up
abstract: At Microsoft, Bob Muglia helped build the company’s server and tools business into a $17 billion-a-year juggernaut. Now he’s running a cloud database start-up that has raised $26 million in funding.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Announces Breakup Plan as Technology Landscape Shifts
abstract: The Silicon Valley pioneer said it would divide in two, with one company for its data businesses and another focusing on PCs and printers.

headline: A.M.D. Names Lisa Su as Chief Executive
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices, the largest maker of computer semiconductors after Intel, said on Wednesday that it had appointed Lisa Su as its new president and chief executive.

headline: Today in Small Business: Dubious Excuses for Calling in Sick
abstract: What’s the worst excuse for calling in sick you have ever heard?

headline: With Promotion, Sundar Pichai Becomes Google’s Product Chief
abstract: The move makes Mr. Pichai the second-most powerful person at the company.

headline: Income at Intel Climbs 12% on PC Sales
abstract: For all the new business Intel is pursuing, chips for PCs brought in the vast bulk of the company’s third-quarter revenue.

headline: Quip: Make Numbers Dynamic, Too
abstract: Quip makes apps for smartphones and tablets that lets lots of people collaborate on documents. Now it is adding spreadsheets at no charge. Besides some heroic engineering – this spreadsheet has over 400 formulas, and can be popped into a document but remain dynamic – Quip’s design principles show where work is going.

headline: Paul Allen to Give $100 Million to Tackle Ebola Crisis
abstract: The Microsoft co-founder said he hoped to help coordinate disparate fund-raising efforts.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Is Said to Be Planning a Split of Businesses
abstract: The company is expected to divide into two entities — one that consists of its PC business and another that is more enterprise-focused, people familiar with the matter said.

headline: A History of Innovation, With a Few Blind Spots
abstract: By chronicling the building blocks of technological advances, Walter Isaacson’s “The Innovators” hopes to teach us about the nature of innovation, Jonathan A. Knee writes in a review, the debut Book Entry column.

headline: Daily Report: Hewlett-Packard to Break Into Two Companies
abstract: The company, considered a foundational institution of Silicon Valley, said in a news release that it intended to divide itself into a company aimed at business technology and one that sells personal computers and printers.

headline: Amazon Spends and Grows, but Still Wants for Money
abstract: Amazon, which announces its quarterly earnings on Thursday, is likely to hit $100 billion a year in revenue next year. But profit seems as elusive as ever.

headline: New Apple Tool Checks iPhones for ‘Kill Switch’ Security
abstract: Starting next summer, a new law will require every smartphone sold in California to include a so-called kill switch that renders the device unusable if it is reported lost or stolen. Apple now has a tool to check whether an Apple device has a kill switch turned on.

headline: Atlanta Hawks Hire Goldman and Inner Circle Sports to Sell Team
abstract: The Atlanta Hawks’ hiring of the investment banks comes nearly two months after the basketball franchise’s majority owner drew criticism for remarks about the team’s black fans.

abstract: A guide to co-working in New York. If you want to be a great leader, start acting weirder. Why millions of new blue-collar jobs will open up over the next few years.

headline: Today in Small Business: A Lesson in Pricing
abstract: Is franchising a scam? A start-up gets a valuation of $2 billion. Should car manufacturers be allowed to sell directly to consumers?

headline: Moving a Music Library to Linux
abstract: Plus, making text bigger in Google Maps.

headline: Shining a Light on Nosy Apps
abstract: Plus, creating a fund-raising page on Facebook.

headline: Ireland to Phase Out ‘Double Irish’ Tax Break Used by Tech Giants
abstract: The provision known as the “double Irish,” used by companies like Google to reduce their bills, has been under scrutiny from European Union regulators.

headline: Madison Square Garden Company to Explore Split
abstract: A breakup would separate the New York Knicks and Rangers professional sports teams from the company’s live entertainment business.

headline: Stephen Colbert Has a Mock Feud With Google Over Search Results
abstract: Stephen Colbert chided the search engine for getting his height wrong, a situation that highlighted challenges about the accuracy and sources of its information.

headline: IBM and SAP: A Cloud Pact That Solves Problems and Holds Promise
abstract: The deal suggests that the demand for cloud-delivered software from mainstream corporate customers is accelerating.

headline: Today in Small Business: Start-Ups With a Social Mission

headline: Today in Small Business: The Coolest New Businesses in Brooklyn
abstract: Uber for Business. How to work from home more effectively. Is it legal for bosses to use social media tools to check backgrounds when hiring?

headline: G.M. Tech Center Becomes National Historic Landmark
abstract: The National Park Service awarded the designation to G.M.’s research campus in Warren, Mich., as one of Eero Saarinen’s most significant designs.

headline: AT&T Wants You to Put Down the Phone, and Head for the Cloud
abstract: Even for a company that has been through a lot, this is an impressive change: AT&T seems to want to kill desk phones, rip up its network of traditional switches, connect to cloud computing and even build software-based systems.

headline: Twitter Sues U.S. Government Over Data Disclosure Rules
abstract: The social media giant wants to loosen restrictions on what it is allowed to tell users about government information requests.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘We’re the Uber of Whatever!’
abstract: Google is preparing to take on Apple Pay. How one company pampers its workers. Amazon is likely to top $100 billion in revenue next year — but hasn’t made a quarterly profit since 2011.

headline: Amazon Shops for Real Estate in New York City
abstract: Real estate executives said the building would be used for offices and a distribution center.

headline: Spanish as a Second Language, With the Accent on Fun
abstract: Plenty of smartphone apps offer worthwhile and entertaining lessons.

headline: IBM’s Watson Attracts Commercial Clients
abstract: IBM’s Watson unit is announcing its first wave of commercial partners, as the company tries to turn the impressive technology into a real business.

headline: Microsoft Billionaire Reboots Seattle Movie Temple
abstract: What do you do when you are a billionaire and a movie buff? If you are Paul G. Allen, you turn the iconic theater you already own into a state-of-the-art theater.

headline: Microsoft’s Nadella Talks About the Future of Office
abstract: Satya Nadella, the company’s chief executive, discusses how Microsoft’s focus on helping people “get stuff done” distinguishes it from competitors like Google and Apple.

headline: Microsoft Hopes This Video Game Collection Wings Its Way to Success
abstract: A campaign that rivals the promotion of a major movie is underway for Halo: The Master Chief Collection, a set of four Xbox video games.

headline: Microsoft, Changing Tack, Makes Office Suite Free on Mobile
abstract: In a sign of the seismic changes underway in the tech industry, Microsoft will give away the software for iPads, iPhones and Android tablets.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Offering Free Mobile Version of Office
abstract: The free software for iPads, iPhones and Android tablets will do most of the most essential tasks done with the computer versions of the product, whose applications include Word, Excel and PowerPoint.

headline: Microsoft Band Is a Welcome Surprise in the Wearable Market
abstract: The company’s new wearable device may be the most flexible of its kind available now.

headline: AirDrop Alternatives for Windows and Android
abstract: Plus, minimizing the translucent look of windows and menus in OS X Yosemite.

headline: What Cloud Computing Means to Your Job
abstract: The next big technology migration will change how workplaces are organized. Bad news, middle managers: You’re going to get less important.

headline: With New Tablet, Nokia Returns to Devices
abstract: The N1, with a 7.9 inch display and run on Google’s Android operating system, will pit the Finnish company against its longtime ally Microsoft.

headline: Assessing Space on a Computer’s Hard Drive
abstract: Plus, comparing HDTV with ultrahigh-definition.

headline: Ireland Vies to Remain Silicon Valley’s Low-Tax Home Away From Home
abstract: Though Ireland has been under international pressure to close loopholes that have drawn companies like Google and Microsoft, the country is still touting its low-tax appeal.

headline: How to See a Full Web Address on the Safari Browser
abstract: The browser’s settings can be changed, or users can click on the address field. Also, a considering the value of a touch-screen PC.

headline: Amazon Moves to Extend Cloud-Computing Dominance
abstract: Amazon Web Services already has the largest share of the worldwide cloud-computing market, and is looking for ways to expand the range of services it offers.

headline: Gift From Ballmer Will Expand Computer Science Faculty at Harvard
abstract: Mr. Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief executive, will make a financial contribution to Harvard that will enable the school to expand its computer science faculty by about 50 percent.

headline: Firefox Makes Yahoo Its New Default for Search, Replacing Google
abstract: Marissa Mayer, Yahoo’s chief executive, signaled with the deal with Mozilla that she still believes search is a part of the company’s future.

headline: E.U. Parliament Passes Measure to Break Up Google in Symbolic Vote
abstract: While the vote poses no immediate threat to the company, it symbolizes the growing resentment in Europe toward the American technology titan.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘The Yelp of Business Software’
abstract: The rush is on for a new breed of marijuana capitalist in New York. How even a profitable company can run out of cash. Binding referendums in several red states Tuesday would raise the state minimum wage above the $7.25 an hour mandated by the federal government.

headline: Google to Quadruple Computer Science Prize Winnings to $1 Million
abstract: The Turing prize for computer science will be quadrupled to $1 million, a jump funded by Google.

headline: European Antitrust Regulators to Hold Discussions With Google’s Rivals
abstract: The new competition commissioner for the European Union says she wants to hear what companies most concerned about Google’s practices have to say before resolving the union’s longstanding antitrust case.

headline: How to Use a VPN
abstract: Plus, troubleshooting “file in use” messages.

headline: Facebook Testing Collaboration Tools for Businesses
abstract: The company is testing a new product called Facebook@Work, which will allow users to collaborate on projects through group chats and document collaboration with co-workers.

headline: Today in Small Business: Veteran-Owned Businesses
abstract: More business-related election returns. After 20 years, the banner ad is finally in decline. And there’s a Bitcoin-only cafe in Prague.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, miscellaneous news from advertising agencies and more.

headline: Today in Small Business: Election Fallout
abstract: The private sector created 230,000 jobs in October. New York is becoming doughnut city. And how did Taylor Swift sell a million copies of her album in a week? It’s called #taylurking.

headline: Samsung Turns to BlackBerry for Better Security
abstract: BlackBerry has boasted that its network and software, as well as special hardware within its phones, provide a level of security for corporate and government users that its competitors cannot match.

headline: Florida and F.T.C. Accuse Firms of Deceptively Selling Tech Support
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission and the State of Florida say the companies used software designed to trick consumers into thinking their computers had bugs or errors that needed to be fixed.

headline: Churchill Downs to Buy Big Fish Games for Up to $885 Million
abstract: Churchill Downs, which owns casinos and racetracks, has become the latest company to make a bold move into mobile game.

headline: GitHub Hits the Cloud
abstract: The popular method of creating software says its business version will be available for direct use on the most popular public cloud. GitHub also said it now has 17 million repositories, or projects, on file. At the start of the year it had 10 million.

headline: Europe Takes Aim at Deals Created to Escape Taxes
abstract: As global authorities ramp up efforts to close tax loopholes, companies are lobbying against proposed reforms.

headline: Today in Small Business: Paternity Leave
abstract: The economy is producing steady gains on jobs. Oyster farming is booming. And here’s why the new soda tax in Berkeley, Calif., may not reduce obesity.

headline: Today in Small Business: Avoiding Bad Yelp Reviews
abstract: Did this “cereal milk” start-up target the wrong market? Should small businesses have to offer health insurance to part-time workers? The ultimate list of start-up competitions, hackathons, business-plan contests and more.

headline: Dell’s Life After Wall Street
abstract: A year after a grueling fight with the investor Carl C. Icahn, Michael S. Dell says he is very happy to have the computer company that bears his name back to himself.

headline: Today in Small Business: Demise of the Internet Sales Tax
abstract: American retail workers steal more than shoplifters. Pinterest says its male users have doubled in the past year. A company gets $100 million to remake the cash register.

headline: Google Chromecast Adds Games

abstract: With its vast share of the industry’s profits, Apple was the target at the Mobile World Congress, where Samsung and Microsoft are trying to position their products as business tools.

headline: Sony Reveals Its Waterproof 10-Inch Tablet, and a Midrange Phone the U.S. Can’t Have
abstract: The 10-inch Sony Xperia Z4 tablet is waterproof and dustproof; boasts extremely long battery life and has powerful specs. The Xperia M4 Aqua smartphone is also waterproof and has a two-day battery life, but it will not be sold in the United States.

headline: The Tax Con Cometh
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service is not emailing you to request personal information. Not now. Not ever.

headline: Microsoft Presents Low-Cost Phones and Windows 10 for Mobile
abstract: At the Mobile World Congress, the company for the first time showed off the operating system for phones and continued its evolving strategy of delivering low-cost Lumia devices.

headline: If Only G.E. Had an Activist Investor Who Cared
abstract: General Electric has been a beehive of activity, but the market thinks its shares are dead money, and such a perception may be difficult to shake off.

headline: Google Offers Cheap Storage for Certain Kinds of Data
abstract: Google just matched Amazon for cheap online storage, with an important difference: While Amazon promises to fetch the cheap data in hours, Google offers to do it in three seconds.

headline: Take Google to Court, Staff Report Urged F.T.C.
abstract: An internal Federal Trade Commission report recommended that the agency take action against Google for anticompetitive practices. The F.T.C. voted not to bring charges.

headline: IBM Scores Weather Data Deal and Starts Internet of Things Unit
abstract: IBM adds another big data source to its data analysis business in a partnership with the Weather Company.

headline: Orange Seeks Foreign Partner for Video Site Dailymotion
abstract: Orange’s chief executive discusses the non-French future of the video site Dailymotion.

headline: Uber’s Chief Financial Officer to Leave Company
abstract: Brent Callinicos, the chief financial officer of Uber, plans to leave the ride-sharing company, in what will be one of the highest-level departures yet for the six-year-old start-up.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Invests Another $52 Million in Network Start-Up Tanium
abstract: The new investment values the start-up at about $1.75 billion, or nearly double the valuation attached to its financing round last summer.

headline: F.T.C. Addresses Its Choice Not to Sue Google
abstract: The agency issued a rare statement defending its choice not to take legal action after investigating Google for anticompetitive behavior in 2011 and 2012.

headline: Slack, the Office Messaging App That May Finally Sink Email
abstract: The start-up Slack is changing the way workers communicate, with a group chat app that eschews privacy and automatically archives almost everything.

headline: Qualcomm and Intel to Introduce New Biometric Security Technology
abstract: Qualcomm has a new fingerprint reading technology that it hopes can eventually replace passwords both for devices and apps.

headline: Europe’s Digital Chief Vows to Intervene on Technology Abuses
abstract: Andrus Ansip reaffirmed the region’s tough stance on anticompetitive practices, data protection and tax avoidance in an interview at the Mobile World Congress.

headline: GoDaddy Said to Price I.P.O. Above Expected Range
abstract: The Internet registration company sold stock at $20 a share, raising $440 million and putting its market value at just more than $3 billion.

headline: Tech Executives Pressure Indiana After Passage of Controversial Law
abstract: An industry with a long history of supporting gay rights is starting to speak out against a new Indiana law that gives legal cover to people who refuse to do business with same-sex couples.

headline: Digital Learning Companies Falling Short of Student Privacy Pledge
abstract: A number of ed tech companies said they would improve the security and privacy of their services. But a new report concludes they are falling short of expectations.

headline: How to Find Old or Expired Websites
abstract: An Internet Archive offers a large and growing collection of web pages as they used to appear.

headline: Outdated Encryption Keys Leave Phones Vulnerable to Hackers
abstract: Apple and Google said they were releasing patches to fix the problem, which results in part from 1990s American technology export restrictions.

abstract: Patenting everything is so 2005. Companies like Facebook and Tesla Motors have followed the lead of open-source software, and now expose hardware designs possibly worth millions.

headline: Facebook Opens Messenger for App Developers
abstract: The social media giant has ambitious plans for its messaging service, including linking business to its user base.

headline: Nintendo Forms Partnership to Develop Mobile Games

headline: To Bring Virtual Reality to Market, Furious Efforts to Solve Nausea
abstract: Oculus VR, Sony, HTC and other headset makers have incorporated technology to combat motion sickness, paving the way to mass-marketing their products.

headline: Facebook’s Yann LeCun Discusses Digital Companions and Artificial Intelligence (and Emotions)

headline: Video Feature: Design Gains Importance as Devices Get More Personal
abstract: Experts say it’s not enough for a smartphone or other gadget to have all the software bells and whistles, it must also look and feel good.

headline: HTC Unveils a New Phone and Wearable Device
abstract: The company also discussed a new headset for activities in virtual reality, but the emphasis is on a device for fitness enthusiasts and another version of a well-reviewed smartphone.

abstract: Lots of places lay claim to being a budding tech innovation hub, some with more justification than others. Orlando, for instance, is no Provo.

abstract: In an industry that avoids controversy, the heads of several prominent companies, including Apple and Salesforce.com, have chosen to pick a battle.

headline: Salesforce’s Slow Growth May Prompt Hunt for a Buyer
abstract: Oracle and Microsoft want to increase cloud capacity, making them possible suitors.

abstract: How to give an old iPhone to a friend for use with Wi-Fi, to surf and use apps.

abstract: Amazon said in its first-quarter earnings report that its cloud division, Amazon Web Services, had revenue of $1.57 billion and operating income of $265 million.

abstract: Amazon said in its first-quarter earnings report that its cloud division, Amazon Web Services, had revenue of $1.57 billion and operating income of $265 million.

headline: Daily Report: Joining American Peers, Google Gets Caught in Europe’s Cross Hairs
abstract: American technology companies are no strangers to antitrust challenges by European regulators, but the cost has tended to be measured in money and time, not business practices.

abstract: As the antitrust case against Microsoft showed, the giants that look most unbeatable can falter in ways that have nothing to do with the actions of government regulators.

headline: Google Joins Its U.S. Peers Under Europe’s Scrutiny
abstract: American technology companies are no strangers to antitrust challenges by European regulators, but the cost has tended to be measured in money and time, not business practices.

abstract: Europe’s antitrust chief is expected to accuse the search giant of using its dominant position to favor its own services, a case that could force a change in its practices.

abstract: A deal with the telecommunications equipment maker could help Nokia battle competitors.

abstract: Margrethe Vestager, Europe’s antitrust regulator, is expected to change course with her predecessor and file charges that could hasten a settlement.

abstract: The pursuit of an I.P.O. reflects a wager that consumers will remain interested in tracking their health through devices strapped to their bodies.

abstract: A group of gamers act as solo tour guides for millions of Minecraft players, gradually creating their own genre of entertainment.

abstract: Those departing include Stephen Elop, the former Nokia chief executive, and Mark Penn, a former campaign strategist for Hillary and Bill Clinton.

abstract: The Surface Hub, which costs up to $20,000, will be made in Wilsonville, Ore., joining a small group of tech products that are made in America.

abstract: With $40 million from Microsoft, the Global Innovation Exchange will open in fall 2016, and offer a master’s degree in technology innovation.

abstract: In a report about data privacy published by the Electronic Frontier Foundation this week, tech companies like Yahoo, Apple and Adobe earned top marks, while WhatsApp and AT&T came in last.

abstract: With companies increasing their disclosures about contributions, perhaps campaign finance reformers should turn their attention elsewhere.

abstract: Pressure from competitors has compelled the company to make the upgrade free and to find new ways to profit from some of its big moneymakers.

The responses were funny, vulnerable and indicative of a universal sense of: “We’ve had enough.” The collective picture they painted was of a work force struggling to do tasks that were once easy, people who know they are lucky to have a job but dream of quitting, and who would do anything to never have a Zoom meeting again.
